author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: THE LIFE OF CASTRUCCIO CASTRACANI OF LUCCA

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Nicolo Machiavelli, born at Florence on 3rd May 1469. From 1494 to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: 1512 held an official post at Florence which included diplomatic

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: missions to various European courts. Imprisoned in Florence, 1512;

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: later exiled and returned to San Casciano. Died at Florence on 22nd

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: June 1527.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: INTRODUCTION

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Nicolo Machiavelli was born at Florence on 3rd May 1469. He was the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: second son of Bernardo di Nicolo Machiavelli, a lawyer of some repute,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and of Bartolommea di Stefano Nelli, his wife. Both parents were

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: members of the old Florentine nobility.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: His life falls naturally into three periods, each of which singularly

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: enough constitutes a distinct and important era in the history of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Florence. His youth was concurrent with the greatness of Florence as an

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Italian power under the guidance of Lorenzo de’ Medici, Il Magnifico.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: The downfall of the Medici in Florence occurred in 1494, in which year

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Machiavelli entered the public service. During his official career

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Florence was free under the government of a Republic, which lasted

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: until 1512, when the Medici returned to power, and Machiavelli lost his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: office. The Medici again ruled Florence from 1512 until 1527, when they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: were once more driven out. This was the period of Machiavelli’s

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: literary activity and increasing influence; but he died, within a few

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: weeks of the expulsion of the Medici, on 22nd June 1527, in his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: fifty-eighth year, without having regained office.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Although there is little recorded of the youth of Machiavelli, the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Florence of those days is so well known that the early environment of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: this representative citizen may be easily imagined. Florence has been

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: described as a city with two opposite currents of life, one directed by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the fervent and austere Savonarola, the other by the splendour-loving

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Lorenzo. Savonarola’s influence upon the young Machiavelli must have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: been slight, for although at one time he wielded immense power over the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: fortunes of Florence, he only furnished Machiavelli with a subject of a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: gibe in The Prince, where he is cited as an example of an unarmed

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prophet who came to a bad end. Whereas the magnificence of the Medicean

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: rule during the life of Lorenzo appeared to have impressed Machiavelli

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: strongly, for he frequently recurs to it in his writings, and it is to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Lorenzo’s grandson that he dedicates The Prince.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Machiavelli, in his “History of Florence,” gives us a picture of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: young men among whom his youth was passed. He writes: “They were freer

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: than their forefathers in dress and living, and spent more in other

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: kinds of excesses, consuming their time and money in idleness, gaming,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and women; their chief aim was to appear well dressed and to speak with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: wit and acuteness, whilst he who could wound others the most cleverly

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: was thought the wisest.” In a letter to his son Guido, Machiavelli

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: shows why youth should avail itself of its opportunities for study, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: leads us to infer that his own youth had been so occupied. He writes:

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: “I have received your letter, which has given me the greatest pleasure,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: especially because you tell me you are quite restored in health, than

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: which I could have no better news; for if God grant life to you, and to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: me, I hope to make a good man of you if you are willing to do your

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: share.” Then, writing of a new patron, he continues: “This will turn

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: out well for you, but it is necessary for you to study; since, then,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: you have no longer the excuse of illness, take pains to study letters

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and music, for you see what honour is done to me for the little skill I

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: have. Therefore, my son, if you wish to please me, and to bring success

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and honour to yourself, do right and study, because others will help

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: you if you help yourself.”

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: The second period of Machiavelli’s life was spent in the service of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: free Republic of Florence, which flourished, as stated above, from the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: expulsion of the Medici in 1494 until their return in 1512. After

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: serving four years in one of the public offices he was appointed

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Chancellor and Secretary to the Second Chancery, the Ten of Liberty and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Peace. Here we are on firm ground when dealing with the events of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Machiavelli’s life, for during this time he took a leading part in the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: affairs of the Republic, and we have its decrees, records, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: dispatches to guide us, as well as his own writings. A mere

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: recapitulation of a few of his transactions with the statesmen and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: soldiers of his time gives a fair indication of his activities, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: supplies the sources from which he drew the experiences and characters

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: which illustrate The Prince.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: His first mission was in 1499 to Catherina Sforza, “my lady of Forli”

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of The Prince, from whose conduct and fate he drew the moral that it

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: is far better to earn the confidence of the people than to rely on

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: fortresses. This is a very noticeable principle in Machiavelli, and is

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: urged by him in many ways as a matter of vital importance to princes.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: In 1500 he was sent to France to obtain terms from Louis XII for

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: continuing the war against Pisa: this king it was who, in his conduct

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of affairs in Italy, committed the five capital errors in statecraft

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: summarized in The Prince, and was consequently driven out. He, also,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: it was who made the dissolution of his marriage a condition of support

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to Pope Alexander VI; which leads Machiavelli to refer those who urge

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that such promises should be kept to what he has written concerning the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: faith of princes.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Machiavelli’s public life was largely occupied with events arising out

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of the ambitions of Pope Alexander VI and his son, Cesare Borgia, the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Duke Valentino, and these characters fill a large space of The

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Prince. Machiavelli never hesitates to cite the actions of the duke

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: for the benefit of usurpers who wish to keep the states they have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: seized; he can, indeed, find no precepts to offer so good as the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: pattern of Cesare Borgia’s conduct, insomuch that Cesare is acclaimed

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: by some critics as the “hero” of The Prince. Yet in The Prince the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: duke is in point of fact cited as a type of the man who rises on the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: fortune of others, and falls with them; who takes every course that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: might be expected from a prudent man but the course which will save

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: him; who is prepared for all eventualities but the one which happens;

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and who, when all his abilities fail to carry him through, exclaims

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that it was not his fault, but an extraordinary and unforeseen

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: fatality.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: On the death of Pius III, in 1503, Machiavelli was sent to Rome to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: watch the election of his successor, and there he saw Cesare Borgia

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: cheated into allowing the choice of the College to fall on Giuliano

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: delle Rovere (Julius II), who was one of the cardinals that had most

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: reason to fear the duke. Machiavelli, when commenting on this election,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: says that he who thinks new favours will cause great personages to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: forget old injuries deceives himself. Julius did not rest until he had

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ruined Cesare.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: It was to Julius II that Machiavelli was sent in 1506, when that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: pontiff was commencing his enterprise against Bologna; which he brought

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to a successful issue, as he did many of his other adventures, owing

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: chiefly to his impetuous character. It is in reference to Pope Julius

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that Machiavelli moralizes on the resemblance between Fortune and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: women, and concludes that it is the bold rather than the cautious man

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that will win and hold them both.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: It is impossible to follow here the varying fortunes of the Italian

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: states, which in 1507 were controlled by France, Spain, and Germany,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: with results that have lasted to our day; we are concerned with those

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: events, and with the three great actors in them, so far only as they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: impinge on the personality of Machiavelli. He had several meetings with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Louis XII of France, and his estimate of that monarch’s character has

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: already been alluded to. Machiavelli has painted Ferdinand of Aragon as

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the man who accomplished great things under the cloak of religion, but

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: who in reality had no mercy, faith, humanity, or integrity; and who,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: had he allowed himself to be influenced by such motives, would have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: been ruined. The Emperor Maximilian was one of the most interesting men

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of the age, and his character has been drawn by many hands; but

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Machiavelli, who was an envoy at his court in 1507-8, reveals the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: secret of his many failures when he describes him as a secretive man,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: without force of character—ignoring the human agencies necessary to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: carry his schemes into effect, and never insisting on the fulfilment of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: his wishes.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: The remaining years of Machiavelli’s official career were filled with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: events arising out of the League of Cambrai, made in 1508 between the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: three great European powers already mentioned and the pope, with the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: object of crushing the Venetian Republic. This result was attained in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the battle of Vaila, when Venice lost in one day all that she had won

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: in eight hundred years. Florence had a difficult part to play during

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: these events, complicated as they were by the feud which broke out

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: between the pope and the French, because friendship with France had

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: dictated the entire policy of the Republic. When, in 1511, Julius II

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: finally formed the Holy League against France, and with the assistance

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of the Swiss drove the French out of Italy, Florence lay at the mercy

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of the Pope, and had to submit to his terms, one of which was that the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Medici should be restored. The return of the Medici to Florence on 1st

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: September 1512, and the consequent fall of the Republic, was the signal

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: for the dismissal of Machiavelli and his friends, and thus put an end

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to his public career, for, as we have seen, he died without regaining

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: office.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: LITERATURE AND DEATH — Æt. 43-58—1512-27

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: On the return of the Medici, Machiavelli, who for a few weeks had

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: vainly hoped to retain his office under the new masters of Florence,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: was dismissed by decree dated 7th November 1512. Shortly after this he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: was accused of complicity in an abortive conspiracy against the Medici,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: imprisoned, and put to the question by torture. The new Medicean pope,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Leo X, procured his release, and he retired to his small property at

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: San Casciano, near Florence, where he devoted himself to literature. In

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: a letter to Francesco Vettori, dated 13th December 1513, he has left a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: very interesting description of his life at this period, which

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: elucidates his methods and his motives in writing The Prince. After

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: describing his daily occupations with his family and neighbours, he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: writes: “The evening being come, I return home and go to my study; at

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the entrance I pull off my peasant-clothes, covered with dust and dirt,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and put on my noble court dress, and thus becomingly re-clothed I pass

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: into the ancient courts of the men of old, where, being lovingly

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: received by them, I am fed with that food which is mine alone; where I

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: do not hesitate to speak with them, and to ask for the reason of their

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: actions, and they in their benignity answer me; and for four hours I

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: feel no weariness, I forget every trouble, poverty does not dismay,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: death does not terrify me; I am possessed entirely by those great men.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: And because Dante says:

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Knowledge doth come of learning well retained,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Unfruitful else,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: I have noted down what I have gained from their conversation, and have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: composed a small work on ‘Principalities,’ where I pour myself out as

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: fully as I can in meditation on the subject, discussing what a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: principality is, what kinds there are, how they can be acquired, how

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: they can be kept, why they are lost: and if any of my fancies ever

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: pleased you, this ought not to displease you: and to a prince,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: especially to a new one, it should be welcome: therefore I dedicate it

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to his Magnificence Giuliano. Filippo Casavecchio has seen it; he will

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: be able to tell you what is in it, and of the discourses I have had

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: with him; nevertheless, I am still enriching and polishing it.”

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: The “little book” suffered many vicissitudes before attaining the form

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: in which it has reached us. Various mental influences were at work

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: during its composition; its title and patron were changed; and for some

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: unknown reason it was finally dedicated to Lorenzo de’ Medici. Although

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Machiavelli discussed with Casavecchio whether it should be sent or

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: presented in person to the patron, there is no evidence that Lorenzo

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ever received or even read it: he certainly never gave Machiavelli any

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: employment. Although it was plagiarized during Machiavelli’s lifetime,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: The Prince was never published by him, and its text is still

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: disputable.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Machiavelli concludes his letter to Vettori thus: “And as to this

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: little thing [his book], when it has been read it will be seen that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: during the fifteen years I have given to the study of statecraft I have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: neither slept nor idled; and men ought ever to desire to be served by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: one who has reaped experience at the expense of others. And of my

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: loyalty none could doubt, because having always kept faith I could not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: now learn how to break it; for he who has been faithful and honest, as

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: I have, cannot change his nature; and my poverty is a witness to my

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: honesty.”

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Before Machiavelli had got The Prince off his hands he commenced his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: “Discourse on the First Decade of Titus Livius,” which should be read

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: concurrently with The Prince. These and several minor works occupied

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: him until the year 1518, when he accepted a small commission to look

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: after the affairs of some Florentine merchants at Genoa. In 1519 the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Medicean rulers of Florence granted a few political concessions to her

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: citizens, and Machiavelli with others was consulted upon a new

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: constitution under which the Great Council was to be restored; but on

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: one pretext or another it was not promulgated.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: In 1520 the Florentine merchants again had recourse to Machiavelli to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: settle their difficulties with Lucca, but this year was chiefly

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: remarkable for his re-entry into Florentine literary society, where he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: was much sought after, and also for the production of his “Art of War.”

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: It was in the same year that he received a commission at the instance

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of Cardinal de’ Medici to write the “History of Florence,” a task which

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: occupied him until 1525. His return to popular favour may have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: determined the Medici to give him this employment, for an old writer

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: observes that “an able statesman out of work, like a huge whale, will

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: endeavour to overturn the ship unless he has an empty cask to play

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: with.”

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: When the “History of Florence” was finished, Machiavelli took it to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Rome for presentation to his patron, Giuliano de’ Medici, who had in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the meanwhile become pope under the title of Clement VII. It is

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: somewhat remarkable that, as, in 1513, Machiavelli had written The

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Prince for the instruction of the Medici after they had just regained

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: power in Florence, so, in 1525, he dedicated the “History of Florence”

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to the head of the family when its ruin was now at hand. In that year

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the battle of Pavia destroyed the French rule in Italy, and left

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Francis I a prisoner in the hands of his great rival, Charles V. This

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: was followed by the sack of Rome, upon the news of which the popular

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: party at Florence threw off the yoke of the Medici, who were once more

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: banished.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Machiavelli was absent from Florence at this time, but hastened his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: return, hoping to secure his former office of secretary to the “Ten of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Liberty and Peace.” Unhappily he was taken ill soon after he reached

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Florence, where he died on 22nd June 1527.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: THE MAN AND HIS WORKS

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: No one can say where the bones of Machiavelli rest, but modern Florence

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: has decreed him a stately cenotaph in Santa Croce, by the side of her

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: most famous sons; recognizing that, whatever other nations may have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: found in his works, Italy found in them the idea of her unity and the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: germs of her renaissance among the nations of Europe. Whilst it is idle

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to protest against the world-wide and evil signification of his name,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: it may be pointed out that the harsh construction of his doctrine which

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: this sinister reputation implies was unknown to his own day, and that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the researches of recent times have enabled us to interpret him more

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: reasonably. It is due to these inquiries that the shape of an “unholy

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: necromancer,” which so long haunted men’s vision, has begun to fade.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Machiavelli was undoubtedly a man of great observation, acuteness, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: industry; noting with appreciative eye whatever passed before him, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: with his supreme literary gift turning it to account in his enforced

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: retirement from affairs. He does not present himself, nor is he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: depicted by his contemporaries, as a type of that rare combination, the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: successful statesman and author, for he appears to have been only

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: moderately prosperous in his several embassies and political

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: employments. He was misled by Catherina Sforza, ignored by Louis XII,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: overawed by Cesare Borgia; several of his embassies were quite barren

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of results; his attempts to fortify Florence failed, and the soldiery

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that he raised astonished everybody by their cowardice. In the conduct

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of his own affairs he was timid and time-serving; he dared not appear

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: by the side of Soderini, to whom he owed so much, for fear of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: compromising himself; his connection with the Medici was open to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: suspicion, and Giuliano appears to have recognized his real forte when

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: he set him to write the “History of Florence,” rather than employ him

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: in the state. And it is on the literary side of his character, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: there alone, that we find no weakness and no failure.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Although the light of almost four centuries has been focused on The

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Prince, its problems are still debatable and interesting, because they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: are the eternal problems between the ruled and their rulers. Such as

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: they are, its ethics are those of Machiavelli’s contemporaries; yet

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: they cannot be said to be out of date so long as the governments of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Europe rely on material rather than on moral forces. Its historical

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: incidents and personages become interesting by reason of the uses which

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Machiavelli makes of them to illustrate his theories of government and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: conduct.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Leaving out of consideration those maxims of state which still furnish

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: some European and eastern statesmen with principles of action, The

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Prince is bestrewn with truths that can be proved at every turn. Men

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: are still the dupes of their simplicity and greed, as they were in the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: days of Alexander VI. The cloak of religion still conceals the vices

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: which Machiavelli laid bare in the character of Ferdinand of Aragon.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Men will not look at things as they really are, but as they wish them

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to be—and are ruined. In politics there are no perfectly safe courses;

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prudence consists in choosing the least dangerous ones. Then—to pass to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: a higher plane—Machiavelli reiterates that, although crimes may win an

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: empire, they do not win glory. Necessary wars are just wars, and the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: arms of a nation are hallowed when it has no other resource but to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: fight.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: It is the cry of a far later day than Machiavelli’s that government

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: should be elevated into a living moral force, capable of inspiring the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: people with a just recognition of the fundamental principles of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: society; to this “high argument” The Prince contributes but little.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Machiavelli always refused to write either of men or of governments

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: otherwise than as he found them, and he writes with such skill and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: insight that his work is of abiding value. But what invests The

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Prince with more than a merely artistic or historical interest is the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: incontrovertible truth that it deals with the great principles which

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: still guide nations and rulers in their relationship with each other

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and their neighbours.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: In translating The Prince my aim has been to achieve at all costs an

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: exact literal rendering of the original, rather than a fluent

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: paraphrase adapted to the modern notions of style and expression.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Machiavelli was no facile phrasemonger; the conditions under which he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: wrote obliged him to weigh every word; his themes were lofty, his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: substance grave, his manner nobly plain and serious. Quis eo fuit

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: unquam in partiundis rebus, in definiendis, in explanandis pressior?

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: In The Prince, it may be truly said, there is reason assignable, not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: only for every word, but for the position of every word. To an

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Englishman of Shakespeare’s time the translation of such a treatise was

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: in some ways a comparatively easy task, for in those times the genius

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of the English more nearly resembled that of the Italian language; to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the Englishman of to-day it is not so simple. To take a single example:

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the word intrattenere, employed by Machiavelli to indicate the policy

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: adopted by the Roman Senate towards the weaker states of Greece, would

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: by an Elizabethan be correctly rendered “entertain,” and every

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: contemporary reader would understand what was meant by saying that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: “Rome entertained the Ætolians and the Achaeans without augmenting

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: their power.” But to-day such a phrase would seem obsolete and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ambiguous, if not unmeaning: we are compelled to say that “Rome

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: maintained friendly relations with the Ætolians,” etc., using four

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: words to do the work of one. I have tried to preserve the pithy brevity

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of the Italian so far as was consistent with an absolute fidelity to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the sense. If the result be an occasional asperity I can only hope that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the reader, in his eagerness to reach the author’s meaning, may

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: overlook the roughness of the road that leads him to it.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: DEDICATION

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: To the Magnificent Lorenzo Di Piero De’ Medici

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Those who strive to obtain the good graces of a prince are accustomed

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to come before him with such things as they hold most precious, or in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: which they see him take most delight; whence one often sees horses,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: arms, cloth of gold, precious stones, and similar ornaments presented

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to princes, worthy of their greatness.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Desiring therefore to present myself to your Magnificence with some

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: testimony of my devotion towards you, I have not found among my

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: possessions anything which I hold more dear than, or value so much as,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the knowledge of the actions of great men, acquired by long experience

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: in contemporary affairs, and a continual study of antiquity; which,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: having reflected upon it with great and prolonged diligence, I now

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: send, digested into a little volume, to your Magnificence.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: And although I may consider this work unworthy of your countenance,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: nevertheless I trust much to your benignity that it may be acceptable,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: seeing that it is not possible for me to make a better gift than to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: offer you the opportunity of understanding in the shortest time all

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that I have learnt in so many years, and with so many troubles and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: dangers; which work I have not embellished with swelling or magnificent

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: words, nor stuffed with rounded periods, nor with any extrinsic

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: allurements or adornments whatever, with which so many are accustomed

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to embellish their works; for I have wished either that no honour

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: should be given it, or else that the truth of the matter and the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: weightiness of the theme shall make it acceptable.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Nor do I hold with those who regard it as a presumption if a man of low

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and humble condition dare to discuss and settle the concerns of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: princes; because, just as those who draw landscapes place themselves

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: below in the plain to contemplate the nature of the mountains and of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: lofty places, and in order to contemplate the plains place themselves

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: upon high mountains, even so to understand the nature of the people it

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: needs to be a prince, and to understand that of princes it needs to be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of the people.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Take then, your Magnificence, this little gift in the spirit in which I

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: send it; wherein, if it be diligently read and considered by you, you

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: will learn my extreme desire that you should attain that greatness

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: which fortune and your other attributes promise. And if your

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Magnificence from the summit of your greatness will sometimes turn your

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: eyes to these lower regions, you will see how unmeritedly I suffer a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: great and continued malignity of fortune.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: THE PRINCE

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CHAPTER I.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: HOW MANY KINDS OF PRINCIPALITIES THERE ARE, AND BY WHAT MEANS THEY ARE

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ACQUIRED

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: All states, all powers, that have held and hold rule over men have been

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and are either republics or principalities.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Principalities are either hereditary, in which the family has been long

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: established; or they are new.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: The new are either entirely new, as was Milan to Francesco Sforza, or

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: they are, as it were, members annexed to the hereditary state of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prince who has acquired them, as was the kingdom of Naples to that of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the King of Spain.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Such dominions thus acquired are either accustomed to live under a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prince, or to live in freedom; and are acquired either by the arms of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the prince himself, or of others, or else by fortune or by ability.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CHAPTER II.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CONCERNING HEREDITARY PRINCIPALITIES

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: I will leave out all discussion on republics, inasmuch as in another

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: place I have written of them at length, and will address myself only to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: principalities. In doing so I will keep to the order indicated above,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and discuss how such principalities are to be ruled and preserved.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: I say at once there are fewer difficulties in holding hereditary

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: states, and those long accustomed to the family of their prince, than

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: new ones; for it is sufficient only not to transgress the customs of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: his ancestors, and to deal prudently with circumstances as they arise,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: for a prince of average powers to maintain himself in his state, unless

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: he be deprived of it by some extraordinary and excessive force; and if

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: he should be so deprived of it, whenever anything sinister happens to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the usurper, he will regain it.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: We have in Italy, for example, the Duke of Ferrara, who could not have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: withstood the attacks of the Venetians in ’84, nor those of Pope Julius

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: in ’10, unless he had been long established in his dominions. For the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: hereditary prince has less cause and less necessity to offend; hence it

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: happens that he will be more loved; and unless extraordinary vices

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: cause him to be hated, it is reasonable to expect that his subjects

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: will be naturally well disposed towards him; and in the antiquity and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: duration of his rule the memories and motives that make for change are

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: lost, for one change always leaves the toothing for another.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CHAPTER III.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CONCERNING MIXED PRINCIPALITIES

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: But the difficulties occur in a new principality. And firstly, if it be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: not entirely new, but is, as it were, a member of a state which, taken

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: collectively, may be called composite, the changes arise chiefly from

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: an inherent difficulty which there is in all new principalities; for

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: men change their rulers willingly, hoping to better themselves, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: this hope induces them to take up arms against him who rules: wherein

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: they are deceived, because they afterwards find by experience they have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: gone from bad to worse. This follows also on another natural and common

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: necessity, which always causes a new prince to burden those who have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: submitted to him with his soldiery and with infinite other hardships

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: which he must put upon his new acquisition.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: In this way you have enemies in all those whom you have injured in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: seizing that principality, and you are not able to keep those friends

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: who put you there because of your not being able to satisfy them in the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: way they expected, and you cannot take strong measures against them,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: feeling bound to them. For, although one may be very strong in armed

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: forces, yet in entering a province one has always need of the goodwill

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of the natives.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: For these reasons Louis the Twelfth, King of France, quickly occupied

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Milan, and as quickly lost it; and to turn him out the first time it

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: only needed Lodovico’s own forces; because those who had opened the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: gates to him, finding themselves deceived in their hopes of future

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: benefit, would not endure the ill-treatment of the new prince. It is

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: very true that, after acquiring rebellious provinces a second time,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: they are not so lightly lost afterwards, because the prince, with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: little reluctance, takes the opportunity of the rebellion to punish the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: delinquents, to clear out the suspects, and to strengthen himself in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the weakest places. Thus to cause France to lose Milan the first time

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: it was enough for the Duke Lodovico[1] to raise insurrections on the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: borders; but to cause him to lose it a second time it was necessary to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: bring the whole world against him, and that his armies should be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: defeated and driven out of Italy; which followed from the causes above

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: mentioned.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [1] Duke Lodovico was Lodovico Moro, a son of Francesco Sforza, who

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: married Beatrice d’Este. He ruled over Milan from 1494 to 1500, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: died in 1510.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Nevertheless Milan was taken from France both the first and the second

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: time. The general reasons for the first have been discussed; it remains

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to name those for the second, and to see what resources he had, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: what any one in his situation would have had for maintaining himself

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: more securely in his acquisition than did the King of France.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Now I say that those dominions which, when acquired, are added to an

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ancient state by him who acquires them, are either of the same country

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and language, or they are not. When they are, it is easier to hold

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: them, especially when they have not been accustomed to self-government;

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and to hold them securely it is enough to have destroyed the family of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the prince who was ruling them; because the two peoples, preserving in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: other things the old conditions, and not being unlike in customs, will

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: live quietly together, as one has seen in Brittany, Burgundy, Gascony,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and Normandy, which have been bound to France for so long a time: and,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: although there may be some difference in language, nevertheless the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: customs are alike, and the people will easily be able to get on amongst

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: themselves. He who has annexed them, if he wishes to hold them, has

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: only to bear in mind two considerations: the one, that the family of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: their former lord is extinguished; the other, that neither their laws

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: nor their taxes are altered, so that in a very short time they will

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: become entirely one body with the old principality.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: But when states are acquired in a country differing in language,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: customs, or laws, there are difficulties, and good fortune and great

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: energy are needed to hold them, and one of the greatest and most real

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: helps would be that he who has acquired them should go and reside

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: there. This would make his position more secure and durable, as it has

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: made that of the Turk in Greece, who, notwithstanding all the other

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: measures taken by him for holding that state, if he had not settled

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: there, would not have been able to keep it. Because, if one is on the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: spot, disorders are seen as they spring up, and one can quickly remedy

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: them; but if one is not at hand, they are heard of only when they are

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: great, and then one can no longer remedy them. Besides this, the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: country is not pillaged by your officials; the subjects are satisfied

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: by prompt recourse to the prince; thus, wishing to be good, they have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: more cause to love him, and wishing to be otherwise, to fear him. He

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: who would attack that state from the outside must have the utmost

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: caution; as long as the prince resides there it can only be wrested

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: from him with the greatest difficulty.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: The other and better course is to send colonies to one or two places,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: which may be as keys to that state, for it is necessary either to do

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: this or else to keep there a great number of cavalry and infantry. A

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prince does not spend much on colonies, for with little or no expense

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: he can send them out and keep them there, and he offends a minority

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: only of the citizens from whom he takes lands and houses to give them

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to the new inhabitants; and those whom he offends, remaining poor and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: scattered, are never able to injure him; whilst the rest being

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: uninjured are easily kept quiet, and at the same time are anxious not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to err for fear it should happen to them as it has to those who have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: been despoiled. In conclusion, I say that these colonies are not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: costly, they are more faithful, they injure less, and the injured, as

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: has been said, being poor and scattered, cannot hurt. Upon this, one

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: has to remark that men ought either to be well treated or crushed,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: because they can avenge themselves of lighter injuries, of more serious

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ones they cannot; therefore the injury that is to be done to a man

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ought to be of such a kind that one does not stand in fear of revenge.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: But in maintaining armed men there in place of colonies one spends much

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: more, having to consume on the garrison all the income from the state,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: so that the acquisition turns into a loss, and many more are

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: exasperated, because the whole state is injured; through the shifting

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of the garrison up and down all become acquainted with hardship, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: all become hostile, and they are enemies who, whilst beaten on their

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: own ground, are yet able to do hurt. For every reason, therefore, such

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: guards are as useless as a colony is useful.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Again, the prince who holds a country differing in the above respects

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ought to make himself the head and defender of his less powerful

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: neighbours, and to weaken the more powerful amongst them, taking care

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that no foreigner as powerful as himself shall, by any accident, get a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: footing there; for it will always happen that such a one will be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: introduced by those who are discontented, either through excess of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ambition or through fear, as one has seen already. The Romans were

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: brought into Greece by the Ætolians; and in every other country where

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: they obtained a footing they were brought in by the inhabitants. And

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the usual course of affairs is that, as soon as a powerful foreigner

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: enters a country, all the subject states are drawn to him, moved by the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: hatred which they feel against the ruling power. So that in respect to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: those subject states he has not to take any trouble to gain them over

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to himself, for the whole of them quickly rally to the state which he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: has acquired there. He has only to take care that they do not get hold

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of too much power and too much authority, and then with his own forces,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and with their goodwill, he can easily keep down the more powerful of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: them, so as to remain entirely master in the country. And he who does

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: not properly manage this business will soon lose what he has acquired,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and whilst he does hold it he will have endless difficulties and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: troubles.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: The Romans, in the countries which they annexed, observed closely these

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: measures; they sent colonies and maintained friendly relations with[2]

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the minor powers, without increasing their strength; they kept down the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: greater, and did not allow any strong foreign powers to gain authority.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Greece appears to me sufficient for an example. The Achaeans and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Ætolians were kept friendly by them, the kingdom of Macedonia was

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: humbled, Antiochus was driven out; yet the merits of the Achaeans and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Ætolians never secured for them permission to increase their power, nor

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: did the persuasions of Philip ever induce the Romans to be his friends

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: without first humbling him, nor did the influence of Antiochus make

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: them agree that he should retain any lordship over the country. Because

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the Romans did in these instances what all prudent princes ought to do,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: who have to regard not only present troubles, but also future ones, for

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: which they must prepare with every energy, because, when foreseen, it

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: is easy to remedy them; but if you wait until they approach, the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: medicine is no longer in time because the malady has become incurable;

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: for it happens in this, as the physicians say it happens in hectic

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: fever, that in the beginning of the malady it is easy to cure but

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: difficult to detect, but in the course of time, not having been either

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: detected or treated in the beginning, it becomes easy to detect but

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: difficult to cure. Thus it happens in affairs of state, for when the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: evils that arise have been foreseen (which it is only given to a wise

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: man to see), they can be quickly redressed, but when, through not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: having been foreseen, they have been permitted to grow in a way that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: every one can see them, there is no longer a remedy. Therefore, the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Romans, foreseeing troubles, dealt with them at once, and, even to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: avoid a war, would not let them come to a head, for they knew that war

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: is not to be avoided, but is only to be put off to the advantage of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: others; moreover they wished to fight with Philip and Antiochus in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Greece so as not to have to do it in Italy; they could have avoided

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: both, but this they did not wish; nor did that ever please them which

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: is forever in the mouths of the wise ones of our time:—Let us enjoy the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: benefits of the time—but rather the benefits of their own valour and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prudence, for time drives everything before it, and is able to bring

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: with it good as well as evil, and evil as well as good.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [2] See remark in the introduction on the word “intrattenere.”

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: But let us turn to France and inquire whether she has done any of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: things mentioned. I will speak of Louis[3] (and not of Charles)[4] as

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the one whose conduct is the better to be observed, he having held

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: possession of Italy for the longest period; and you will see that he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: has done the opposite to those things which ought to be done to retain

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: a state composed of divers elements.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [3] Louis XII, King of France, “The Father of the People,” born 1462,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: died 1515.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [4] Charles VIII, King of France, born 1470, died 1498.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: King Louis was brought into Italy by the ambition of the Venetians, who

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: desired to obtain half the state of Lombardy by his intervention. I

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: will not blame the course taken by the king, because, wishing to get a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: foothold in Italy, and having no friends there—seeing rather that every

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: door was shut to him owing to the conduct of Charles—he was forced to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: accept those friendships which he could get, and he would have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: succeeded very quickly in his design if in other matters he had not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: made some mistakes. The king, however, having acquired Lombardy,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: regained at once the authority which Charles had lost: Genoa yielded;

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the Florentines became his friends; the Marquess of Mantua, the Duke of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Ferrara, the Bentivogli, my lady of Forli, the Lords of Faenza, of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Pesaro, of Rimini, of Camerino, of Piombino, the Lucchese, the Pisans,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the Sienese—everybody made advances to him to become his friend. Then

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: could the Venetians realize the rashness of the course taken by them,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: which, in order that they might secure two towns in Lombardy, had made

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the king master of two-thirds of Italy.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Let any one now consider with what little difficulty the king could

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: have maintained his position in Italy had he observed the rules above

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: laid down, and kept all his friends secure and protected; for although

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: they were numerous they were both weak and timid, some afraid of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Church, some of the Venetians, and thus they would always have been

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: forced to stand in with him, and by their means he could easily have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: made himself secure against those who remained powerful. But he was no

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: sooner in Milan than he did the contrary by assisting Pope Alexander to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: occupy the Romagna. It never occurred to him that by this action he was

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: weakening himself, depriving himself of friends and of those who had

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: thrown themselves into his lap, whilst he aggrandized the Church by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: adding much temporal power to the spiritual, thus giving it greater

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: authority. And having committed this prime error, he was obliged to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: follow it up, so much so that, to put an end to the ambition of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Alexander, and to prevent his becoming the master of Tuscany, he was

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: himself forced to come into Italy.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: And as if it were not enough to have aggrandized the Church, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: deprived himself of friends, he, wishing to have the kingdom of Naples,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: divided it with the King of Spain, and where he was the prime arbiter

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: in Italy he takes an associate, so that the ambitious of that country

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and the malcontents of his own should have somewhere to shelter; and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: whereas he could have left in the kingdom his own pensioner as king, he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: drove him out, to put one there who was able to drive him, Louis, out

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: in turn.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: The wish to acquire is in truth very natural and common, and men always

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: do so when they can, and for this they will be praised not blamed; but

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: when they cannot do so, yet wish to do so by any means, then there is

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: folly and blame. Therefore, if France could have attacked Naples with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: her own forces she ought to have done so; if she could not, then she

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ought not to have divided it. And if the partition which she made with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the Venetians in Lombardy was justified by the excuse that by it she

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: got a foothold in Italy, this other partition merited blame, for it had

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: not the excuse of that necessity.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Therefore Louis made these five errors: he destroyed the minor powers,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: he increased the strength of one of the greater powers in Italy, he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: brought in a foreign power, he did not settle in the country, he did

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: not send colonies. Which errors, had he lived, were not enough to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: injure him had he not made a sixth by taking away their dominions from

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the Venetians; because, had he not aggrandized the Church, nor brought

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Spain into Italy, it would have been very reasonable and necessary to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: humble them; but having first taken these steps, he ought never to have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: consented to their ruin, for they, being powerful, would always have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: kept off others from designs on Lombardy, to which the Venetians would

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: never have consented except to become masters themselves there; also

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: because the others would not wish to take Lombardy from France in order

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to give it to the Venetians, and to run counter to both they would not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: have had the courage.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: And if any one should say: “King Louis yielded the Romagna to Alexander

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and the kingdom to Spain to avoid war,” I answer for the reasons given

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: above that a blunder ought never to be perpetrated to avoid war,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: because it is not to be avoided, but is only deferred to your

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: disadvantage. And if another should allege the pledge which the king

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: had given to the Pope that he would assist him in the enterprise, in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: exchange for the dissolution of his marriage[5] and for the cap to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Rouen,[6] to that I reply what I shall write later on concerning the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: faith of princes, and how it ought to be kept.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [5] Louis XII divorced his wife, Jeanne, daughter of Louis XI, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: married in 1499 Anne of Brittany, widow of Charles VIII, in order to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: retain the Duchy of Brittany for the crown.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [6] The Archbishop of Rouen. He was Georges d’Amboise, created a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: cardinal by Alexander VI. Born 1460, died 1510.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Thus King Louis lost Lombardy by not having followed any of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: conditions observed by those who have taken possession of countries and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: wished to retain them. Nor is there any miracle in this, but much that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: is reasonable and quite natural. And on these matters I spoke at Nantes

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: with Rouen, when Valentino, as Cesare Borgia, the son of Pope

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Alexander, was usually called, occupied the Romagna, and on Cardinal

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Rouen observing to me that the Italians did not understand war, I

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: replied to him that the French did not understand statecraft, meaning

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that otherwise they would not have allowed the Church to reach such

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: greatness. And in fact it has been seen that the greatness of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Church and of Spain in Italy has been caused by France, and her ruin

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: may be attributed to them. From this a general rule is drawn which

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: never or rarely fails: that he who is the cause of another becoming

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: powerful is ruined; because that predominancy has been brought about

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: either by astuteness or else by force, and both are distrusted by him

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: who has been raised to power.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CHAPTER IV.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: WHY THE KINGDOM OF DARIUS, CONQUERED BY ALEXANDER, DID NOT REBEL

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: AGAINST THE SUCCESSORS OF ALEXANDER AT HIS DEATH

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Considering the difficulties which men have had to hold to a newly

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: acquired state, some might wonder how, seeing that Alexander the Great

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: became the master of Asia in a few years, and died whilst it was

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: scarcely settled (whence it might appear reasonable that the whole

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: empire would have rebelled), nevertheless his successors maintained

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: themselves, and had to meet no other difficulty than that which arose

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: among themselves from their own ambitions.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: I answer that the principalities of which one has record are found to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: be governed in two different ways; either by a prince, with a body of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: servants, who assist him to govern the kingdom as ministers by his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: favour and permission; or by a prince and barons, who hold that dignity

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: by antiquity of blood and not by the grace of the prince. Such barons

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: have states and their own subjects, who recognize them as lords and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: hold them in natural affection. Those states that are governed by a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prince and his servants hold their prince in more consideration,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: because in all the country there is no one who is recognized as

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: superior to him, and if they yield obedience to another they do it as

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to a minister and official, and they do not bear him any particular

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: affection.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: The examples of these two governments in our time are the Turk and the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: King of France. The entire monarchy of the Turk is governed by one

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: lord, the others are his servants; and, dividing his kingdom into

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: sanjaks, he sends there different administrators, and shifts and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: changes them as he chooses. But the King of France is placed in the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: midst of an ancient body of lords, acknowledged by their own subjects,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and beloved by them; they have their own prerogatives, nor can the king

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: take these away except at his peril. Therefore, he who considers both

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of these states will recognize great difficulties in seizing the state

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of the Turk, but, once it is conquered, great ease in holding it. The

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: causes of the difficulties in seizing the kingdom of the Turk are that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the usurper cannot be called in by the princes of the kingdom, nor can

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: he hope to be assisted in his designs by the revolt of those whom the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: lord has around him. This arises from the reasons given above; for his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ministers, being all slaves and bondmen, can only be corrupted with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: great difficulty, and one can expect little advantage from them when

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: they have been corrupted, as they cannot carry the people with them,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: for the reasons assigned. Hence, he who attacks the Turk must bear in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: mind that he will find him united, and he will have to rely more on his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: own strength than on the revolt of others; but, if once the Turk has

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: been conquered, and routed in the field in such a way that he cannot

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: replace his armies, there is nothing to fear but the family of this

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prince, and, this being exterminated, there remains no one to fear, the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: others having no credit with the people; and as the conqueror did not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: rely on them before his victory, so he ought not to fear them after it.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: The contrary happens in kingdoms governed like that of France, because

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: one can easily enter there by gaining over some baron of the kingdom,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: for one always finds malcontents and such as desire a change. Such men,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: for the reasons given, can open the way into the state and render the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: victory easy; but if you wish to hold it afterwards, you meet with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: infinite difficulties, both from those who have assisted you and from

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: those you have crushed. Nor is it enough for you to have exterminated

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the family of the prince, because the lords that remain make themselves

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the heads of fresh movements against you, and as you are unable either

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to satisfy or exterminate them, that state is lost whenever time brings

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the opportunity.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Now if you will consider what was the nature of the government of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Darius, you will find it similar to the kingdom of the Turk, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: therefore it was only necessary for Alexander, first to overthrow him

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: in the field, and then to take the country from him. After which

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: victory, Darius being killed, the state remained secure to Alexander,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: for the above reasons. And if his successors had been united they would

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: have enjoyed it securely and at their ease, for there were no tumults

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: raised in the kingdom except those they provoked themselves.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: But it is impossible to hold with such tranquillity states constituted

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: like that of France. Hence arose those frequent rebellions against the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Romans in Spain, France, and Greece, owing to the many principalities

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: there were in these states, of which, as long as the memory of them

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: endured, the Romans always held an insecure possession; but with the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: power and long continuance of the empire the memory of them passed

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: away, and the Romans then became secure possessors. And when fighting

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: afterwards amongst themselves, each one was able to attach to himself

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: his own parts of the country, according to the authority he had assumed

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: there; and the family of the former lord being exterminated, none other

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: than the Romans were acknowledged.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: When these things are remembered no one will marvel at the ease with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: which Alexander held the Empire of Asia, or at the difficulties which

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: others have had to keep an acquisition, such as Pyrrhus and many more;

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: this is not occasioned by the little or abundance of ability in the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: conqueror, but by the want of uniformity in the subject state.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CHAPTER V.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CONCERNING THE WAY TO GOVERN CITIES OR PRINCIPALITIES WHICH LIVED UNDER

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: THEIR OWN LAWS BEFORE THEY WERE ANNEXED

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Whenever those states which have been acquired as stated have been

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: accustomed to live under their own laws and in freedom, there are three

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: courses for those who wish to hold them: the first is to ruin them, the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: next is to reside there in person, the third is to permit them to live

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: under their own laws, drawing a tribute, and establishing within it an

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: oligarchy which will keep it friendly to you. Because such a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: government, being created by the prince, knows that it cannot stand

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: without his friendship and interest, and does its utmost to support

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: him; and therefore he who would keep a city accustomed to freedom will

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: hold it more easily by the means of its own citizens than in any other

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: way.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: There are, for example, the Spartans and the Romans. The Spartans held

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Athens and Thebes, establishing there an oligarchy: nevertheless they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: lost them. The Romans, in order to hold Capua, Carthage, and Numantia,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: dismantled them, and did not lose them. They wished to hold Greece as

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the Spartans held it, making it free and permitting its laws, and did

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: not succeed. So to hold it they were compelled to dismantle many cities

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: in the country, for in truth there is no safe way to retain them

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: otherwise than by ruining them. And he who becomes master of a city

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: accustomed to freedom and does not destroy it, may expect to be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: destroyed by it, for in rebellion it has always the watchword of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: liberty and its ancient privileges as a rallying point, which neither

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: time nor benefits will ever cause it to forget. And whatever you may do

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: or provide against, they never forget that name or their privileges

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: unless they are disunited or dispersed, but at every chance they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: immediately rally to them, as Pisa after the hundred years she had been

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: held in bondage by the Florentines.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: But when cities or countries are accustomed to live under a prince, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: his family is exterminated, they, being on the one hand accustomed to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: obey and on the other hand not having the old prince, cannot agree in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: making one from amongst themselves, and they do not know how to govern

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: themselves. For this reason they are very slow to take up arms, and a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prince can gain them to himself and secure them much more easily. But

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: in republics there is more vitality, greater hatred, and more desire

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: for vengeance, which will never permit them to allow the memory of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: their former liberty to rest; so that the safest way is to destroy them

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: or to reside there.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CHAPTER VI.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CONCERNING NEW PRINCIPALITIES WHICH ARE ACQUIRED BY ONE’S OWN ARMS AND

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ABILITY

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Let no one be surprised if, in speaking of entirely new principalities

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: as I shall do, I adduce the highest examples both of prince and of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: state; because men, walking almost always in paths beaten by others,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and following by imitation their deeds, are yet unable to keep entirely

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to the ways of others or attain to the power of those they imitate. A

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: wise man ought always to follow the paths beaten by great men, and to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: imitate those who have been supreme, so that if his ability does not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: equal theirs, at least it will savour of it. Let him act like the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: clever archers who, designing to hit the mark which yet appears too far

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: distant, and knowing the limits to which the strength of their bow

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: attains, take aim much higher than the mark, not to reach by their

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: strength or arrow to so great a height, but to be able with the aid of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: so high an aim to hit the mark they wish to reach.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
