text: I say, therefore, that in entirely new principalities, where there is a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: new prince, more or less difficulty is found in keeping them,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: accordingly as there is more or less ability in him who has acquired

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the state. Now, as the fact of becoming a prince from a private station

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: presupposes either ability or fortune, it is clear that one or other of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: these things will mitigate in some degree many difficulties.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Nevertheless, he who has relied least on fortune is established the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: strongest. Further, it facilitates matters when the prince, having no

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: other state, is compelled to reside there in person.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: But to come to those who, by their own ability and not through fortune,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: have risen to be princes, I say that Moses, Cyrus, Romulus, Theseus,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and such like are the most excellent examples. And although one may not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: discuss Moses, he having been a mere executor of the will of God, yet

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: he ought to be admired, if only for that favour which made him worthy

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to speak with God. But in considering Cyrus and others who have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: acquired or founded kingdoms, all will be found admirable; and if their

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: particular deeds and conduct shall be considered, they will not be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: found inferior to those of Moses, although he had so great a preceptor.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: And in examining their actions and lives one cannot see that they owed

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: anything to fortune beyond opportunity, which brought them the material

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to mould into the form which seemed best to them. Without that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: opportunity their powers of mind would have been extinguished, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: without those powers the opportunity would have come in vain.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: It was necessary, therefore, to Moses that he should find the people of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Israel in Egypt enslaved and oppressed by the Egyptians, in order that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: they should be disposed to follow him so as to be delivered out of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: bondage. It was necessary that Romulus should not remain in Alba, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that he should be abandoned at his birth, in order that he should

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: become King of Rome and founder of the fatherland. It was necessary

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that Cyrus should find the Persians discontented with the government of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the Medes, and the Medes soft and effeminate through their long peace.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Theseus could not have shown his ability had he not found the Athenians

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: dispersed. These opportunities, therefore, made those men fortunate,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and their high ability enabled them to recognize the opportunity

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: whereby their country was ennobled and made famous.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Those who by valorous ways become princes, like these men, acquire a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: principality with difficulty, but they keep it with ease. The

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: difficulties they have in acquiring it rise in part from the new rules

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and methods which they are forced to introduce to establish their

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: government and its security. And it ought to be remembered that there

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: is nothing more difficult to take in hand, more perilous to conduct, or

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: more uncertain in its success, than to take the lead in the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: introduction of a new order of things, because the innovator has for

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: enemies all those who have done well under the old conditions, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: lukewarm defenders in those who may do well under the new. This

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: coolness arises partly from fear of the opponents, who have the laws on

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: their side, and partly from the incredulity of men, who do not readily

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: believe in new things until they have had a long experience of them.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Thus it happens that whenever those who are hostile have the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: opportunity to attack they do it like partisans, whilst the others

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: defend lukewarmly, in such wise that the prince is endangered along

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: with them.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: It is necessary, therefore, if we desire to discuss this matter

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: thoroughly, to inquire whether these innovators can rely on themselves

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: or have to depend on others: that is to say, whether, to consummate

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: their enterprise, have they to use prayers or can they use force? In

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the first instance they always succeed badly, and never compass

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: anything; but when they can rely on themselves and use force, then they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: are rarely endangered. Hence it is that all armed prophets have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: conquered, and the unarmed ones have been destroyed. Besides the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: reasons mentioned, the nature of the people is variable, and whilst it

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: is easy to persuade them, it is difficult to fix them in that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: persuasion. And thus it is necessary to take such measures that, when

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: they believe no longer, it may be possible to make them believe by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: force.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: If Moses, Cyrus, Theseus, and Romulus had been unarmed they could not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: have enforced their constitutions for long—as happened in our time to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Fra Girolamo Savonarola, who was ruined with his new order of things

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: immediately the multitude believed in him no longer, and he had no

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: means of keeping steadfast those who believed or of making the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: unbelievers to believe. Therefore such as these have great difficulties

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: in consummating their enterprise, for all their dangers are in the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ascent, yet with ability they will overcome them; but when these are

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: overcome, and those who envied them their success are exterminated,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: they will begin to be respected, and they will continue afterwards

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: powerful, secure, honoured, and happy.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: To these great examples I wish to add a lesser one; still it bears some

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: resemblance to them, and I wish it to suffice me for all of a like

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: kind: it is Hiero the Syracusan.[1] This man rose from a private

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: station to be Prince of Syracuse, nor did he, either, owe anything to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: fortune but opportunity; for the Syracusans, being oppressed, chose him

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: for their captain, afterwards he was rewarded by being made their

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prince. He was of so great ability, even as a private citizen, that one

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: who writes of him says he wanted nothing but a kingdom to be a king.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: This man abolished the old soldiery, organized the new, gave up old

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: alliances, made new ones; and as he had his own soldiers and allies, on

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: such foundations he was able to build any edifice: thus, whilst he had

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: endured much trouble in acquiring, he had but little in keeping.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [1] Hiero II, born about 307 B.C., died 216 B.C.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CHAPTER VII.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CONCERNING NEW PRINCIPALITIES WHICH ARE ACQUIRED EITHER BY THE ARMS OF

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: OTHERS OR BY GOOD FORTUNE

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Those who solely by good fortune become princes from being private

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: citizens have little trouble in rising, but much in keeping atop; they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: have not any difficulties on the way up, because they fly, but they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: have many when they reach the summit. Such are those to whom some state

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: is given either for money or by the favour of him who bestows it; as

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: happened to many in Greece, in the cities of Ionia and of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Hellespont, where princes were made by Darius, in order that they might

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: hold the cities both for his security and his glory; as also were those

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: emperors who, by the corruption of the soldiers, from being citizens

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: came to empire. Such stand simply elevated upon the goodwill and the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: fortune of him who has elevated them—two most inconstant and unstable

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: things. Neither have they the knowledge requisite for the position;

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: because, unless they are men of great worth and ability, it is not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: reasonable to expect that they should know how to command, having

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: always lived in a private condition; besides, they cannot hold it

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: because they have not forces which they can keep friendly and faithful.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: States that rise unexpectedly, then, like all other things in nature

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: which are born and grow rapidly, cannot leave their foundations and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: correspondencies[1] fixed in such a way that the first storm will not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: overthrow them; unless, as is said, those who unexpectedly become

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: princes are men of so much ability that they know they have to be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prepared at once to hold that which fortune has thrown into their laps,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and that those foundations, which others have laid before they became

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: princes, they must lay afterwards.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [1] “Le radici e corrispondenze,” their roots (i.e. foundations) and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: correspondencies or relations with other states—a common meaning of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: “correspondence” and “correspondency” in the sixteenth and seventeenth

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: centuries.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Concerning these two methods of rising to be a prince by ability or

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: fortune, I wish to adduce two examples within our own recollection, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: these are Francesco Sforza[2] and Cesare Borgia. Francesco, by proper

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: means and with great ability, from being a private person rose to be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Duke of Milan, and that which he had acquired with a thousand anxieties

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: he kept with little trouble. On the other hand, Cesare Borgia, called

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: by the people Duke Valentino, acquired his state during the ascendancy

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of his father, and on its decline he lost it, notwithstanding that he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: had taken every measure and done all that ought to be done by a wise

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and able man to fix firmly his roots in the states which the arms and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: fortunes of others had bestowed on him.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [2] Francesco Sforza, born 1401, died 1466. He married Bianca Maria

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Visconti, a natural daughter of Filippo Visconti, the Duke of Milan,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: on whose death he procured his own elevation to the duchy. Machiavelli

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: was the accredited agent of the Florentine Republic to Cesare Borgia

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: (1478-1507) during the transactions which led up to the assassinations

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of the Orsini and Vitelli at Sinigalia, and along with his letters to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: his chiefs in Florence he has left an account, written ten years

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: before The Prince, of the proceedings of the duke in his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: “Descritione del modo tenuto dal duca Valentino nello ammazzare

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Vitellozzo Vitelli,” etc., a translation of which is appended to the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: present work.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Because, as is stated above, he who has not first laid his foundations

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: may be able with great ability to lay them afterwards, but they will be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: laid with trouble to the architect and danger to the building. If,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: therefore, all the steps taken by the duke be considered, it will be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: seen that he laid solid foundations for his future power, and I do not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: consider it superfluous to discuss them, because I do not know what

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: better precepts to give a new prince than the example of his actions;

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and if his dispositions were of no avail, that was not his fault, but

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the extraordinary and extreme malignity of fortune.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Alexander the Sixth, in wishing to aggrandize the duke, his son, had

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: many immediate and prospective difficulties. Firstly, he did not see

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: his way to make him master of any state that was not a state of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Church; and if he was willing to rob the Church he knew that the Duke

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of Milan and the Venetians would not consent, because Faenza and Rimini

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: were already under the protection of the Venetians. Besides this, he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: saw the arms of Italy, especially those by which he might have been

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: assisted, in hands that would fear the aggrandizement of the Pope,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: namely, the Orsini and the Colonnesi and their following. It behoved

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: him, therefore, to upset this state of affairs and embroil the powers,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: so as to make himself securely master of part of their states. This was

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: easy for him to do, because he found the Venetians, moved by other

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: reasons, inclined to bring back the French into Italy; he would not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: only not oppose this, but he would render it more easy by dissolving

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the former marriage of King Louis. Therefore the king came into Italy

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: with the assistance of the Venetians and the consent of Alexander. He

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: was no sooner in Milan than the Pope had soldiers from him for the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: attempt on the Romagna, which yielded to him on the reputation of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: king. The duke, therefore, having acquired the Romagna and beaten the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Colonnesi, while wishing to hold that and to advance further, was

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: hindered by two things: the one, his forces did not appear loyal to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: him, the other, the goodwill of France: that is to say, he feared that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the forces of the Orsini, which he was using, would not stand to him,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that not only might they hinder him from winning more, but might

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: themselves seize what he had won, and that the king might also do the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: same. Of the Orsini he had a warning when, after taking Faenza and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: attacking Bologna, he saw them go very unwillingly to that attack. And

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: as to the king, he learned his mind when he himself, after taking the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Duchy of Urbino, attacked Tuscany, and the king made him desist from

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that undertaking; hence the duke decided to depend no more upon the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: arms and the luck of others.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: For the first thing he weakened the Orsini and Colonnesi parties in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Rome, by gaining to himself all their adherents who were gentlemen,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: making them his gentlemen, giving them good pay, and, according to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: their rank, honouring them with office and command in such a way that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: in a few months all attachment to the factions was destroyed and turned

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: entirely to the duke. After this he awaited an opportunity to crush the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Orsini, having scattered the adherents of the Colonna house. This came

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to him soon and he used it well; for the Orsini, perceiving at length

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that the aggrandizement of the duke and the Church was ruin to them,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: called a meeting of the Magione in Perugia. From this sprung the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: rebellion at Urbino and the tumults in the Romagna, with endless

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: dangers to the duke, all of which he overcame with the help of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: French. Having restored his authority, not to leave it at risk by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: trusting either to the French or other outside forces, he had recourse

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to his wiles, and he knew so well how to conceal his mind that, by the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: mediation of Signor Pagolo—whom the duke did not fail to secure with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: all kinds of attention, giving him money, apparel, and horses—the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Orsini were reconciled, so that their simplicity brought them into his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: power at Sinigalia.[3] Having exterminated the leaders, and turned

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: their partisans into his friends, the duke laid sufficiently good

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: foundations to his power, having all the Romagna and the Duchy of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Urbino; and the people now beginning to appreciate their prosperity, he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: gained them all over to himself. And as this point is worthy of notice,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and to be imitated by others, I am not willing to leave it out.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [3] Sinigalia, 31st December 1502.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: When the duke occupied the Romagna he found it under the rule of weak

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: masters, who rather plundered their subjects than ruled them, and gave

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: them more cause for disunion than for union, so that the country was

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: full of robbery, quarrels, and every kind of violence; and so, wishing

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to bring back peace and obedience to authority, he considered it

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: necessary to give it a good governor. Thereupon he promoted Messer

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Ramiro d’Orco,[4] a swift and cruel man, to whom he gave the fullest

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: power. This man in a short time restored peace and unity with the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: greatest success. Afterwards the duke considered that it was not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: advisable to confer such excessive authority, for he had no doubt but

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that he would become odious, so he set up a court of judgment in the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: country, under a most excellent president, wherein all cities had their

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: advocates. And because he knew that the past severity had caused some

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: hatred against himself, so, to clear himself in the minds of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: people, and gain them entirely to himself, he desired to show that, if

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: any cruelty had been practised, it had not originated with him, but in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the natural sternness of the minister. Under this pretence he took

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Ramiro, and one morning caused him to be executed and left on the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: piazza at Cesena with the block and a bloody knife at his side. The

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: barbarity of this spectacle caused the people to be at once satisfied

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and dismayed.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [4] Ramiro d’Orco. Ramiro de Lorqua.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: But let us return whence we started. I say that the duke, finding

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: himself now sufficiently powerful and partly secured from immediate

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: dangers by having armed himself in his own way, and having in a great

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: measure crushed those forces in his vicinity that could injure him if

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: he wished to proceed with his conquest, had next to consider France,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: for he knew that the king, who too late was aware of his mistake, would

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: not support him. And from this time he began to seek new alliances and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to temporize with France in the expedition which she was making towards

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the kingdom of Naples against the Spaniards who were besieging Gaeta.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: It was his intention to secure himself against them, and this he would

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: have quickly accomplished had Alexander lived.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Such was his line of action as to present affairs. But as to the future

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: he had to fear, in the first place, that a new successor to the Church

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: might not be friendly to him and might seek to take from him that which

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Alexander had given him, so he decided to act in four ways. Firstly, by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: exterminating the families of those lords whom he had despoiled, so as

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to take away that pretext from the Pope. Secondly, by winning to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: himself all the gentlemen of Rome, so as to be able to curb the Pope

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: with their aid, as has been observed. Thirdly, by converting the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: college more to himself. Fourthly, by acquiring so much power before

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the Pope should die that he could by his own measures resist the first

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: shock. Of these four things, at the death of Alexander, he had

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: accomplished three. For he had killed as many of the dispossessed lords

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: as he could lay hands on, and few had escaped; he had won over the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Roman gentlemen, and he had the most numerous party in the college. And

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: as to any fresh acquisition, he intended to become master of Tuscany,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: for he already possessed Perugia and Piombino, and Pisa was under his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: protection. And as he had no longer to study France (for the French

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: were already driven out of the kingdom of Naples by the Spaniards, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: in this way both were compelled to buy his goodwill), he pounced down

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: upon Pisa. After this, Lucca and Siena yielded at once, partly through

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: hatred and partly through fear of the Florentines; and the Florentines

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: would have had no remedy had he continued to prosper, as he was

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prospering the year that Alexander died, for he had acquired so much

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: power and reputation that he would have stood by himself, and no longer

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: have depended on the luck and the forces of others, but solely on his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: own power and ability.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: But Alexander died five years after he had first drawn the sword. He

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: left the duke with the state of Romagna alone consolidated, with the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: rest in the air, between two most powerful hostile armies, and sick

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: unto death. Yet there were in the duke such boldness and ability, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: he knew so well how men are to be won or lost, and so firm were the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: foundations which in so short a time he had laid, that if he had not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: had those armies on his back, or if he had been in good health, he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: would have overcome all difficulties. And it is seen that his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: foundations were good, for the Romagna awaited him for more than a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: month. In Rome, although but half alive, he remained secure; and whilst

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the Baglioni, the Vitelli, and the Orsini might come to Rome, they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: could not effect anything against him. If he could not have made Pope

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: him whom he wished, at least the one whom he did not wish would not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: have been elected. But if he had been in sound health at the death of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Alexander,[5] everything would have been different to him. On the day

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that Julius the Second[6] was elected, he told me that he had thought

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of everything that might occur at the death of his father, and had

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: provided a remedy for all, except that he had never anticipated that,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: when the death did happen, he himself would be on the point to die.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [5] Alexander VI died of fever, 18th August 1503.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [6] Julius II was Giuliano della Rovere, Cardinal of San Pietro ad

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Vincula, born 1443, died 1513.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: When all the actions of the duke are recalled, I do not know how to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: blame him, but rather it appears to be, as I have said, that I ought to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: offer him for imitation to all those who, by the fortune or the arms of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: others, are raised to government. Because he, having a lofty spirit and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: far-reaching aims, could not have regulated his conduct otherwise, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: only the shortness of the life of Alexander and his own sickness

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: frustrated his designs. Therefore, he who considers it necessary to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: secure himself in his new principality, to win friends, to overcome

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: either by force or fraud, to make himself beloved and feared by the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: people, to be followed and revered by the soldiers, to exterminate

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: those who have power or reason to hurt him, to change the old order of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: things for new, to be severe and gracious, magnanimous and liberal, to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: destroy a disloyal soldiery and to create new, to maintain friendship

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: with kings and princes in such a way that they must help him with zeal

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and offend with caution, cannot find a more lively example than the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: actions of this man.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Only can he be blamed for the election of Julius the Second, in whom he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: made a bad choice, because, as is said, not being able to elect a Pope

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to his own mind, he could have hindered any other from being elected

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Pope; and he ought never to have consented to the election of any

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: cardinal whom he had injured or who had cause to fear him if they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: became pontiffs. For men injure either from fear or hatred. Those whom

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: he had injured, amongst others, were San Pietro ad Vincula, Colonna,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: San Giorgio, and Ascanio.[7] The rest, in becoming Pope, had to fear

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: him, Rouen and the Spaniards excepted; the latter from their

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: relationship and obligations, the former from his influence, the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: kingdom of France having relations with him. Therefore, above

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: everything, the duke ought to have created a Spaniard Pope, and,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: failing him, he ought to have consented to Rouen and not San Pietro ad

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Vincula. He who believes that new benefits will cause great personages

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to forget old injuries is deceived. Therefore, the duke erred in his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: choice, and it was the cause of his ultimate ruin.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [7] San Giorgio is Raffaello Riario. Ascanio is Ascanio Sforza.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CHAPTER VIII.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CONCERNING THOSE WHO HAVE OBTAINED A PRINCIPALITY BY WICKEDNESS

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Although a prince may rise from a private station in two ways, neither

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of which can be entirely attributed to fortune or genius, yet it is

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: manifest to me that I must not be silent on them, although one could be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: more copiously treated when I discuss republics. These methods are

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: when, either by some wicked or nefarious ways, one ascends to the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: principality, or when by the favour of his fellow-citizens a private

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: person becomes the prince of his country. And speaking of the first

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: method, it will be illustrated by two examples—one ancient, the other

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: modern—and without entering further into the subject, I consider these

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: two examples will suffice those who may be compelled to follow them.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Agathocles, the Sicilian,[1] became King of Syracuse not only from a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: private but from a low and abject position. This man, the son of a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: potter, through all the changes in his fortunes always led an infamous

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: life. Nevertheless, he accompanied his infamies with so much ability of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: mind and body that, having devoted himself to the military profession,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: he rose through its ranks to be Praetor of Syracuse. Being established

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: in that position, and having deliberately resolved to make himself

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prince and to seize by violence, without obligation to others, that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: which had been conceded to him by assent, he came to an understanding

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: for this purpose with Amilcar, the Carthaginian, who, with his army,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: was fighting in Sicily. One morning he assembled the people and the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: senate of Syracuse, as if he had to discuss with them things relating

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to the Republic, and at a given signal the soldiers killed all the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: senators and the richest of the people; these dead, he seized and held

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the princedom of that city without any civil commotion. And although he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: was twice routed by the Carthaginians, and ultimately besieged, yet not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: only was he able to defend his city, but leaving part of his men for

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: its defence, with the others he attacked Africa, and in a short time

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: raised the siege of Syracuse. The Carthaginians, reduced to extreme

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: necessity, were compelled to come to terms with Agathocles, and,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: leaving Sicily to him, had to be content with the possession of Africa.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [1] Agathocles the Sicilian, born 361 B.C., died 289 B.C.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Therefore, he who considers the actions and the genius of this man will

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: see nothing, or little, which can be attributed to fortune, inasmuch as

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: he attained pre-eminence, as is shown above, not by the favour of any

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: one, but step by step in the military profession, which steps were

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: gained with a thousand troubles and perils, and were afterwards boldly

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: held by him with many hazardous dangers. Yet it cannot be called talent

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to slay fellow-citizens, to deceive friends, to be without faith,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: without mercy, without religion; such methods may gain empire, but not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: glory. Still, if the courage of Agathocles in entering into and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: extricating himself from dangers be considered, together with his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: greatness of mind in enduring and overcoming hardships, it cannot be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: seen why he should be esteemed less than the most notable captain.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Nevertheless, his barbarous cruelty and inhumanity with infinite

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: wickedness do not permit him to be celebrated among the most excellent

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: men. What he achieved cannot be attributed either to fortune or genius.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: In our times, during the rule of Alexander the Sixth, Oliverotto da

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Fermo, having been left an orphan many years before, was brought up by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: his maternal uncle, Giovanni Fogliani, and in the early days of his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: youth sent to fight under Pagolo Vitelli, that, being trained under his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: discipline, he might attain some high position in the military

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: profession. After Pagolo died, he fought under his brother Vitellozzo,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and in a very short time, being endowed with wit and a vigorous body

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and mind, he became the first man in his profession. But it appearing a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: paltry thing to serve under others, he resolved, with the aid of some

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: citizens of Fermo, to whom the slavery of their country was dearer than

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: its liberty, and with the help of the Vitelleschi, to seize Fermo. So

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: he wrote to Giovanni Fogliani that, having been away from home for many

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: years, he wished to visit him and his city, and in some measure to look

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: upon his patrimony; and although he had not laboured to acquire

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: anything except honour, yet, in order that the citizens should see he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: had not spent his time in vain, he desired to come honourably, so would

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: be accompanied by one hundred horsemen, his friends and retainers; and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: he entreated Giovanni to arrange that he should be received honourably

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: by the Fermians, all of which would be not only to his honour, but also

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to that of Giovanni himself, who had brought him up.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Giovanni, therefore, did not fail in any attentions due to his nephew,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and he caused him to be honourably received by the Fermians, and he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: lodged him in his own house, where, having passed some days, and having

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: arranged what was necessary for his wicked designs, Oliverotto gave a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: solemn banquet to which he invited Giovanni Fogliani and the chiefs of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Fermo. When the viands and all the other entertainments that are usual

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: in such banquets were finished, Oliverotto artfully began certain grave

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: discourses, speaking of the greatness of Pope Alexander and his son

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Cesare, and of their enterprises, to which discourse Giovanni and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: others answered; but he rose at once, saying that such matters ought to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: be discussed in a more private place, and he betook himself to a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: chamber, whither Giovanni and the rest of the citizens went in after

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: him. No sooner were they seated than soldiers issued from secret places

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and slaughtered Giovanni and the rest. After these murders Oliverotto,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: mounted on horseback, rode up and down the town and besieged the chief

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: magistrate in the palace, so that in fear the people were forced to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: obey him, and to form a government, of which he made himself the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prince. He killed all the malcontents who were able to injure him, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: strengthened himself with new civil and military ordinances, in such a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: way that, in the year during which he held the principality, not only

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: was he secure in the city of Fermo, but he had become formidable to all

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: his neighbours. And his destruction would have been as difficult as

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that of Agathocles if he had not allowed himself to be overreached by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Cesare Borgia, who took him with the Orsini and Vitelli at Sinigalia,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: as was stated above. Thus one year after he had committed this

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: parricide, he was strangled, together with Vitellozzo, whom he had made

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: his leader in valour and wickedness.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Some may wonder how it can happen that Agathocles, and his like, after

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: infinite treacheries and cruelties, should live for long secure in his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: country, and defend himself from external enemies, and never be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: conspired against by his own citizens; seeing that many others, by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: means of cruelty, have never been able even in peaceful times to hold

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the state, still less in the doubtful times of war. I believe that this

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: follows from severities[2] being badly or properly used. Those may be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: called properly used, if of evil it is possible to speak well, that are

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: applied at one blow and are necessary to one’s security, and that are

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: not persisted in afterwards unless they can be turned to the advantage

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of the subjects. The badly employed are those which, notwithstanding

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: they may be few in the commencement, multiply with time rather than

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: decrease. Those who practise the first system are able, by aid of God

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: or man, to mitigate in some degree their rule, as Agathocles did. It is

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: impossible for those who follow the other to maintain themselves.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [2] Mr Burd suggests that this word probably comes near the modern

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: equivalent of Machiavelli’s thought when he speaks of “crudelta” than

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the more obvious “cruelties.”

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Hence it is to be remarked that, in seizing a state, the usurper ought

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to examine closely into all those injuries which it is necessary for

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: him to inflict, and to do them all at one stroke so as not to have to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: repeat them daily; and thus by not unsettling men he will be able to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: reassure them, and win them to himself by benefits. He who does

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: otherwise, either from timidity or evil advice, is always compelled to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: keep the knife in his hand; neither can he rely on his subjects, nor

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: can they attach themselves to him, owing to their continued and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: repeated wrongs. For injuries ought to be done all at one time, so

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that, being tasted less, they offend less; benefits ought to be given

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: little by little, so that the flavour of them may last longer.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: And above all things, a prince ought to live amongst his people in such

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: a way that no unexpected circumstances, whether of good or evil, shall

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: make him change; because if the necessity for this comes in troubled

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: times, you are too late for harsh measures; and mild ones will not help

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: you, for they will be considered as forced from you, and no one will be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: under any obligation to you for them.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CHAPTER IX.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CONCERNING A CIVIL PRINCIPALITY

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: But coming to the other point—where a leading citizen becomes the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prince of his country, not by wickedness or any intolerable violence,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: but by the favour of his fellow citizens—this may be called a civil

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: principality: nor is genius or fortune altogether necessary to attain

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to it, but rather a happy shrewdness. I say then that such a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: principality is obtained either by the favour of the people or by the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: favour of the nobles. Because in all cities these two distinct parties

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: are found, and from this it arises that the people do not wish to be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ruled nor oppressed by the nobles, and the nobles wish to rule and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: oppress the people; and from these two opposite desires there arises in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: cities one of three results, either a principality, self-government, or

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: anarchy.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: A principality is created either by the people or by the nobles,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: accordingly as one or other of them has the opportunity; for the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: nobles, seeing they cannot withstand the people, begin to cry up the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: reputation of one of themselves, and they make him a prince, so that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: under his shadow they can give vent to their ambitions. The people,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: finding they cannot resist the nobles, also cry up the reputation of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: one of themselves, and make him a prince so as to be defended by his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: authority. He who obtains sovereignty by the assistance of the nobles

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: maintains himself with more difficulty than he who comes to it by the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: aid of the people, because the former finds himself with many around

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: him who consider themselves his equals, and because of this he can

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: neither rule nor manage them to his liking. But he who reaches

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: sovereignty by popular favour finds himself alone, and has none around

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: him, or few, who are not prepared to obey him.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Besides this, one cannot by fair dealing, and without injury to others,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: satisfy the nobles, but you can satisfy the people, for their object is

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: more righteous than that of the nobles, the latter wishing to oppress,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: while the former only desire not to be oppressed. It is to be added

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: also that a prince can never secure himself against a hostile people,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: because of there being too many, whilst from the nobles he can secure

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: himself, as they are few in number. The worst that a prince may expect

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: from a hostile people is to be abandoned by them; but from hostile

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: nobles he has not only to fear abandonment, but also that they will

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: rise against him; for they, being in these affairs more far-seeing and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: astute, always come forward in time to save themselves, and to obtain

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: favours from him whom they expect to prevail. Further, the prince is

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: compelled to live always with the same people, but he can do well

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: without the same nobles, being able to make and unmake them daily, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to give or take away authority when it pleases him.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Therefore, to make this point clearer, I say that the nobles ought to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: be looked at mainly in two ways: that is to say, they either shape

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: their course in such a way as binds them entirely to your fortune, or

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: they do not. Those who so bind themselves, and are not rapacious, ought

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to be honoured and loved; those who do not bind themselves may be dealt

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: with in two ways; they may fail to do this through pusillanimity and a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: natural want of courage, in which case you ought to make use of them,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: especially of those who are of good counsel; and thus, whilst in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prosperity you honour them, in adversity you do not have to fear them.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: But when for their own ambitious ends they shun binding themselves, it

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: is a token that they are giving more thought to themselves than to you,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and a prince ought to guard against such, and to fear them as if they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: were open enemies, because in adversity they always help to ruin him.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Therefore, one who becomes a prince through the favour of the people

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ought to keep them friendly, and this he can easily do seeing they only

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ask not to be oppressed by him. But one who, in opposition to the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: people, becomes a prince by the favour of the nobles, ought, above

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: everything, to seek to win the people over to himself, and this he may

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: easily do if he takes them under his protection. Because men, when they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: receive good from him of whom they were expecting evil, are bound more

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: closely to their benefactor; thus the people quickly become more

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: devoted to him than if he had been raised to the principality by their

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: favours; and the prince can win their affections in many ways, but as

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: these vary according to the circumstances one cannot give fixed rules,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: so I omit them; but, I repeat, it is necessary for a prince to have the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: people friendly, otherwise he has no security in adversity.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Nabis,[1] Prince of the Spartans, sustained the attack of all Greece,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and of a victorious Roman army, and against them he defended his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: country and his government; and for the overcoming of this peril it was

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: only necessary for him to make himself secure against a few, but this

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: would not have been sufficient had the people been hostile. And do not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: let any one impugn this statement with the trite proverb that “He who

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: builds on the people, builds on the mud,” for this is true when a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: private citizen makes a foundation there, and persuades himself that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the people will free him when he is oppressed by his enemies or by the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: magistrates; wherein he would find himself very often deceived, as

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: happened to the Gracchi in Rome and to Messer Giorgio Scali[2] in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Florence. But granted a prince who has established himself as above,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: who can command, and is a man of courage, undismayed in adversity, who

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: does not fail in other qualifications, and who, by his resolution and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: energy, keeps the whole people encouraged—such a one will never find

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: himself deceived in them, and it will be shown that he has laid his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: foundations well.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [1] Nabis, tyrant of Sparta, conquered by the Romans under Flamininus

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: in 195 B.C.; killed 192 B.C.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [2] Messer Giorgio Scali. This event is to be found in Machiavelli’s

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: “Florentine History,” Book III.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: These principalities are liable to danger when they are passing from

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the civil to the absolute order of government, for such princes either

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: rule personally or through magistrates. In the latter case their

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: government is weaker and more insecure, because it rests entirely on

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the goodwill of those citizens who are raised to the magistracy, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: who, especially in troubled times, can destroy the government with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: great ease, either by intrigue or open defiance; and the prince has not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the chance amid tumults to exercise absolute authority, because the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: citizens and subjects, accustomed to receive orders from magistrates,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: are not of a mind to obey him amid these confusions, and there will

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: always be in doubtful times a scarcity of men whom he can trust. For

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: such a prince cannot rely upon what he observes in quiet times, when

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: citizens have need of the state, because then every one agrees with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: him; they all promise, and when death is far distant they all wish to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: die for him; but in troubled times, when the state has need of its

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: citizens, then he finds but few. And so much the more is this

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: experiment dangerous, inasmuch as it can only be tried once. Therefore

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: a wise prince ought to adopt such a course that his citizens will

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: always in every sort and kind of circumstance have need of the state

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and of him, and then he will always find them faithful.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CHAPTER X.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CONCERNING THE WAY IN WHICH THE STRENGTH OF ALL PRINCIPALITIES OUGHT TO

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: BE MEASURED

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: It is necessary to consider another point in examining the character of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: these principalities: that is, whether a prince has such power that, in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: case of need, he can support himself with his own resources, or whether

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: he has always need of the assistance of others. And to make this quite

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: clear I say that I consider those who are able to support themselves by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: their own resources who can, either by abundance of men or money, raise

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: a sufficient army to join battle against any one who comes to attack

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: them; and I consider those always to have need of others who cannot

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: show themselves against the enemy in the field, but are forced to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: defend themselves by sheltering behind walls. The first case has been

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: discussed, but we will speak of it again should it recur. In the second

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: case one can say nothing except to encourage such princes to provision

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and fortify their towns, and not on any account to defend the country.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: And whoever shall fortify his town well, and shall have managed the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: other concerns of his subjects in the way stated above, and to be often

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: repeated, will never be attacked without great caution, for men are

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: always adverse to enterprises where difficulties can be seen, and it

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: will be seen not to be an easy thing to attack one who has his town

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: well fortified, and is not hated by his people.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: The cities of Germany are absolutely free, they own but little country

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: around them, and they yield obedience to the emperor when it suits

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: them, nor do they fear this or any other power they may have near them,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: because they are fortified in such a way that every one thinks the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: taking of them by assault would be tedious and difficult, seeing they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: have proper ditches and walls, they have sufficient artillery, and they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: always keep in public depots enough for one year’s eating, drinking,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and firing. And beyond this, to keep the people quiet and without loss

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to the state, they always have the means of giving work to the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: community in those labours that are the life and strength of the city,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and on the pursuit of which the people are supported; they also hold

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: military exercises in repute, and moreover have many ordinances to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: uphold them.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Therefore, a prince who has a strong city, and had not made himself

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: odious, will not be attacked, or if any one should attack he will only

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: be driven off with disgrace; again, because that the affairs of this

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: world are so changeable, it is almost impossible to keep an army a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: whole year in the field without being interfered with. And whoever

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: should reply: If the people have property outside the city, and see it

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: burnt, they will not remain patient, and the long siege and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: self-interest will make them forget their prince; to this I answer that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: a powerful and courageous prince will overcome all such difficulties by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: giving at one time hope to his subjects that the evil will not be for

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: long, at another time fear of the cruelty of the enemy, then preserving

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: himself adroitly from those subjects who seem to him to be too bold.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Further, the enemy would naturally on his arrival at once burn and ruin

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the country at the time when the spirits of the people are still hot

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and ready for the defence; and, therefore, so much the less ought the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prince to hesitate; because after a time, when spirits have cooled, the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: damage is already done, the ills are incurred, and there is no longer

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: any remedy; and therefore they are so much the more ready to unite with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: their prince, he appearing to be under obligations to them now that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: their houses have been burnt and their possessions ruined in his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: defence. For it is the nature of men to be bound by the benefits they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: confer as much as by those they receive. Therefore, if everything is

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: well considered, it will not be difficult for a wise prince to keep the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: minds of his citizens steadfast from first to last, when he does not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: fail to support and defend them.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CHAPTER XI.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CONCERNING ECCLESIASTICAL PRINCIPALITIES

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: It only remains now to speak of ecclesiastical principalities, touching

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: which all difficulties are prior to getting possession, because they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: are acquired either by capacity or good fortune, and they can be held

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: without either; for they are sustained by the ancient ordinances of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: religion, which are so all-powerful, and of such a character that the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: principalities may be held no matter how their princes behave and live.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: These princes alone have states and do not defend them; and they have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: subjects and do not rule them; and the states, although unguarded, are

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: not taken from them, and the subjects, although not ruled, do not care,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and they have neither the desire nor the ability to alienate

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: themselves. Such principalities only are secure and happy. But being

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: upheld by powers, to which the human mind cannot reach, I shall speak

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: no more of them, because, being exalted and maintained by God, it would

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: be the act of a presumptuous and rash man to discuss them.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Nevertheless, if any one should ask of me how comes it that the Church

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: has attained such greatness in temporal power, seeing that from

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Alexander backwards the Italian potentates (not only those who have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: been called potentates, but every baron and lord, though the smallest)

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: have valued the temporal power very slightly—yet now a king of France

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: trembles before it, and it has been able to drive him from Italy, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to ruin the Venetians—although this may be very manifest, it does not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: appear to me superfluous to recall it in some measure to memory.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Before Charles, King of France, passed into Italy,[1] this country was

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: under the dominion of the Pope, the Venetians, the King of Naples, the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Duke of Milan, and the Florentines. These potentates had two principal

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: anxieties: the one, that no foreigner should enter Italy under arms;

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the other, that none of themselves should seize more territory. Those

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: about whom there was the most anxiety were the Pope and the Venetians.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: To restrain the Venetians the union of all the others was necessary, as

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: it was for the defence of Ferrara; and to keep down the Pope they made

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: use of the barons of Rome, who, being divided into two factions, Orsini

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and Colonnesi, had always a pretext for disorder, and, standing with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: arms in their hands under the eyes of the Pontiff, kept the pontificate

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: weak and powerless. And although there might arise sometimes a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: courageous pope, such as Sixtus, yet neither fortune nor wisdom could

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: rid him of these annoyances. And the short life of a pope is also a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: cause of weakness; for in the ten years, which is the average life of a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: pope, he can with difficulty lower one of the factions; and if, so to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: speak, one people should almost destroy the Colonnesi, another would

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: arise hostile to the Orsini, who would support their opponents, and yet

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: would not have time to ruin the Orsini. This was the reason why the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: temporal powers of the pope were little esteemed in Italy.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [1] Charles VIII invaded Italy in 1494.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Alexander the Sixth arose afterwards, who of all the pontiffs that have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ever been showed how a pope with both money and arms was able to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prevail; and through the instrumentality of the Duke Valentino, and by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: reason of the entry of the French, he brought about all those things

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: which I have discussed above in the actions of the duke. And although

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: his intention was not to aggrandize the Church, but the duke,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: nevertheless, what he did contributed to the greatness of the Church,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: which, after his death and the ruin of the duke, became the heir to all

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: his labours.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Pope Julius came afterwards and found the Church strong, possessing all

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the Romagna, the barons of Rome reduced to impotence, and, through the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: chastisements of Alexander, the factions wiped out; he also found the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: way open to accumulate money in a manner such as had never been

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: practised before Alexander’s time. Such things Julius not only

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: followed, but improved upon, and he intended to gain Bologna, to ruin

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the Venetians, and to drive the French out of Italy. All of these

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: enterprises prospered with him, and so much the more to his credit,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: inasmuch as he did everything to strengthen the Church and not any

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: private person. He kept also the Orsini and Colonnesi factions within

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the bounds in which he found them; and although there was among them

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: some mind to make disturbance, nevertheless he held two things firm:

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the one, the greatness of the Church, with which he terrified them; and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the other, not allowing them to have their own cardinals, who caused

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the disorders among them. For whenever these factions have their

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: cardinals they do not remain quiet for long, because cardinals foster

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the factions in Rome and out of it, and the barons are compelled to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: support them, and thus from the ambitions of prelates arise disorders

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and tumults among the barons. For these reasons his Holiness Pope

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Leo[2] found the pontificate most powerful, and it is to be hoped that,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: if others made it great in arms, he will make it still greater and more

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: venerated by his goodness and infinite other virtues.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [2] Pope Leo X was the Cardinal de’ Medici.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CHAPTER XII.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: HOW MANY KINDS OF SOLDIERY THERE ARE, AND CONCERNING MERCENARIES

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Having discoursed particularly on the characteristics of such

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: principalities as in the beginning I proposed to discuss, and having

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: considered in some degree the causes of there being good or bad, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: having shown the methods by which many have sought to acquire them and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to hold them, it now remains for me to discuss generally the means of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: offence and defence which belong to each of them.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: We have seen above how necessary it is for a prince to have his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: foundations well laid, otherwise it follows of necessity he will go to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ruin. The chief foundations of all states, new as well as old or

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: composite, are good laws and good arms; and as there cannot be good

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: laws where the state is not well armed, it follows that where they are

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: well armed they have good laws. I shall leave the laws out of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: discussion and shall speak of the arms.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: I say, therefore, that the arms with which a prince defends his state

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: are either his own, or they are mercenaries, auxiliaries, or mixed.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Mercenaries and auxiliaries are useless and dangerous; and if one holds

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: his state based on these arms, he will stand neither firm nor safe; for

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: they are disunited, ambitious, and without discipline, unfaithful,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: valiant before friends, cowardly before enemies; they have neither the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: fear of God nor fidelity to men, and destruction is deferred only so

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: long as the attack is; for in peace one is robbed by them, and in war

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: by the enemy. The fact is, they have no other attraction or reason for

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: keeping the field than a trifle of stipend, which is not sufficient to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: make them willing to die for you. They are ready enough to be your

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: soldiers whilst you do not make war, but if war comes they take

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: themselves off or run from the foe; which I should have little trouble

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to prove, for the ruin of Italy has been caused by nothing else than by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: resting all her hopes for many years on mercenaries, and although they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: formerly made some display and appeared valiant amongst themselves, yet

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: when the foreigners came they showed what they were. Thus it was that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Charles, King of France, was allowed to seize Italy with chalk in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: hand;[1] and he who told us that our sins were the cause of it told the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: truth, but they were not the sins he imagined, but those which I have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: related. And as they were the sins of princes, it is the princes who

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: have also suffered the penalty.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [1] “With chalk in hand,” “col gesso.” This is one of the bons mots

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of Alexander VI, and refers to the ease with which Charles VIII seized

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Italy, implying that it was only necessary for him to send his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: quartermasters to chalk up the billets for his soldiers to conquer the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: country. Cf. “The History of Henry VII,” by Lord Bacon: “King

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Charles had conquered the realm of Naples, and lost it again, in a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: kind of a felicity of a dream. He passed the whole length of Italy

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: without resistance: so that it was true what Pope Alexander was wont

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to say: That the Frenchmen came into Italy with chalk in their hands,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to mark up their lodgings, rather than with swords to fight.”

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: I wish to demonstrate further the infelicity of these arms. The

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: mercenary captains are either capable men or they are not; if they are,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: you cannot trust them, because they always aspire to their own

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: greatness, either by oppressing you, who are their master, or others

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: contrary to your intentions; but if the captain is not skilful, you are

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ruined in the usual way.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: And if it be urged that whoever is armed will act in the same way,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: whether mercenary or not, I reply that when arms have to be resorted

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to, either by a prince or a republic, then the prince ought to go in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: person and perform the duty of a captain; the republic has to send its

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: citizens, and when one is sent who does not turn out satisfactorily, it

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ought to recall him, and when one is worthy, to hold him by the laws so

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that he does not leave the command. And experience has shown princes

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and republics, single-handed, making the greatest progress, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: mercenaries doing nothing except damage; and it is more difficult to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: bring a republic, armed with its own arms, under the sway of one of its

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: citizens than it is to bring one armed with foreign arms. Rome and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Sparta stood for many ages armed and free. The Switzers are completely

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: armed and quite free.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Of ancient mercenaries, for example, there are the Carthaginians, who

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: were oppressed by their mercenary soldiers after the first war with the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Romans, although the Carthaginians had their own citizens for captains.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: After the death of Epaminondas, Philip of Macedon was made captain of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: their soldiers by the Thebans, and after victory he took away their

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: liberty.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Duke Filippo being dead, the Milanese enlisted Francesco Sforza against

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the Venetians, and he, having overcome the enemy at Caravaggio,[2]

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: allied himself with them to crush the Milanese, his masters. His

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: father, Sforza, having been engaged by Queen Johanna[3] of Naples, left

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: her unprotected, so that she was forced to throw herself into the arms

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of the King of Aragon, in order to save her kingdom. And if the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Venetians and Florentines formerly extended their dominions by these

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: arms, and yet their captains did not make themselves princes, but have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: defended them, I reply that the Florentines in this case have been

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: favoured by chance, for of the able captains, of whom they might have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: stood in fear, some have not conquered, some have been opposed, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: others have turned their ambitions elsewhere. One who did not conquer

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: was Giovanni Acuto,[4] and since he did not conquer his fidelity cannot

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: be proved; but every one will acknowledge that, had he conquered, the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Florentines would have stood at his discretion. Sforza had the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Bracceschi always against him, so they watched each other. Francesco

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: turned his ambition to Lombardy; Braccio against the Church and the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: kingdom of Naples. But let us come to that which happened a short while

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
