text: ago. The Florentines appointed as their captain Pagolo Vitelli, a most

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prudent man, who from a private position had risen to the greatest

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: renown. If this man had taken Pisa, nobody can deny that it would have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: been proper for the Florentines to keep in with him, for if he became

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the soldier of their enemies they had no means of resisting, and if

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: they held to him they must obey him. The Venetians, if their

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: achievements are considered, will be seen to have acted safely and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: gloriously so long as they sent to war their own men, when with armed

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: gentlemen and plebians they did valiantly. This was before they turned

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to enterprises on land, but when they began to fight on land they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: forsook this virtue and followed the custom of Italy. And in the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: beginning of their expansion on land, through not having much

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: territory, and because of their great reputation, they had not much to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: fear from their captains; but when they expanded, as under

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Carmignuola,[5] they had a taste of this mistake; for, having found him

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: a most valiant man (they beat the Duke of Milan under his leadership),

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and, on the other hand, knowing how lukewarm he was in the war, they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: feared they would no longer conquer under him, and for this reason they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: were not willing, nor were they able, to let him go; and so, not to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: lose again that which they had acquired, they were compelled, in order

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to secure themselves, to murder him. They had afterwards for their

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: captains Bartolomeo da Bergamo, Roberto da San Severino, the count of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Pitigliano,[6] and the like, under whom they had to dread loss and not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: gain, as happened afterwards at Vaila,[7] where in one battle they lost

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that which in eight hundred years they had acquired with so much

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: trouble. Because from such arms conquests come but slowly, long delayed

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and inconsiderable, but the losses sudden and portentous.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [2] Battle of Caravaggio, 15th September 1448.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [3] Johanna II of Naples, the widow of Ladislao, King of Naples.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [4] Giovanni Acuto. An English knight whose name was Sir John

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Hawkwood. He fought in the English wars in France, and was knighted by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Edward III; afterwards he collected a body of troops and went into

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Italy. These became the famous “White Company.” He took part in many

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: wars, and died in Florence in 1394. He was born about 1320 at Sible

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Hedingham, a village in Essex. He married Domnia, a daughter of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Bernabo Visconti.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [5] Carmignuola. Francesco Bussone, born at Carmagnola about 1390,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: executed at Venice, 5th May 1432.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [6] Bartolomeo Colleoni of Bergamo; died 1457. Roberto of San

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Severino; died fighting for Venice against Sigismund, Duke of Austria,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: in 1487. “Primo capitano in Italia.”—Machiavelli. Count of Pitigliano;

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Nicolo Orsini, born 1442, died 1510.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [7] Battle of Vaila in 1509.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: And as with these examples I have reached Italy, which has been ruled

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: for many years by mercenaries, I wish to discuss them more seriously,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: in order that, having seen their rise and progress, one may be better

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prepared to counteract them. You must understand that the empire has

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: recently come to be repudiated in Italy, that the Pope has acquired

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: more temporal power, and that Italy has been divided up into more

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: states, for the reason that many of the great cities took up arms

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: against their nobles, who, formerly favoured by the emperor, were

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: oppressing them, whilst the Church was favouring them so as to gain

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: authority in temporal power: in many others their citizens became

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: princes. From this it came to pass that Italy fell partly into the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: hands of the Church and of republics, and, the Church consisting of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: priests and the republic of citizens unaccustomed to arms, both

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: commenced to enlist foreigners.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: The first who gave renown to this soldiery was Alberigo da Conio,[8]

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the Romagnian. From the school of this man sprang, among others,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Braccio and Sforza, who in their time were the arbiters of Italy. After

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: these came all the other captains who till now have directed the arms

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of Italy; and the end of all their valour has been, that she has been

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: overrun by Charles, robbed by Louis, ravaged by Ferdinand, and insulted

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: by the Switzers. The principle that has guided them has been, first, to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: lower the credit of infantry so that they might increase their own.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: They did this because, subsisting on their pay and without territory,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: they were unable to support many soldiers, and a few infantry did not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: give them any authority; so they were led to employ cavalry, with a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: moderate force of which they were maintained and honoured; and affairs

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: were brought to such a pass that, in an army of twenty thousand

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: soldiers, there were not to be found two thousand foot soldiers. They

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: had, besides this, used every art to lessen fatigue and danger to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: themselves and their soldiers, not killing in the fray, but taking

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prisoners and liberating without ransom. They did not attack towns at

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: night, nor did the garrisons of the towns attack encampments at night;

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: they did not surround the camp either with stockade or ditch, nor did

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: they campaign in the winter. All these things were permitted by their

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: military rules, and devised by them to avoid, as I have said, both

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: fatigue and dangers; thus they have brought Italy to slavery and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: contempt.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [8] Alberigo da Conio. Alberico da Barbiano, Count of Cunio in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Romagna. He was the leader of the famous “Company of St George,”

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: composed entirely of Italian soldiers. He died in 1409.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CHAPTER XIII.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CONCERNING AUXILIARIES, MIXED SOLDIERY, AND ONE’S OWN

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Auxiliaries, which are the other useless arm, are employed when a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prince is called in with his forces to aid and defend, as was done by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Pope Julius in the most recent times; for he, having, in the enterprise

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: against Ferrara, had poor proof of his mercenaries, turned to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: auxiliaries, and stipulated with Ferdinand, King of Spain,[1] for his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: assistance with men and arms. These arms may be useful and good in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: themselves, but for him who calls them in they are always

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: disadvantageous; for losing, one is undone, and winning, one is their

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: captive.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [1] Ferdinand V (F. II of Aragon and Sicily, F. III of Naples),

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: surnamed “The Catholic,” born 1452, died 1516.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: And although ancient histories may be full of examples, I do not wish

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to leave this recent one of Pope Julius the Second, the peril of which

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: cannot fail to be perceived; for he, wishing to get Ferrara, threw

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: himself entirely into the hands of the foreigner. But his good fortune

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: brought about a third event, so that he did not reap the fruit of his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: rash choice; because, having his auxiliaries routed at Ravenna, and the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Switzers having risen and driven out the conquerors (against all

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: expectation, both his and others), it so came to pass that he did not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: become prisoner to his enemies, they having fled, nor to his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: auxiliaries, he having conquered by other arms than theirs.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: The Florentines, being entirely without arms, sent ten thousand

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Frenchmen to take Pisa, whereby they ran more danger than at any other

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: time of their troubles.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: The Emperor of Constantinople,[2] to oppose his neighbours, sent ten

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: thousand Turks into Greece, who, on the war being finished, were not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: willing to quit; this was the beginning of the servitude of Greece to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the infidels.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [2] Joannes Cantacuzenus, born 1300, died 1383.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Therefore, let him who has no desire to conquer make use of these arms,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: for they are much more hazardous than mercenaries, because with them

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the ruin is ready made; they are all united, all yield obedience to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: others; but with mercenaries, when they have conquered, more time and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: better opportunities are needed to injure you; they are not all of one

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: community, they are found and paid by you, and a third party, which you

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: have made their head, is not able all at once to assume enough

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: authority to injure you. In conclusion, in mercenaries dastardy is most

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: dangerous; in auxiliaries, valour. The wise prince, therefore, has

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: always avoided these arms and turned to his own; and has been willing

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: rather to lose with them than to conquer with the others, not deeming

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that a real victory which is gained with the arms of others.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: I shall never hesitate to cite Cesare Borgia and his actions. This duke

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: entered the Romagna with auxiliaries, taking there only French

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: soldiers, and with them he captured Imola and Forli; but afterwards,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: such forces not appearing to him reliable, he turned to mercenaries,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: discerning less danger in them, and enlisted the Orsini and Vitelli;

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: whom presently, on handling and finding them doubtful, unfaithful, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: dangerous, he destroyed and turned to his own men. And the difference

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: between one and the other of these forces can easily be seen when one

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: considers the difference there was in the reputation of the duke, when

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: he had the French, when he had the Orsini and Vitelli, and when he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: relied on his own soldiers, on whose fidelity he could always count and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: found it ever increasing; he was never esteemed more highly than when

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: every one saw that he was complete master of his own forces.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: I was not intending to go beyond Italian and recent examples, but I am

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: unwilling to leave out Hiero, the Syracusan, he being one of those I

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: have named above. This man, as I have said, made head of the army by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the Syracusans, soon found out that a mercenary soldiery, constituted

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: like our Italian condottieri, was of no use; and it appearing to him

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that he could neither keep them nor let them go, he had them all cut to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: pieces, and afterwards made war with his own forces and not with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: aliens.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: I wish also to recall to memory an instance from the Old Testament

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: applicable to this subject. David offered himself to Saul to fight with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Goliath, the Philistine champion, and, to give him courage, Saul armed

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: him with his own weapons; which David rejected as soon as he had them

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: on his back, saying he could make no use of them, and that he wished to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: meet the enemy with his sling and his knife. In conclusion, the arms of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: others either fall from your back, or they weigh you down, or they bind

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: you fast.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Charles the Seventh,[3] the father of King Louis the Eleventh,[4]

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: having by good fortune and valour liberated France from the English,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: recognized the necessity of being armed with forces of his own, and he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: established in his kingdom ordinances concerning men-at-arms and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: infantry. Afterwards his son, King Louis, abolished the infantry and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: began to enlist the Switzers, which mistake, followed by others, is, as

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: is now seen, a source of peril to that kingdom; because, having raised

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the reputation of the Switzers, he has entirely diminished the value of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: his own arms, for he has destroyed the infantry altogether; and his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: men-at-arms he has subordinated to others, for, being as they are so

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: accustomed to fight along with Switzers, it does not appear that they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: can now conquer without them. Hence it arises that the French cannot

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: stand against the Switzers, and without the Switzers they do not come

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: off well against others. The armies of the French have thus become

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: mixed, partly mercenary and partly national, both of which arms

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: together are much better than mercenaries alone or auxiliaries alone,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: but much inferior to one’s own forces. And this example proves it, for

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the kingdom of France would be unconquerable if the ordinance of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Charles had been enlarged or maintained.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [3] Charles VII of France, surnamed “The Victorious,” born 1403, died

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [4] Louis XI, son of the above, born 1423, died 1483.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: But the scanty wisdom of man, on entering into an affair which looks

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: well at first, cannot discern the poison that is hidden in it, as I

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: have said above of hectic fevers. Therefore, if he who rules a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: principality cannot recognize evils until they are upon him, he is not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: truly wise; and this insight is given to few. And if the first disaster

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to the Roman Empire[5] should be examined, it will be found to have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: commenced only with the enlisting of the Goths; because from that time

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the vigour of the Roman Empire began to decline, and all that valour

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: which had raised it passed away to others.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [5] “Many speakers to the House the other night in the debate on the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: reduction of armaments seemed to show a most lamentable ignorance of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the conditions under which the British Empire maintains its existence.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: When Mr Balfour replied to the allegations that the Roman Empire sank

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: under the weight of its military obligations, he said that this was

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ‘wholly unhistorical.’ He might well have added that the Roman power

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: was at its zenith when every citizen acknowledged his liability to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: fight for the State, but that it began to decline as soon as this

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: obligation was no longer recognised.”—Pall Mall Gazette, 15th May

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: I conclude, therefore, that no principality is secure without having

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: its own forces; on the contrary, it is entirely dependent on good

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: fortune, not having the valour which in adversity would defend it. And

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: it has always been the opinion and judgment of wise men that nothing

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: can be so uncertain or unstable as fame or power not founded on its own

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: strength. And one’s own forces are those which are composed either of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: subjects, citizens, or dependents; all others are mercenaries or

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: auxiliaries. And the way to make ready one’s own forces will be easily

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: found if the rules suggested by me shall be reflected upon, and if one

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: will consider how Philip, the father of Alexander the Great, and many

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: republics and princes have armed and organized themselves, to which

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: rules I entirely commit myself.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CHAPTER XIV.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: THAT WHICH CONCERNS A PRINCE ON THE SUBJECT OF THE ART OF WAR

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: A prince ought to have no other aim or thought, nor select anything

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: else for his study, than war and its rules and discipline; for this is

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the sole art that belongs to him who rules, and it is of such force

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that it not only upholds those who are born princes, but it often

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: enables men to rise from a private station to that rank. And, on the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: contrary, it is seen that when princes have thought more of ease than

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of arms they have lost their states. And the first cause of your losing

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: it is to neglect this art; and what enables you to acquire a state is

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to be master of the art. Francesco Sforza, through being martial, from

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: a private person became Duke of Milan; and the sons, through avoiding

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the hardships and troubles of arms, from dukes became private persons.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: For among other evils which being unarmed brings you, it causes you to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: be despised, and this is one of those ignominies against which a prince

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ought to guard himself, as is shown later on. Because there is nothing

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: proportionate between the armed and the unarmed; and it is not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: reasonable that he who is armed should yield obedience willingly to him

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: who is unarmed, or that the unarmed man should be secure among armed

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: servants. Because, there being in the one disdain and in the other

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: suspicion, it is not possible for them to work well together. And

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: therefore a prince who does not understand the art of war, over and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: above the other misfortunes already mentioned, cannot be respected by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: his soldiers, nor can he rely on them. He ought never, therefore, to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: have out of his thoughts this subject of war, and in peace he should

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: addict himself more to its exercise than in war; this he can do in two

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ways, the one by action, the other by study.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: As regards action, he ought above all things to keep his men well

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: organized and drilled, to follow incessantly the chase, by which he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: accustoms his body to hardships, and learns something of the nature of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: localities, and gets to find out how the mountains rise, how the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: valleys open out, how the plains lie, and to understand the nature of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: rivers and marshes, and in all this to take the greatest care. Which

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: knowledge is useful in two ways. Firstly, he learns to know his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: country, and is better able to undertake its defence; afterwards, by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: means of the knowledge and observation of that locality, he understands

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: with ease any other which it may be necessary for him to study

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: hereafter; because the hills, valleys, and plains, and rivers and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: marshes that are, for instance, in Tuscany, have a certain resemblance

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to those of other countries, so that with a knowledge of the aspect of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: one country one can easily arrive at a knowledge of others. And the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prince that lacks this skill lacks the essential which it is desirable

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that a captain should possess, for it teaches him to surprise his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: enemy, to select quarters, to lead armies, to array the battle, to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: besiege towns to advantage.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Philopoemen,[1] Prince of the Achaeans, among other praises which

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: writers have bestowed on him, is commended because in time of peace he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: never had anything in his mind but the rules of war; and when he was in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the country with friends, he often stopped and reasoned with them: “If

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the enemy should be upon that hill, and we should find ourselves here

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: with our army, with whom would be the advantage? How should one best

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: advance to meet him, keeping the ranks? If we should wish to retreat,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: how ought we to pursue?” And he would set forth to them, as he went,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: all the chances that could befall an army; he would listen to their

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: opinion and state his, confirming it with reasons, so that by these

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: continual discussions there could never arise, in time of war, any

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: unexpected circumstances that he could not deal with.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [1] Philopoemen, “the last of the Greeks,” born 252 B.C., died 183

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: B.C.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: But to exercise the intellect the prince should read histories, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: study there the actions of illustrious men, to see how they have borne

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: themselves in war, to examine the causes of their victories and defeat,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: so as to avoid the latter and imitate the former; and above all do as

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: an illustrious man did, who took as an exemplar one who had been

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: praised and famous before him, and whose achievements and deeds he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: always kept in his mind, as it is said Alexander the Great imitated

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Achilles, Caesar Alexander, Scipio Cyrus. And whoever reads the life of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Cyrus, written by Xenophon, will recognize afterwards in the life of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Scipio how that imitation was his glory, and how in chastity,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: affability, humanity, and liberality Scipio conformed to those things

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: which have been written of Cyrus by Xenophon. A wise prince ought to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: observe some such rules, and never in peaceful times stand idle, but

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: increase his resources with industry in such a way that they may be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: available to him in adversity, so that if fortune chances it may find

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: him prepared to resist her blows.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CHAPTER XV.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CONCERNING THINGS FOR WHICH MEN, AND ESPECIALLY PRINCES, ARE PRAISED OR

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: BLAMED

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: It remains now to see what ought to be the rules of conduct for a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prince towards subject and friends. And as I know that many have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: written on this point, I expect I shall be considered presumptuous in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: mentioning it again, especially as in discussing it I shall depart from

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the methods of other people. But, it being my intention to write a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: thing which shall be useful to him who apprehends it, it appears to me

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: more appropriate to follow up the real truth of the matter than the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: imagination of it; for many have pictured republics and principalities

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: which in fact have never been known or seen, because how one lives is

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: so far distant from how one ought to live, that he who neglects what is

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: done for what ought to be done, sooner effects his ruin than his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: preservation; for a man who wishes to act entirely up to his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: professions of virtue soon meets with what destroys him among so much

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that is evil.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Hence it is necessary for a prince wishing to hold his own to know how

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to do wrong, and to make use of it or not according to necessity.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Therefore, putting on one side imaginary things concerning a prince,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and discussing those which are real, I say that all men when they are

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: spoken of, and chiefly princes for being more highly placed, are

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: remarkable for some of those qualities which bring them either blame or

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: praise; and thus it is that one is reputed liberal, another miserly,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: using a Tuscan term (because an avaricious person in our language is

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: still he who desires to possess by robbery, whilst we call one miserly

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: who deprives himself too much of the use of his own); one is reputed

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: generous, one rapacious; one cruel, one compassionate; one faithless,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: another faithful; one effeminate and cowardly, another bold and brave;

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: one affable, another haughty; one lascivious, another chaste; one

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: sincere, another cunning; one hard, another easy; one grave, another

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: frivolous; one religious, another unbelieving, and the like. And I know

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that every one will confess that it would be most praiseworthy in a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prince to exhibit all the above qualities that are considered good; but

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: because they can neither be entirely possessed nor observed, for human

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: conditions do not permit it, it is necessary for him to be sufficiently

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prudent that he may know how to avoid the reproach of those vices which

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: would lose him his state; and also to keep himself, if it be possible,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: from those which would not lose him it; but this not being possible, he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: may with less hesitation abandon himself to them. And again, he need

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: not make himself uneasy at incurring a reproach for those vices without

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: which the state can only be saved with difficulty, for if everything is

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: considered carefully, it will be found that something which looks like

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: virtue, if followed, would be his ruin; whilst something else, which

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: looks like vice, yet followed brings him security and prosperity.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CHAPTER XVI.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CONCERNING LIBERALITY AND MEANNESS

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Commencing then with the first of the above-named characteristics, I

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: say that it would be well to be reputed liberal. Nevertheless,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: liberality exercised in a way that does not bring you the reputation

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: for it, injures you; for if one exercises it honestly and as it should

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: be exercised, it may not become known, and you will not avoid the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: reproach of its opposite. Therefore, any one wishing to maintain among

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: men the name of liberal is obliged to avoid no attribute of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: magnificence; so that a prince thus inclined will consume in such acts

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: all his property, and will be compelled in the end, if he wish to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: maintain the name of liberal, to unduly weigh down his people, and tax

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: them, and do everything he can to get money. This will soon make him

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: odious to his subjects, and becoming poor he will be little valued by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: any one; thus, with his liberality, having offended many and rewarded

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: few, he is affected by the very first trouble and imperilled by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: whatever may be the first danger; recognizing this himself, and wishing

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to draw back from it, he runs at once into the reproach of being

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: miserly.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Therefore, a prince, not being able to exercise this virtue of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: liberality in such a way that it is recognized, except to his cost, if

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: he is wise he ought not to fear the reputation of being mean, for in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: time he will come to be more considered than if liberal, seeing that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: with his economy his revenues are enough, that he can defend himself

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: against all attacks, and is able to engage in enterprises without

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: burdening his people; thus it comes to pass that he exercises

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: liberality towards all from whom he does not take, who are numberless,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and meanness towards those to whom he does not give, who are few.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: We have not seen great things done in our time except by those who have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: been considered mean; the rest have failed. Pope Julius the Second was

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: assisted in reaching the papacy by a reputation for liberality, yet he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: did not strive afterwards to keep it up, when he made war on the King

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of France; and he made many wars without imposing any extraordinary tax

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: on his subjects, for he supplied his additional expenses out of his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: long thriftiness. The present King of Spain would not have undertaken

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: or conquered in so many enterprises if he had been reputed liberal. A

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prince, therefore, provided that he has not to rob his subjects, that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: he can defend himself, that he does not become poor and abject, that he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: is not forced to become rapacious, ought to hold of little account a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: reputation for being mean, for it is one of those vices which will

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: enable him to govern.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: And if any one should say: Caesar obtained empire by liberality, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: many others have reached the highest positions by having been liberal,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and by being considered so, I answer: Either you are a prince in fact,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: or in a way to become one. In the first case this liberality is

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: dangerous, in the second it is very necessary to be considered liberal;

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and Caesar was one of those who wished to become pre-eminent in Rome;

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: but if he had survived after becoming so, and had not moderated his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: expenses, he would have destroyed his government. And if any one should

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: reply: Many have been princes, and have done great things with armies,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: who have been considered very liberal, I reply: Either a prince spends

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that which is his own or his subjects’ or else that of others. In the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: first case he ought to be sparing, in the second he ought not to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: neglect any opportunity for liberality. And to the prince who goes

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: forth with his army, supporting it by pillage, sack, and extortion,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: handling that which belongs to others, this liberality is necessary,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: otherwise he would not be followed by soldiers. And of that which is

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: neither yours nor your subjects’ you can be a ready giver, as were

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Cyrus, Caesar, and Alexander; because it does not take away your

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: reputation if you squander that of others, but adds to it; it is only

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: squandering your own that injures you.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: And there is nothing wastes so rapidly as liberality, for even whilst

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: you exercise it you lose the power to do so, and so become either poor

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: or despised, or else, in avoiding poverty, rapacious and hated. And a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prince should guard himself, above all things, against being despised

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and hated; and liberality leads you to both. Therefore it is wiser to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: have a reputation for meanness which brings reproach without hatred,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: than to be compelled through seeking a reputation for liberality to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: incur a name for rapacity which begets reproach with hatred.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CHAPTER XVII.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CONCERNING CRUELTY AND CLEMENCY, AND WHETHER IT IS BETTER TO BE LOVED

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: THAN FEARED

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Coming now to the other qualities mentioned above, I say that every

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prince ought to desire to be considered clement and not cruel.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Nevertheless he ought to take care not to misuse this clemency. Cesare

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Borgia was considered cruel; notwithstanding, his cruelty reconciled

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the Romagna, unified it, and restored it to peace and loyalty. And if

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: this be rightly considered, he will be seen to have been much more

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: merciful than the Florentine people, who, to avoid a reputation for

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: cruelty, permitted Pistoia to be destroyed.[1] Therefore a prince, so

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: long as he keeps his subjects united and loyal, ought not to mind the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: reproach of cruelty; because with a few examples he will be more

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: merciful than those who, through too much mercy, allow disorders to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: arise, from which follow murders or robberies; for these are wont to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: injure the whole people, whilst those executions which originate with a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prince offend the individual only.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [1] During the rioting between the Cancellieri and Panciatichi

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: factions in 1502 and 1503.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: And of all princes, it is impossible for the new prince to avoid the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: imputation of cruelty, owing to new states being full of dangers. Hence

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Virgil, through the mouth of Dido, excuses the inhumanity of her reign

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: owing to its being new, saying:

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: “Res dura, et regni novitas me talia cogunt

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Moliri, et late fines custode tueri.”[2]

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Nevertheless he ought to be slow to believe and to act, nor should he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: himself show fear, but proceed in a temperate manner with prudence and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: humanity, so that too much confidence may not make him incautious and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: too much distrust render him intolerable.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [2] . . . against my will, my fate

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: A throne unsettled, and an infant state,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Bid me defend my realms with all my pow’rs,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: And guard with these severities my shores.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Christopher Pitt.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Upon this a question arises: whether it be better to be loved than

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: feared or feared than loved? It may be answered that one should wish to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: be both, but, because it is difficult to unite them in one person, it

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: is much safer to be feared than loved, when, of the two, either must be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: dispensed with. Because this is to be asserted in general of men, that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: they are ungrateful, fickle, false, cowardly, covetous, and as long as

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: you succeed they are yours entirely; they will offer you their blood,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: property, life, and children, as is said above, when the need is far

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: distant; but when it approaches they turn against you. And that prince

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: who, relying entirely on their promises, has neglected other

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: precautions, is ruined; because friendships that are obtained by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: payments, and not by greatness or nobility of mind, may indeed be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: earned, but they are not secured, and in time of need cannot be relied

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: upon; and men have less scruple in offending one who is beloved than

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: one who is feared, for love is preserved by the link of obligation

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: which, owing to the baseness of men, is broken at every opportunity for

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: their advantage; but fear preserves you by a dread of punishment which

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: never fails.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Nevertheless a prince ought to inspire fear in such a way that, if he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: does not win love, he avoids hatred; because he can endure very well

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: being feared whilst he is not hated, which will always be as long as he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: abstains from the property of his citizens and subjects and from their

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: women. But when it is necessary for him to proceed against the life of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: someone, he must do it on proper justification and for manifest cause,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: but above all things he must keep his hands off the property of others,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: because men more quickly forget the death of their father than the loss

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of their patrimony. Besides, pretexts for taking away the property are

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: never wanting; for he who has once begun to live by robbery will always

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: find pretexts for seizing what belongs to others; but reasons for

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: taking life, on the contrary, are more difficult to find and sooner

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: lapse. But when a prince is with his army, and has under control a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: multitude of soldiers, then it is quite necessary for him to disregard

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the reputation of cruelty, for without it he would never hold his army

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: united or disposed to its duties.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Among the wonderful deeds of Hannibal this one is enumerated: that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: having led an enormous army, composed of many various races of men, to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: fight in foreign lands, no dissensions arose either among them or

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: against the prince, whether in his bad or in his good fortune. This

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: arose from nothing else than his inhuman cruelty, which, with his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: boundless valour, made him revered and terrible in the sight of his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: soldiers, but without that cruelty, his other virtues were not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: sufficient to produce this effect. And short-sighted writers admire his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: deeds from one point of view and from another condemn the principal

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: cause of them. That it is true his other virtues would not have been

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: sufficient for him may be proved by the case of Scipio, that most

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: excellent man, not only of his own times but within the memory of man,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: against whom, nevertheless, his army rebelled in Spain; this arose from

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: nothing but his too great forbearance, which gave his soldiers more

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: license than is consistent with military discipline. For this he was

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: upbraided in the Senate by Fabius Maximus, and called the corrupter of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the Roman soldiery. The Locrians were laid waste by a legate of Scipio,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: yet they were not avenged by him, nor was the insolence of the legate

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: punished, owing entirely to his easy nature. Insomuch that someone in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the Senate, wishing to excuse him, said there were many men who knew

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: much better how not to err than to correct the errors of others. This

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: disposition, if he had been continued in the command, would have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: destroyed in time the fame and glory of Scipio; but, he being under the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: control of the Senate, this injurious characteristic not only concealed

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: itself, but contributed to his glory.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Returning to the question of being feared or loved, I come to the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: conclusion that, men loving according to their own will and fearing

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: according to that of the prince, a wise prince should establish himself

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: on that which is in his own control and not in that of others; he must

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: endeavour only to avoid hatred, as is noted.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CHAPTER XVIII.[1]

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CONCERNING THE WAY IN WHICH PRINCES SHOULD KEEP FAITH

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [1] “The present chapter has given greater offence than any other

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: portion of Machiavelli’s writings.” Burd, “Il Principe,” p. 297.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Every one admits how praiseworthy it is in a prince to keep faith, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to live with integrity and not with craft. Nevertheless our experience

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: has been that those princes who have done great things have held good

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: faith of little account, and have known how to circumvent the intellect

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of men by craft, and in the end have overcome those who have relied on

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: their word. You must know there are two ways of contesting,[2] the one

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: by the law, the other by force; the first method is proper to men, the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: second to beasts; but because the first is frequently not sufficient,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: it is necessary to have recourse to the second. Therefore it is

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: necessary for a prince to understand how to avail himself of the beast

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and the man. This has been figuratively taught to princes by ancient

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: writers, who describe how Achilles and many other princes of old were

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: given to the Centaur Chiron to nurse, who brought them up in his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: discipline; which means solely that, as they had for a teacher one who

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: was half beast and half man, so it is necessary for a prince to know

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: how to make use of both natures, and that one without the other is not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: durable. A prince, therefore, being compelled knowingly to adopt the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: beast, ought to choose the fox and the lion; because the lion cannot

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: defend himself against snares and the fox cannot defend himself against

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: wolves. Therefore, it is necessary to be a fox to discover the snares

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and a lion to terrify the wolves. Those who rely simply on the lion do

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: not understand what they are about. Therefore a wise lord cannot, nor

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ought he to, keep faith when such observance may be turned against him,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and when the reasons that caused him to pledge it exist no longer. If

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: men were entirely good this precept would not hold, but because they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: are bad, and will not keep faith with you, you too are not bound to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: observe it with them. Nor will there ever be wanting to a prince

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: legitimate reasons to excuse this non-observance. Of this endless

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: modern examples could be given, showing how many treaties and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: engagements have been made void and of no effect through the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: faithlessness of princes; and he who has known best how to employ the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: fox has succeeded best.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [2] “Contesting,” i.e. “striving for mastery.” Mr Burd points out

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that this passage is imitated directly from Cicero’s “De Officiis”:

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: “Nam cum sint duo genera decertandi, unum per disceptationem, alterum

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: per vim; cumque illud proprium sit hominis, hoc beluarum; confugiendum

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: est ad posterius, si uti non licet superiore.”

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: But it is necessary to know well how to disguise this characteristic,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and to be a great pretender and dissembler; and men are so simple, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: so subject to present necessities, that he who seeks to deceive will

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: always find someone who will allow himself to be deceived. One recent

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: example I cannot pass over in silence. Alexander the Sixth did nothing

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: else but deceive men, nor ever thought of doing otherwise, and he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: always found victims; for there never was a man who had greater power

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: in asserting, or who with greater oaths would affirm a thing, yet would

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: observe it less; nevertheless his deceits always succeeded according to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: his wishes,[3] because he well understood this side of mankind.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [3] “Nondimanco sempre gli succederono gli inganni (ad votum).” The

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: words “ad votum” are omitted in the Testina addition, 1550.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Alexander never did what he said,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Cesare never said what he did.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Italian Proverb.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Therefore it is unnecessary for a prince to have all the good qualities

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: I have enumerated, but it is very necessary to appear to have them. And

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: I shall dare to say this also, that to have them and always to observe

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: them is injurious, and that to appear to have them is useful; to appear

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: merciful, faithful, humane, religious, upright, and to be so, but with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: a mind so framed that should you require not to be so, you may be able

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and know how to change to the opposite.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: And you have to understand this, that a prince, especially a new one,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: cannot observe all those things for which men are esteemed, being often

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: forced, in order to maintain the state, to act contrary to fidelity,[4]

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: friendship, humanity, and religion. Therefore it is necessary for him

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to have a mind ready to turn itself accordingly as the winds and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: variations of fortune force it, yet, as I have said above, not to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: diverge from the good if he can avoid doing so, but, if compelled, then

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to know how to set about it.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [4] “Contrary to fidelity” or “faith,” “contro alla fede,” and “tutto

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: fede,” “altogether faithful,” in the next paragraph. It is noteworthy

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that these two phrases, “contro alla fede” and “tutto fede,” were

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: omitted in the Testina edition, which was published with the sanction

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of the papal authorities. It may be that the meaning attached to the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: word “fede” was “the faith,” i.e. the Catholic creed, and not as

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: rendered here “fidelity” and “faithful.” Observe that the word

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: “religione” was suffered to stand in the text of the Testina, being

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: used to signify indifferently every shade of belief, as witness “the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: religion,” a phrase inevitably employed to designate the Huguenot

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: heresy. South in his Sermon IX, p. 69, ed. 1843, comments on this

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: passage as follows: “That great patron and Coryphaeus of this tribe,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Nicolo Machiavel, laid down this for a master rule in his political

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: scheme: ‘That the show of religion was helpful to the politician, but

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the reality of it hurtful and pernicious.’”

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: For this reason a prince ought to take care that he never lets anything

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: slip from his lips that is not replete with the above-named five

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: qualities, that he may appear to him who sees and hears him altogether

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: merciful, faithful, humane, upright, and religious. There is nothing

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: more necessary to appear to have than this last quality, inasmuch as

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: men judge generally more by the eye than by the hand, because it

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: belongs to everybody to see you, to few to come in touch with you.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Every one sees what you appear to be, few really know what you are, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: those few dare not oppose themselves to the opinion of the many, who

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: have the majesty of the state to defend them; and in the actions of all

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: men, and especially of princes, which it is not prudent to challenge,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: one judges by the result.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: For that reason, let a prince have the credit of conquering and holding

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: his state, the means will always be considered honest, and he will be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: praised by everybody; because the vulgar are always taken by what a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: thing seems to be and by what comes of it; and in the world there are

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: only the vulgar, for the few find a place there only when the many have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: no ground to rest on.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: One prince[5] of the present time, whom it is not well to name, never

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: preaches anything else but peace and good faith, and to both he is most

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: hostile, and either, if he had kept it, would have deprived him of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: reputation and kingdom many a time.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [5] Ferdinand of Aragon. “When Machiavelli was writing The Prince it

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: would have been clearly impossible to mention Ferdinand’s name here

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: without giving offence.” Burd’s “Il Principe,” p. 308.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CHAPTER XIX.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: THAT ONE SHOULD AVOID BEING DESPISED AND HATED

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Now, concerning the characteristics of which mention is made above, I

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: have spoken of the more important ones, the others I wish to discuss

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: briefly under this generality, that the prince must consider, as has

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: been in part said before, how to avoid those things which will make him

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: hated or contemptible; and as often as he shall have succeeded he will

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: have fulfilled his part, and he need not fear any danger in other

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: reproaches.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: It makes him hated above all things, as I have said, to be rapacious,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and to be a violator of the property and women of his subjects, from

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: both of which he must abstain. And when neither their property nor

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: their honor is touched, the majority of men live content, and he has

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: only to contend with the ambition of a few, whom he can curb with ease

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: in many ways.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: It makes him contemptible to be considered fickle, frivolous,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: effeminate, mean-spirited, irresolute, from all of which a prince

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: should guard himself as from a rock; and he should endeavour to show in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: his actions greatness, courage, gravity, and fortitude; and in his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: private dealings with his subjects let him show that his judgments are

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: irrevocable, and maintain himself in such reputation that no one can

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: hope either to deceive him or to get round him.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: That prince is highly esteemed who conveys this impression of himself,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and he who is highly esteemed is not easily conspired against; for,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: provided it is well known that he is an excellent man and revered by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: his people, he can only be attacked with difficulty. For this reason a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prince ought to have two fears, one from within, on account of his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: subjects, the other from without, on account of external powers. From

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the latter he is defended by being well armed and having good allies,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and if he is well armed he will have good friends, and affairs will

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: always remain quiet within when they are quiet without, unless they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: should have been already disturbed by conspiracy; and even should

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: affairs outside be disturbed, if he has carried out his preparations

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and has lived as I have said, as long as he does not despair, he will

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: resist every attack, as I said Nabis the Spartan did.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: But concerning his subjects, when affairs outside are disturbed he has

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: only to fear that they will conspire secretly, from which a prince can

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: easily secure himself by avoiding being hated and despised, and by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: keeping the people satisfied with him, which it is most necessary for

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: him to accomplish, as I said above at length. And one of the most

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: efficacious remedies that a prince can have against conspiracies is not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to be hated and despised by the people, for he who conspires against a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prince always expects to please them by his removal; but when the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: conspirator can only look forward to offending them, he will not have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the courage to take such a course, for the difficulties that confront a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: conspirator are infinite. And as experience shows, many have been the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: conspiracies, but few have been successful; because he who conspires

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: cannot act alone, nor can he take a companion except from those whom he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: believes to be malcontents, and as soon as you have opened your mind to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: a malcontent you have given him the material with which to content

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: himself, for by denouncing you he can look for every advantage; so

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that, seeing the gain from this course to be assured, and seeing the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: other to be doubtful and full of dangers, he must be a very rare

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: friend, or a thoroughly obstinate enemy of the prince, to keep faith

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: with you.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: And, to reduce the matter into a small compass, I say that, on the side

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of the conspirator, there is nothing but fear, jealousy, prospect of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: punishment to terrify him; but on the side of the prince there is the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: majesty of the principality, the laws, the protection of friends and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the state to defend him; so that, adding to all these things the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: popular goodwill, it is impossible that any one should be so rash as to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: conspire. For whereas in general the conspirator has to fear before the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: execution of his plot, in this case he has also to fear the sequel to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the crime; because on account of it he has the people for an enemy, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: thus cannot hope for any escape.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Endless examples could be given on this subject, but I will be content

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: with one, brought to pass within the memory of our fathers. Messer

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Annibale Bentivogli, who was prince in Bologna (grandfather of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: present Annibale), having been murdered by the Canneschi, who had

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: conspired against him, not one of his family survived but Messer

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Giovanni,[1] who was in childhood: immediately after his assassination

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the people rose and murdered all the Canneschi. This sprung from the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: popular goodwill which the house of Bentivogli enjoyed in those days in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Bologna; which was so great that, although none remained there after

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the death of Annibale who was able to rule the state, the Bolognese,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: having information that there was one of the Bentivogli family in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Florence, who up to that time had been considered the son of a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: blacksmith, sent to Florence for him and gave him the government of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: their city, and it was ruled by him until Messer Giovanni came in due

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: course to the government.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [1] Giovanni Bentivogli, born in Bologna 1438, died at Milan 1508. He

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ruled Bologna from 1462 to 1506. Machiavelli’s strong condemnation of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: conspiracies may get its edge from his own very recent experience

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: (February 1513), when he had been arrested and tortured for his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: alleged complicity in the Boscoli conspiracy.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: For this reason I consider that a prince ought to reckon conspiracies

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of little account when his people hold him in esteem; but when it is

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: hostile to him, and bears hatred towards him, he ought to fear

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: everything and everybody. And well-ordered states and wise princes have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: taken every care not to drive the nobles to desperation, and to keep

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the people satisfied and contented, for this is one of the most

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: important objects a prince can have.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Among the best ordered and governed kingdoms of our times is France,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and in it are found many good institutions on which depend the liberty

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and security of the king; of these the first is the parliament and its

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: authority, because he who founded the kingdom, knowing the ambition of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the nobility and their boldness, considered that a bit to their mouths

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: would be necessary to hold them in; and, on the other side, knowing the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: hatred of the people, founded in fear, against the nobles, he wished to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: protect them, yet he was not anxious for this to be the particular care

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of the king; therefore, to take away the reproach which he would be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: liable to from the nobles for favouring the people, and from the people

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: for favouring the nobles, he set up an arbiter, who should be one who

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: could beat down the great and favour the lesser without reproach to the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: king. Neither could you have a better or a more prudent arrangement, or

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: a greater source of security to the king and kingdom. From this one can

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: draw another important conclusion, that princes ought to leave affairs

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of reproach to the management of others, and keep those of grace in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: their own hands. And further, I consider that a prince ought to cherish

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the nobles, but not so as to make himself hated by the people.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: It may appear, perhaps, to some who have examined the lives and deaths

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of the Roman emperors that many of them would be an example contrary to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: my opinion, seeing that some of them lived nobly and showed great

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: qualities of soul, nevertheless they have lost their empire or have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: been killed by subjects who have conspired against them. Wishing,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: therefore, to answer these objections, I will recall the characters of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: some of the emperors, and will show that the causes of their ruin were

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: not different to those alleged by me; at the same time I will only

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: submit for consideration those things that are noteworthy to him who

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: studies the affairs of those times.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: It seems to me sufficient to take all those emperors who succeeded to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the empire from Marcus the philosopher down to Maximinus; they were

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Marcus and his son Commodus, Pertinax, Julian, Severus and his son

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Antoninus Caracalla, Macrinus, Heliogabalus, Alexander, and Maximinus.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: There is first to note that, whereas in other principalities the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ambition of the nobles and the insolence of the people only have to be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: contended with, the Roman emperors had a third difficulty in having to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: put up with the cruelty and avarice of their soldiers, a matter so

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: beset with difficulties that it was the ruin of many; for it was a hard

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: thing to give satisfaction both to soldiers and people; because the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: people loved peace, and for this reason they loved the unaspiring

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prince, whilst the soldiers loved the warlike prince who was bold,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: cruel, and rapacious, which qualities they were quite willing he should

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: exercise upon the people, so that they could get double pay and give

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: vent to their own greed and cruelty. Hence it arose that those emperors

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: were always overthrown who, either by birth or training, had no great

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: authority, and most of them, especially those who came new to the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: principality, recognizing the difficulty of these two opposing humours,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: were inclined to give satisfaction to the soldiers, caring little about

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: injuring the people. Which course was necessary, because, as princes

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: cannot help being hated by someone, they ought, in the first place, to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: avoid being hated by every one, and when they cannot compass this, they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ought to endeavour with the utmost diligence to avoid the hatred of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: most powerful. Therefore, those emperors who through inexperience had

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: need of special favour adhered more readily to the soldiers than to the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: people; a course which turned out advantageous to them or not,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: accordingly as the prince knew how to maintain authority over them.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: From these causes it arose that Marcus, Pertinax, and Alexander, being

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: all men of modest life, lovers of justice, enemies to cruelty, humane,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and benignant, came to a sad end except Marcus; he alone lived and died

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: honoured, because he had succeeded to the throne by hereditary title,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and owed nothing either to the soldiers or the people; and afterwards,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: being possessed of many virtues which made him respected, he always

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: kept both orders in their places whilst he lived, and was neither hated

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: nor despised.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: But Pertinax was created emperor against the wishes of the soldiers,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: who, being accustomed to live licentiously under Commodus, could not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: endure the honest life to which Pertinax wished to reduce them; thus,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: having given cause for hatred, to which hatred there was added contempt

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: for his old age, he was overthrown at the very beginning of his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: administration. And here it should be noted that hatred is acquired as

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: much by good works as by bad ones, therefore, as I said before, a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prince wishing to keep his state is very often forced to do evil; for

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: when that body is corrupt whom you think you have need of to maintain

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: yourself—it may be either the people or the soldiers or the nobles—you

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: have to submit to its humours and to gratify them, and then good works

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: will do you harm.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: But let us come to Alexander, who was a man of such great goodness,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that among the other praises which are accorded him is this, that in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the fourteen years he held the empire no one was ever put to death by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: him unjudged; nevertheless, being considered effeminate and a man who

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: allowed himself to be governed by his mother, he became despised, the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: army conspired against him, and murdered him.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Turning now to the opposite characters of Commodus, Severus, Antoninus

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Caracalla, and Maximinus, you will find them all cruel and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: rapacious-men who, to satisfy their soldiers, did not hesitate to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: commit every kind of iniquity against the people; and all, except

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Severus, came to a bad end; but in Severus there was so much valour

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that, keeping the soldiers friendly, although the people were oppressed

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: by him, he reigned successfully; for his valour made him so much

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: admired in the sight of the soldiers and people that the latter were

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: kept in a way astonished and awed and the former respectful and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: satisfied. And because the actions of this man, as a new prince, were

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: great, I wish to show briefly that he knew well how to counterfeit the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: fox and the lion, which natures, as I said above, it is necessary for a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prince to imitate.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Knowing the sloth of the Emperor Julian, he persuaded the army in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Sclavonia, of which he was captain, that it would be right to go to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Rome and avenge the death of Pertinax, who had been killed by the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: praetorian soldiers; and under this pretext, without appearing to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: aspire to the throne, he moved the army on Rome, and reached Italy

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: before it was known that he had started. On his arrival at Rome, the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Senate, through fear, elected him emperor and killed Julian. After this

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: there remained for Severus, who wished to make himself master of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: whole empire, two difficulties; one in Asia, where Niger, head of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Asiatic army, had caused himself to be proclaimed emperor; the other in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
