text: the west where Albinus was, who also aspired to the throne. And as he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: considered it dangerous to declare himself hostile to both, he decided

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to attack Niger and to deceive Albinus. To the latter he wrote that,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: being elected emperor by the Senate, he was willing to share that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: dignity with him and sent him the title of Caesar; and, moreover, that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the Senate had made Albinus his colleague; which things were accepted

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: by Albinus as true. But after Severus had conquered and killed Niger,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and settled oriental affairs, he returned to Rome and complained to the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Senate that Albinus, little recognizing the benefits that he had

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: received from him, had by treachery sought to murder him, and for this

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ingratitude he was compelled to punish him. Afterwards he sought him

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: out in France, and took from him his government and life. He who will,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: therefore, carefully examine the actions of this man will find him a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: most valiant lion and a most cunning fox; he will find him feared and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: respected by every one, and not hated by the army; and it need not be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: wondered at that he, a new man, was able to hold the empire so well,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: because his supreme renown always protected him from that hatred which

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the people might have conceived against him for his violence.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: But his son Antoninus was a most eminent man, and had very excellent

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: qualities, which made him admirable in the sight of the people and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: acceptable to the soldiers, for he was a warlike man, most enduring of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: fatigue, a despiser of all delicate food and other luxuries, which

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: caused him to be beloved by the armies. Nevertheless, his ferocity and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: cruelties were so great and so unheard of that, after endless single

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: murders, he killed a large number of the people of Rome and all those

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of Alexandria. He became hated by the whole world, and also feared by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: those he had around him, to such an extent that he was murdered in the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: midst of his army by a centurion. And here it must be noted that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: such-like deaths, which are deliberately inflicted with a resolved and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: desperate courage, cannot be avoided by princes, because any one who

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: does not fear to die can inflict them; but a prince may fear them the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: less because they are very rare; he has only to be careful not to do

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: any grave injury to those whom he employs or has around him in the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: service of the state. Antoninus had not taken this care, but had

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: contumeliously killed a brother of that centurion, whom also he daily

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: threatened, yet retained in his bodyguard; which, as it turned out, was

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: a rash thing to do, and proved the emperor’s ruin.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: But let us come to Commodus, to whom it should have been very easy to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: hold the empire, for, being the son of Marcus, he had inherited it, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: he had only to follow in the footsteps of his father to please his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: people and soldiers; but, being by nature cruel and brutal, he gave

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: himself up to amusing the soldiers and corrupting them, so that he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: might indulge his rapacity upon the people; on the other hand, not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: maintaining his dignity, often descending to the theatre to compete

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: with gladiators, and doing other vile things, little worthy of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: imperial majesty, he fell into contempt with the soldiers, and being

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: hated by one party and despised by the other, he was conspired against

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and was killed.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: It remains to discuss the character of Maximinus. He was a very warlike

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: man, and the armies, being disgusted with the effeminacy of Alexander,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of whom I have already spoken, killed him and elected Maximinus to the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: throne. This he did not possess for long, for two things made him hated

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and despised; the one, his having kept sheep in Thrace, which brought

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: him into contempt (it being well known to all, and considered a great

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: indignity by every one), and the other, his having at the accession to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: his dominions deferred going to Rome and taking possession of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: imperial seat; he had also gained a reputation for the utmost ferocity

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: by having, through his prefects in Rome and elsewhere in the empire,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: practised many cruelties, so that the whole world was moved to anger at

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the meanness of his birth and to fear at his barbarity. First Africa

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: rebelled, then the Senate with all the people of Rome, and all Italy

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: conspired against him, to which may be added his own army; this latter,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: besieging Aquileia and meeting with difficulties in taking it, were

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: disgusted with his cruelties, and fearing him less when they found so

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: many against him, murdered him.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: I do not wish to discuss Heliogabalus, Macrinus, or Julian, who, being

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: thoroughly contemptible, were quickly wiped out; but I will bring this

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: discourse to a conclusion by saying that princes in our times have this

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: difficulty of giving inordinate satisfaction to their soldiers in a far

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: less degree, because, notwithstanding one has to give them some

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: indulgence, that is soon done; none of these princes have armies that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: are veterans in the governance and administration of provinces, as were

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the armies of the Roman Empire; and whereas it was then more necessary

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to give satisfaction to the soldiers than to the people, it is now more

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: necessary to all princes, except the Turk and the Soldan, to satisfy

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the people rather the soldiers, because the people are the more

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: powerful.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: From the above I have excepted the Turk, who always keeps round him

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: twelve thousand infantry and fifteen thousand cavalry on which depend

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the security and strength of the kingdom, and it is necessary that,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: putting aside every consideration for the people, he should keep them

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: his friends. The kingdom of the Soldan is similar; being entirely in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the hands of soldiers, it follows again that, without regard to the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: people, he must keep them his friends. But you must note that the state

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of the Soldan is unlike all other principalities, for the reason that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: it is like the Christian pontificate, which cannot be called either an

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: hereditary or a newly formed principality; because the sons of the old

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prince are not the heirs, but he who is elected to that position by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: those who have authority, and the sons remain only noblemen. And this

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: being an ancient custom, it cannot be called a new principality,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: because there are none of those difficulties in it that are met with in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: new ones; for although the prince is new, the constitution of the state

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: is old, and it is framed so as to receive him as if he were its

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: hereditary lord.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: But returning to the subject of our discourse, I say that whoever will

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: consider it will acknowledge that either hatred or contempt has been

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: fatal to the above-named emperors, and it will be recognized also how

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: it happened that, a number of them acting in one way and a number in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: another, only one in each way came to a happy end and the rest to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: unhappy ones. Because it would have been useless and dangerous for

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Pertinax and Alexander, being new princes, to imitate Marcus, who was

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: heir to the principality; and likewise it would have been utterly

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: destructive to Caracalla, Commodus, and Maximinus to have imitated

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Severus, they not having sufficient valour to enable them to tread in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: his footsteps. Therefore a prince, new to the principality, cannot

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: imitate the actions of Marcus, nor, again, is it necessary to follow

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: those of Severus, but he ought to take from Severus those parts which

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: are necessary to found his state, and from Marcus those which are

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: proper and glorious to keep a state that may already be stable and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: firm.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CHAPTER XX.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ARE FORTRESSES, AND MANY OTHER THINGS TO WHICH PRINCES OFTEN RESORT,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ADVANTAGEOUS OR HURTFUL?

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: 1. Some princes, so as to hold securely the state, have disarmed their

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: subjects; others have kept their subject towns distracted by factions;

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: others have fostered enmities against themselves; others have laid

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: themselves out to gain over those whom they distrusted in the beginning

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of their governments; some have built fortresses; some have overthrown

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and destroyed them. And although one cannot give a final judgment on

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: all of these things unless one possesses the particulars of those

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: states in which a decision has to be made, nevertheless I will speak as

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: comprehensively as the matter of itself will admit.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: 2. There never was a new prince who has disarmed his subjects; rather

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: when he has found them disarmed he has always armed them, because, by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: arming them, those arms become yours, those men who were distrusted

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: become faithful, and those who were faithful are kept so, and your

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: subjects become your adherents. And whereas all subjects cannot be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: armed, yet when those whom you do arm are benefited, the others can be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: handled more freely, and this difference in their treatment, which they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: quite understand, makes the former your dependents, and the latter,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: considering it to be necessary that those who have the most danger and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: service should have the most reward, excuse you. But when you disarm

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: them, you at once offend them by showing that you distrust them, either

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: for cowardice or for want of loyalty, and either of these opinions

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: breeds hatred against you. And because you cannot remain unarmed, it

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: follows that you turn to mercenaries, which are of the character

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: already shown; even if they should be good they would not be sufficient

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to defend you against powerful enemies and distrusted subjects.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Therefore, as I have said, a new prince in a new principality has

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: always distributed arms. Histories are full of examples. But when a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prince acquires a new state, which he adds as a province to his old

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: one, then it is necessary to disarm the men of that state, except those

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: who have been his adherents in acquiring it; and these again, with time

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and opportunity, should be rendered soft and effeminate; and matters

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: should be managed in such a way that all the armed men in the state

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: shall be your own soldiers who in your old state were living near you.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: 3. Our forefathers, and those who were reckoned wise, were accustomed

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to say that it was necessary to hold Pistoia by factions and Pisa by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: fortresses; and with this idea they fostered quarrels in some of their

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: tributary towns so as to keep possession of them the more easily. This

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: may have been well enough in those times when Italy was in a way

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: balanced, but I do not believe that it can be accepted as a precept for

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to-day, because I do not believe that factions can ever be of use;

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: rather it is certain that when the enemy comes upon you in divided

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: cities you are quickly lost, because the weakest party will always

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: assist the outside forces and the other will not be able to resist. The

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Venetians, moved, as I believe, by the above reasons, fostered the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Guelph and Ghibelline factions in their tributary cities; and although

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: they never allowed them to come to bloodshed, yet they nursed these

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: disputes amongst them, so that the citizens, distracted by their

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: differences, should not unite against them. Which, as we saw, did not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: afterwards turn out as expected, because, after the rout at Vaila, one

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: party at once took courage and seized the state. Such methods argue,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: therefore, weakness in the prince, because these factions will never be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: permitted in a vigorous principality; such methods for enabling one the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: more easily to manage subjects are only useful in times of peace, but

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: if war comes this policy proves fallacious.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: 4. Without doubt princes become great when they overcome the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: difficulties and obstacles by which they are confronted, and therefore

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: fortune, especially when she desires to make a new prince great, who

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: has a greater necessity to earn renown than an hereditary one, causes

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: enemies to arise and form designs against him, in order that he may

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: have the opportunity of overcoming them, and by them to mount higher,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: as by a ladder which his enemies have raised. For this reason many

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: consider that a wise prince, when he has the opportunity, ought with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: craft to foster some animosity against himself, so that, having crushed

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: it, his renown may rise higher.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: 5. Princes, especially new ones, have found more fidelity and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: assistance in those men who in the beginning of their rule were

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: distrusted than among those who in the beginning were trusted. Pandolfo

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Petrucci, Prince of Siena, ruled his state more by those who had been

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: distrusted than by others. But on this question one cannot speak

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: generally, for it varies so much with the individual; I will only say

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: this, that those men who at the commencement of a princedom have been

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: hostile, if they are of a description to need assistance to support

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: themselves, can always be gained over with the greatest ease, and they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: will be tightly held to serve the prince with fidelity, inasmuch as

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: they know it to be very necessary for them to cancel by deeds the bad

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: impression which he had formed of them; and thus the prince always

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: extracts more profit from them than from those who, serving him in too

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: much security, may neglect his affairs. And since the matter demands

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: it, I must not fail to warn a prince, who by means of secret favours

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: has acquired a new state, that he must well consider the reasons which

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: induced those to favour him who did so; and if it be not a natural

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: affection towards him, but only discontent with their government, then

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: he will only keep them friendly with great trouble and difficulty, for

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: it will be impossible to satisfy them. And weighing well the reasons

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: for this in those examples which can be taken from ancient and modern

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: affairs, we shall find that it is easier for the prince to make friends

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of those men who were contented under the former government, and are

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: therefore his enemies, than of those who, being discontented with it,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: were favourable to him and encouraged him to seize it.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: 6. It has been a custom with princes, in order to hold their states

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: more securely, to build fortresses that may serve as a bridle and bit

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to those who might design to work against them, and as a place of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: refuge from a first attack. I praise this system because it has been

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: made use of formerly. Notwithstanding that, Messer Nicolo Vitelli in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: our times has been seen to demolish two fortresses in Citta di Castello

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: so that he might keep that state; Guido Ubaldo, Duke of Urbino, on

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: returning to his dominion, whence he had been driven by Cesare Borgia,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: razed to the foundations all the fortresses in that province, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: considered that without them it would be more difficult to lose it; the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Bentivogli returning to Bologna came to a similar decision. Fortresses,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: therefore, are useful or not according to circumstances; if they do you

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: good in one way they injure you in another. And this question can be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: reasoned thus: the prince who has more to fear from the people than

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: from foreigners ought to build fortresses, but he who has more to fear

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: from foreigners than from the people ought to leave them alone. The

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: castle of Milan, built by Francesco Sforza, has made, and will make,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: more trouble for the house of Sforza than any other disorder in the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: state. For this reason the best possible fortress is—not to be hated by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the people, because, although you may hold the fortresses, yet they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: will not save you if the people hate you, for there will never be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: wanting foreigners to assist a people who have taken arms against you.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: It has not been seen in our times that such fortresses have been of use

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to any prince, unless to the Countess of Forli,[1] when the Count

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Girolamo, her consort, was killed; for by that means she was able to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: withstand the popular attack and wait for assistance from Milan, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: thus recover her state; and the posture of affairs was such at that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: time that the foreigners could not assist the people. But fortresses

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: were of little value to her afterwards when Cesare Borgia attacked her,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and when the people, her enemy, were allied with foreigners. Therefore,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: it would have been safer for her, both then and before, not to have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: been hated by the people than to have had the fortresses. All these

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: things considered then, I shall praise him who builds fortresses as

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: well as him who does not, and I shall blame whoever, trusting in them,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: cares little about being hated by the people.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [1] Catherine Sforza, a daughter of Galeazzo Sforza and Lucrezia

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Landriani, born 1463, died 1509. It was to the Countess of Forli that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Machiavelli was sent as envoy on 1499. A letter from Fortunati to the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: countess announces the appointment: “I have been with the signori,”

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: wrote Fortunati, “to learn whom they would send and when. They tell me

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that Nicolo Machiavelli, a learned young Florentine noble, secretary

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to my Lords of the Ten, is to leave with me at once.” Cf. “Catherine

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Sforza,” by Count Pasolini, translated by P. Sylvester, 1898.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CHAPTER XXI.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: HOW A PRINCE SHOULD CONDUCT HIMSELF SO AS TO GAIN RENOWN

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Nothing makes a prince so much esteemed as great enterprises and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: setting a fine example. We have in our time Ferdinand of Aragon, the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: present King of Spain. He can almost be called a new prince, because he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: has risen, by fame and glory, from being an insignificant king to be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the foremost king in Christendom; and if you will consider his deeds

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: you will find them all great and some of them extraordinary. In the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: beginning of his reign he attacked Granada, and this enterprise was the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: foundation of his dominions. He did this quietly at first and without

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: any fear of hindrance, for he held the minds of the barons of Castile

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: occupied in thinking of the war and not anticipating any innovations;

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: thus they did not perceive that by these means he was acquiring power

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and authority over them. He was able with the money of the Church and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of the people to sustain his armies, and by that long war to lay the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: foundation for the military skill which has since distinguished him.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Further, always using religion as a plea, so as to undertake greater

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: schemes, he devoted himself with pious cruelty to driving out and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: clearing his kingdom of the Moors; nor could there be a more admirable

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: example, nor one more rare. Under this same cloak he assailed Africa,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: he came down on Italy, he has finally attacked France; and thus his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: achievements and designs have always been great, and have kept the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: minds of his people in suspense and admiration and occupied with the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: issue of them. And his actions have arisen in such a way, one out of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the other, that men have never been given time to work steadily against

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: him.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Again, it much assists a prince to set unusual examples in internal

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: affairs, similar to those which are related of Messer Bernabo da

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Milano, who, when he had the opportunity, by any one in civil life

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: doing some extraordinary thing, either good or bad, would take some

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: method of rewarding or punishing him, which would be much spoken about.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: And a prince ought, above all things, always endeavour in every action

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to gain for himself the reputation of being a great and remarkable man.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: A prince is also respected when he is either a true friend or a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: downright enemy, that is to say, when, without any reservation, he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: declares himself in favour of one party against the other; which course

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: will always be more advantageous than standing neutral; because if two

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of your powerful neighbours come to blows, they are of such a character

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that, if one of them conquers, you have either to fear him or not. In

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: either case it will always be more advantageous for you to declare

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: yourself and to make war strenuously; because, in the first case, if

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: you do not declare yourself, you will invariably fall a prey to the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: conqueror, to the pleasure and satisfaction of him who has been

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: conquered, and you will have no reasons to offer, nor anything to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: protect or to shelter you. Because he who conquers does not want

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: doubtful friends who will not aid him in the time of trial; and he who

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: loses will not harbour you because you did not willingly, sword in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: hand, court his fate.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Antiochus went into Greece, being sent for by the Ætolians to drive out

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the Romans. He sent envoys to the Achaeans, who were friends of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Romans, exhorting them to remain neutral; and on the other hand the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Romans urged them to take up arms. This question came to be discussed

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: in the council of the Achaeans, where the legate of Antiochus urged

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: them to stand neutral. To this the Roman legate answered: “As for that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: which has been said, that it is better and more advantageous for your

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: state not to interfere in our war, nothing can be more erroneous;

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: because by not interfering you will be left, without favour or

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: consideration, the guerdon of the conqueror.” Thus it will always

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: happen that he who is not your friend will demand your neutrality,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: whilst he who is your friend will entreat you to declare yourself with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: arms. And irresolute princes, to avoid present dangers, generally

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: follow the neutral path, and are generally ruined. But when a prince

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: declares himself gallantly in favour of one side, if the party with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: whom he allies himself conquers, although the victor may be powerful

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and may have him at his mercy, yet he is indebted to him, and there is

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: established a bond of amity; and men are never so shameless as to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: become a monument of ingratitude by oppressing you. Victories after all

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: are never so complete that the victor must not show some regard,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: especially to justice. But if he with whom you ally yourself loses, you

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: may be sheltered by him, and whilst he is able he may aid you, and you

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: become companions on a fortune that may rise again.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: In the second case, when those who fight are of such a character that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: you have no anxiety as to who may conquer, so much the more is it

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: greater prudence to be allied, because you assist at the destruction of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: one by the aid of another who, if he had been wise, would have saved

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: him; and conquering, as it is impossible that he should not do with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: your assistance, he remains at your discretion. And here it is to be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: noted that a prince ought to take care never to make an alliance with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: one more powerful than himself for the purposes of attacking others,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: unless necessity compels him, as is said above; because if he conquers

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: you are at his discretion, and princes ought to avoid as much as

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: possible being at the discretion of any one. The Venetians joined with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: France against the Duke of Milan, and this alliance, which caused their

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ruin, could have been avoided. But when it cannot be avoided, as

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: happened to the Florentines when the Pope and Spain sent armies to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: attack Lombardy, then in such a case, for the above reasons, the prince

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ought to favour one of the parties.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Never let any Government imagine that it can choose perfectly safe

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: courses; rather let it expect to have to take very doubtful ones,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: because it is found in ordinary affairs that one never seeks to avoid

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: one trouble without running into another; but prudence consists in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: knowing how to distinguish the character of troubles, and for choice to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: take the lesser evil.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: A prince ought also to show himself a patron of ability, and to honour

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the proficient in every art. At the same time he should encourage his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: citizens to practise their callings peaceably, both in commerce and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: agriculture, and in every other following, so that the one should not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: be deterred from improving his possessions for fear lest they be taken

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: away from him or another from opening up trade for fear of taxes; but

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the prince ought to offer rewards to whoever wishes to do these things

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and designs in any way to honour his city or state.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Further, he ought to entertain the people with festivals and spectacles

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: at convenient seasons of the year; and as every city is divided into

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: guilds or into societies,[1] he ought to hold such bodies in esteem,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and associate with them sometimes, and show himself an example of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: courtesy and liberality; nevertheless, always maintaining the majesty

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of his rank, for this he must never consent to abate in anything.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [1] “Guilds or societies,” “in arti o in tribu.” “Arti” were craft or

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: trade guilds, cf. Florio: “Arte . . . a whole company of any trade

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: in any city or corporation town.” The guilds of Florence are most

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: admirably described by Mr Edgcumbe Staley in his work on the subject

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: (Methuen, 1906). Institutions of a somewhat similar character, called

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: “artel,” exist in Russia to-day, cf. Sir Mackenzie Wallace’s

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: “Russia,” ed. 1905: “The sons . . . were always during the working

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: season members of an artel. In some of the larger towns there are

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: artels of a much more complex kind— permanent associations, possessing

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: large capital, and pecuniarily responsible for the acts of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: individual members.” The word “artel,” despite its apparent

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: similarity, has, Mr Aylmer Maude assures me, no connection with “ars”

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: or “arte.” Its root is that of the verb “rotisya,” to bind oneself by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: an oath; and it is generally admitted to be only another form of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: “rota,” which now signifies a “regimental company.” In both words the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: underlying idea is that of a body of men united by an oath. “Tribu”

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: were possibly gentile groups, united by common descent, and included

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: individuals connected by marriage. Perhaps our words “sects” or

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: “clans” would be most appropriate.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CHAPTER XXII.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CONCERNING THE SECRETARIES OF PRINCES

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: The choice of servants is of no little importance to a prince, and they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: are good or not according to the discrimination of the prince. And the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: first opinion which one forms of a prince, and of his understanding, is

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: by observing the men he has around him; and when they are capable and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: faithful he may always be considered wise, because he has known how to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: recognize the capable and to keep them faithful. But when they are

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: otherwise one cannot form a good opinion of him, for the prime error

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: which he made was in choosing them.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: There were none who knew Messer Antonio da Venafro as the servant of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Pandolfo Petrucci, Prince of Siena, who would not consider Pandolfo to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: be a very clever man in having Venafro for his servant. Because there

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: are three classes of intellects: one which comprehends by itself;

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: another which appreciates what others comprehended; and a third which

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: neither comprehends by itself nor by the showing of others; the first

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: is the most excellent, the second is good, the third is useless.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Therefore, it follows necessarily that, if Pandolfo was not in the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: first rank, he was in the second, for whenever one has judgment to know

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: good and bad when it is said and done, although he himself may not have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the initiative, yet he can recognize the good and the bad in his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: servant, and the one he can praise and the other correct; thus the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: servant cannot hope to deceive him, and is kept honest.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: But to enable a prince to form an opinion of his servant there is one

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: test which never fails; when you see the servant thinking more of his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: own interests than of yours, and seeking inwardly his own profit in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: everything, such a man will never make a good servant, nor will you

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ever be able to trust him; because he who has the state of another in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: his hands ought never to think of himself, but always of his prince,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and never pay any attention to matters in which the prince is not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: concerned.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: On the other hand, to keep his servant honest the prince ought to study

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: him, honouring him, enriching him, doing him kindnesses, sharing with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: him the honours and cares; and at the same time let him see that he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: cannot stand alone, so that many honours may not make him desire more,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: many riches make him wish for more, and that many cares may make him

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: dread chances. When, therefore, servants, and princes towards servants,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: are thus disposed, they can trust each other, but when it is otherwise,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the end will always be disastrous for either one or the other.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CHAPTER XXIII.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: HOW FLATTERERS SHOULD BE AVOIDED

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: I do not wish to leave out an important branch of this subject, for it

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: is a danger from which princes are with difficulty preserved, unless

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: they are very careful and discriminating. It is that of flatterers, of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: whom courts are full, because men are so self-complacent in their own

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: affairs, and in a way so deceived in them, that they are preserved with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: difficulty from this pest, and if they wish to defend themselves they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: run the danger of falling into contempt. Because there is no other way

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of guarding oneself from flatterers except letting men understand that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to tell you the truth does not offend you; but when every one may tell

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: you the truth, respect for you abates.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Therefore a wise prince ought to hold a third course by choosing the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: wise men in his state, and giving to them only the liberty of speaking

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the truth to him, and then only of those things of which he inquires,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and of none others; but he ought to question them upon everything, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: listen to their opinions, and afterwards form his own conclusions. With

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: these councillors, separately and collectively, he ought to carry

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: himself in such a way that each of them should know that, the more

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: freely he shall speak, the more he shall be preferred; outside of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: these, he should listen to no one, pursue the thing resolved on, and be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: steadfast in his resolutions. He who does otherwise is either

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: overthrown by flatterers, or is so often changed by varying opinions

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that he falls into contempt.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: I wish on this subject to adduce a modern example. Fra Luca, the man of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: affairs to Maximilian,[1] the present emperor, speaking of his majesty,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: said: He consulted with no one, yet never got his own way in anything.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: This arose because of his following a practice the opposite to the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: above; for the emperor is a secretive man—he does not communicate his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: designs to any one, nor does he receive opinions on them. But as in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: carrying them into effect they become revealed and known, they are at

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: once obstructed by those men whom he has around him, and he, being

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: pliant, is diverted from them. Hence it follows that those things he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: does one day he undoes the next, and no one ever understands what he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: wishes or intends to do, and no one can rely on his resolutions.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [1] Maximilian I, born in 1459, died 1519, Emperor of the Holy Roman

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Empire. He married, first, Mary, daughter of Charles the Bold; after

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: her death, Bianca Sforza; and thus became involved in Italian

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: politics.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: A prince, therefore, ought always to take counsel, but only when he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: wishes and not when others wish; he ought rather to discourage every

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: one from offering advice unless he asks it; but, however, he ought to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: be a constant inquirer, and afterwards a patient listener concerning

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the things of which he inquired; also, on learning that any one, on any

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: consideration, has not told him the truth, he should let his anger be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: felt.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: And if there are some who think that a prince who conveys an impression

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of his wisdom is not so through his own ability, but through the good

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: advisers that he has around him, beyond doubt they are deceived,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: because this is an axiom which never fails: that a prince who is not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: wise himself will never take good advice, unless by chance he has

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: yielded his affairs entirely to one person who happens to be a very

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prudent man. In this case indeed he may be well governed, but it would

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: not be for long, because such a governor would in a short time take

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: away his state from him.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: But if a prince who is not inexperienced should take counsel from more

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: than one he will never get united counsels, nor will he know how to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: unite them. Each of the counsellors will think of his own interests,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and the prince will not know how to control them or to see through

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: them. And they are not to be found otherwise, because men will always

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prove untrue to you unless they are kept honest by constraint.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Therefore it must be inferred that good counsels, whencesoever they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: come, are born of the wisdom of the prince, and not the wisdom of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prince from good counsels.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CHAPTER XXIV.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: WHY THE PRINCES OF ITALY HAVE LOST THEIR STATES

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: The previous suggestions, carefully observed, will enable a new prince

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to appear well established, and render him at once more secure and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: fixed in the state than if he had been long seated there. For the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: actions of a new prince are more narrowly observed than those of an

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: hereditary one, and when they are seen to be able they gain more men

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and bind far tighter than ancient blood; because men are attracted more

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: by the present than by the past, and when they find the present good

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: they enjoy it and seek no further; they will also make the utmost

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: defence of a prince if he fails them not in other things. Thus it will

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: be a double glory for him to have established a new principality, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: adorned and strengthened it with good laws, good arms, good allies, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: with a good example; so will it be a double disgrace to him who, born a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prince, shall lose his state by want of wisdom.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: And if those seigniors are considered who have lost their states in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Italy in our times, such as the King of Naples, the Duke of Milan, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: others, there will be found in them, firstly, one common defect in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: regard to arms from the causes which have been discussed at length; in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the next place, some one of them will be seen, either to have had the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: people hostile, or if he has had the people friendly, he has not known

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: how to secure the nobles. In the absence of these defects states that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: have power enough to keep an army in the field cannot be lost.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Philip of Macedon, not the father of Alexander the Great, but he who

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: was conquered by Titus Quintius, had not much territory compared to the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: greatness of the Romans and of Greece who attacked him, yet being a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: warlike man who knew how to attract the people and secure the nobles,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: he sustained the war against his enemies for many years, and if in the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: end he lost the dominion of some cities, nevertheless he retained the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: kingdom.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Therefore, do not let our princes accuse fortune for the loss of their

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: principalities after so many years’ possession, but rather their own

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: sloth, because in quiet times they never thought there could be a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: change (it is a common defect in man not to make any provision in the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: calm against the tempest), and when afterwards the bad times came they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: thought of flight and not of defending themselves, and they hoped that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the people, disgusted with the insolence of the conquerors, would

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: recall them. This course, when others fail, may be good, but it is very

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: bad to have neglected all other expedients for that, since you would

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: never wish to fall because you trusted to be able to find someone later

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: on to restore you. This again either does not happen, or, if it does,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: it will not be for your security, because that deliverance is of no

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: avail which does not depend upon yourself; those only are reliable,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: certain, and durable that depend on yourself and your valour.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CHAPTER XXV.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: WHAT FORTUNE CAN EFFECT IN HUMAN AFFAIRS AND HOW TO WITHSTAND HER

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: It is not unknown to me how many men have had, and still have, the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: opinion that the affairs of the world are in such wise governed by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: fortune and by God that men with their wisdom cannot direct them and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that no one can even help them; and because of this they would have us

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: believe that it is not necessary to labour much in affairs, but to let

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: chance govern them. This opinion has been more credited in our times

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: because of the great changes in affairs which have been seen, and may

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: still be seen, every day, beyond all human conjecture. Sometimes

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: pondering over this, I am in some degree inclined to their opinion.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Nevertheless, not to extinguish our free will, I hold it to be true

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that Fortune is the arbiter of one-half of our actions,[1] but that she

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: still leaves us to direct the other half, or perhaps a little less.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [1] Frederick the Great was accustomed to say: “The older one gets the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: more convinced one becomes that his Majesty King Chance does

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: three-quarters of the business of this miserable universe.” Sorel’s

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: “Eastern Question.”

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: I compare her to one of those raging rivers, which when in flood

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: overflows the plains, sweeping away trees and buildings, bearing away

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the soil from place to place; everything flies before it, all yield to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: its violence, without being able in any way to withstand it; and yet,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: though its nature be such, it does not follow therefore that men, when

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the weather becomes fair, shall not make provision, both with defences

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and barriers, in such a manner that, rising again, the waters may pass

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: away by canal, and their force be neither so unrestrained nor so

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: dangerous. So it happens with fortune, who shows her power where valour

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: has not prepared to resist her, and thither she turns her forces where

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: she knows that barriers and defences have not been raised to constrain

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: her.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: And if you will consider Italy, which is the seat of these changes, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: which has given to them their impulse, you will see it to be an open

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: country without barriers and without any defence. For if it had been

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: defended by proper valour, as are Germany, Spain, and France, either

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: this invasion would not have made the great changes it has made or it

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: would not have come at all. And this I consider enough to say

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: concerning resistance to fortune in general.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: But confining myself more to the particular, I say that a prince may be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: seen happy to-day and ruined to-morrow without having shown any change

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of disposition or character. This, I believe, arises firstly from

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: causes that have already been discussed at length, namely, that the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prince who relies entirely on fortune is lost when it changes. I

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: believe also that he will be successful who directs his actions

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: according to the spirit of the times, and that he whose actions do not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: accord with the times will not be successful. Because men are seen, in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: affairs that lead to the end which every man has before him, namely,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: glory and riches, to get there by various methods; one with caution,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: another with haste; one by force, another by skill; one by patience,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: another by its opposite; and each one succeeds in reaching the goal by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: a different method. One can also see of two cautious men the one attain

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: his end, the other fail; and similarly, two men by different

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: observances are equally successful, the one being cautious, the other

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: impetuous; all this arises from nothing else than whether or not they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: conform in their methods to the spirit of the times. This follows from

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: what I have said, that two men working differently bring about the same

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: effect, and of two working similarly, one attains his object and the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: other does not.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Changes in estate also issue from this, for if, to one who governs

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: himself with caution and patience, times and affairs converge in such a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: way that his administration is successful, his fortune is made; but if

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: times and affairs change, he is ruined if he does not change his course

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of action. But a man is not often found sufficiently circumspect to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: know how to accommodate himself to the change, both because he cannot

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: deviate from what nature inclines him to do, and also because, having

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: always prospered by acting in one way, he cannot be persuaded that it

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: is well to leave it; and, therefore, the cautious man, when it is time

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to turn adventurous, does not know how to do it, hence he is ruined;

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: but had he changed his conduct with the times fortune would not have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: changed.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Pope Julius the Second went to work impetuously in all his affairs, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: found the times and circumstances conform so well to that line of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: action that he always met with success. Consider his first enterprise

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: against Bologna, Messer Giovanni Bentivogli being still alive. The

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Venetians were not agreeable to it, nor was the King of Spain, and he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: had the enterprise still under discussion with the King of France;

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: nevertheless he personally entered upon the expedition with his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: accustomed boldness and energy, a move which made Spain and the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Venetians stand irresolute and passive, the latter from fear, the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: former from desire to recover the kingdom of Naples; on the other hand,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: he drew after him the King of France, because that king, having

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: observed the movement, and desiring to make the Pope his friend so as

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to humble the Venetians, found it impossible to refuse him. Therefore

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Julius with his impetuous action accomplished what no other pontiff

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: with simple human wisdom could have done; for if he had waited in Rome

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: until he could get away, with his plans arranged and everything fixed,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: as any other pontiff would have done, he would never have succeeded.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Because the King of France would have made a thousand excuses, and the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: others would have raised a thousand fears.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: I will leave his other actions alone, as they were all alike, and they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: all succeeded, for the shortness of his life did not let him experience

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the contrary; but if circumstances had arisen which required him to go

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: cautiously, his ruin would have followed, because he would never have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: deviated from those ways to which nature inclined him.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: I conclude, therefore that, fortune being changeful and mankind

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: steadfast in their ways, so long as the two are in agreement men are

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: successful, but unsuccessful when they fall out. For my part I consider

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that it is better to be adventurous than cautious, because fortune is a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: woman, and if you wish to keep her under it is necessary to beat and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ill-use her; and it is seen that she allows herself to be mastered by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the adventurous rather than by those who go to work more coldly. She

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: is, therefore, always, woman-like, a lover of young men, because they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: are less cautious, more violent, and with more audacity command her.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CHAPTER XXVI.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: AN EXHORTATION TO LIBERATE ITALY FROM THE BARBARIANS

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Having carefully considered the subject of the above discourses, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: wondering within myself whether the present times were propitious to a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: new prince, and whether there were elements that would give an

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: opportunity to a wise and virtuous one to introduce a new order of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: things which would do honour to him and good to the people of this

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: country, it appears to me that so many things concur to favour a new

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prince that I never knew a time more fit than the present.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: And if, as I said, it was necessary that the people of Israel should be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: captive so as to make manifest the ability of Moses; that the Persians

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: should be oppressed by the Medes so as to discover the greatness of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: soul of Cyrus; and that the Athenians should be dispersed to illustrate

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the capabilities of Theseus: then at the present time, in order to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: discover the virtue of an Italian spirit, it was necessary that Italy

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: should be reduced to the extremity that she is now in, that she should

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: be more enslaved than the Hebrews, more oppressed than the Persians,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: more scattered than the Athenians; without head, without order, beaten,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: despoiled, torn, overrun; and to have endured every kind of desolation.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Although lately some spark may have been shown by one, which made us

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: think he was ordained by God for our redemption, nevertheless it was

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: afterwards seen, in the height of his career, that fortune rejected

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: him; so that Italy, left as without life, waits for him who shall yet

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: heal her wounds and put an end to the ravaging and plundering of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Lombardy, to the swindling and taxing of the kingdom and of Tuscany,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and cleanse those sores that for long have festered. It is seen how she

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: entreats God to send someone who shall deliver her from these wrongs

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and barbarous insolencies. It is seen also that she is ready and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: willing to follow a banner if only someone will raise it.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Nor is there to be seen at present one in whom she can place more hope

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: than in your illustrious house,[1] with its valour and fortune,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: favoured by God and by the Church of which it is now the chief, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: which could be made the head of this redemption. This will not be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: difficult if you will recall to yourself the actions and lives of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: men I have named. And although they were great and wonderful men, yet

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: they were men, and each one of them had no more opportunity than the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: present offers, for their enterprises were neither more just nor easier

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: than this, nor was God more their friend than He is yours.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [1] Giuliano de Medici. He had just been created a cardinal by Leo X.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: In 1523 Giuliano was elected Pope, and took the title of Clement VII.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: With us there is great justice, because that war is just which is

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: necessary, and arms are hallowed when there is no other hope but in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: them. Here there is the greatest willingness, and where the willingness

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: is great the difficulties cannot be great if you will only follow those

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: men to whom I have directed your attention. Further than this, how

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: extraordinarily the ways of God have been manifested beyond example:

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the sea is divided, a cloud has led the way, the rock has poured forth

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: water, it has rained manna, everything has contributed to your

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: greatness; you ought to do the rest. God is not willing to do

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: everything, and thus take away our free will and that share of glory

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: which belongs to us.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: And it is not to be wondered at if none of the above-named Italians

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: have been able to accomplish all that is expected from your illustrious

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: house; and if in so many revolutions in Italy, and in so many

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: campaigns, it has always appeared as if military virtue were exhausted,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: this has happened because the old order of things was not good, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: none of us have known how to find a new one. And nothing honours a man

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: more than to establish new laws and new ordinances when he himself was

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: newly risen. Such things when they are well founded and dignified will

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: make him revered and admired, and in Italy there are not wanting

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: opportunities to bring such into use in every form.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Here there is great valour in the limbs whilst it fails in the head.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Look attentively at the duels and the hand-to-hand combats, how

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: superior the Italians are in strength, dexterity, and subtlety. But

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: when it comes to armies they do not bear comparison, and this springs

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: entirely from the insufficiency of the leaders, since those who are

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: capable are not obedient, and each one seems to himself to know, there

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: having never been any one so distinguished above the rest, either by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: valour or fortune, that others would yield to him. Hence it is that for

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: so long a time, and during so much fighting in the past twenty years,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: whenever there has been an army wholly Italian, it has always given a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: poor account of itself; the first witness to this is Il Taro,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: afterwards Allesandria, Capua, Genoa, Vaila, Bologna, Mestri.[2]

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: [2] The battles of Il Taro, 1495; Alessandria, 1499; Capua, 1501;

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Genoa, 1507; Vaila, 1509; Bologna, 1511; Mestri, 1513.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: If, therefore, your illustrious house wishes to follow these remarkable

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: men who have redeemed their country, it is necessary before all things,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: as a true foundation for every enterprise, to be provided with your own

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: forces, because there can be no more faithful, truer, or better

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: soldiers. And although singly they are good, altogether they will be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: much better when they find themselves commanded by their prince,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: honoured by him, and maintained at his expense. Therefore it is

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: necessary to be prepared with such arms, so that you can be defended

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: against foreigners by Italian valour.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: And although Swiss and Spanish infantry may be considered very

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: formidable, nevertheless there is a defect in both, by reason of which

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: a third order would not only be able to oppose them, but might be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: relied upon to overthrow them. For the Spaniards cannot resist cavalry,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and the Switzers are afraid of infantry whenever they encounter them in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: close combat. Owing to this, as has been and may again be seen, the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Spaniards are unable to resist French cavalry, and the Switzers are

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: overthrown by Spanish infantry. And although a complete proof of this

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: latter cannot be shown, nevertheless there was some evidence of it at

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the battle of Ravenna, when the Spanish infantry were confronted by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: German battalions, who follow the same tactics as the Swiss; when the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Spaniards, by agility of body and with the aid of their shields, got in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: under the pikes of the Germans and stood out of danger, able to attack,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: while the Germans stood helpless, and, if the cavalry had not dashed

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: up, all would have been over with them. It is possible, therefore,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: knowing the defects of both these infantries, to invent a new one,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: which will resist cavalry and not be afraid of infantry; this need not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: create a new order of arms, but a variation upon the old. And these are

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the kind of improvements which confer reputation and power upon a new

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prince.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: This opportunity, therefore, ought not to be allowed to pass for

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: letting Italy at last see her liberator appear. Nor can one express the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: love with which he would be received in all those provinces which have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: suffered so much from these foreign scourings, with what thirst for

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: revenge, with what stubborn faith, with what devotion, with what tears.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: What door would be closed to him? Who would refuse obedience to him?

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: What envy would hinder him? What Italian would refuse him homage? To

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: all of us this barbarous dominion stinks. Let, therefore, your

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: illustrious house take up this charge with that courage and hope with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: which all just enterprises are undertaken, so that under its standard

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: our native country may be ennobled, and under its auspices may be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: verified that saying of Petrarch:

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Virtu contro al Furore

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Prendera l’arme, e fia il combatter corto:

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Che l’antico valore

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Negli italici cuor non e ancor morto.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Virtue against fury shall advance the fight,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: And it i’ th’ combat soon shall put to flight:

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: For the old Roman valour is not dead,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Nor in th’ Italians’ brests extinguished.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Edward Dacre, 1640.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: DESCRIPTION OF THE METHODS ADOPTED BY THE DUKE VALENTINO WHEN MURDERING

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: VITELLOZZO VITELLI, OLIVEROTTO DA FERMO, THE SIGNOR PAGOLO, AND THE

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: DUKE DI GRAVINA ORSINI

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: BY NICOLO MACHIAVELLI

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: The Duke Valentino had returned from Lombardy, where he had been to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: clear himself with the King of France from the calumnies which had been

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: raised against him by the Florentines concerning the rebellion of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Arezzo and other towns in the Val di Chiana, and had arrived at Imola,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: whence he intended with his army to enter upon the campaign against

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Giovanni Bentivogli, the tyrant of Bologna: for he intended to bring

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that city under his domination, and to make it the head of his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Romagnian duchy.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: These matters coming to the knowledge of the Vitelli and Orsini and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: their following, it appeared to them that the duke would become too

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: powerful, and it was feared that, having seized Bologna, he would seek

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to destroy them in order that he might become supreme in Italy. Upon

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: this a meeting was called at Magione in the district of Perugia, to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: which came the cardinal, Pagolo, and the Duke di Gravina Orsini,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Vitellozzo Vitelli, Oliverotto da Fermo, Gianpagolo Baglioni, the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: tyrant of Perugia, and Messer Antonio da Venafro, sent by Pandolfo

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Petrucci, the Prince of Siena. Here were discussed the power and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: courage of the duke and the necessity of curbing his ambitions, which

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: might otherwise bring danger to the rest of being ruined. And they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: decided not to abandon the Bentivogli, but to strive to win over the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Florentines; and they sent their men to one place and another,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: promising to one party assistance and to another encouragement to unite

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: with them against the common enemy. This meeting was at once reported

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: throughout all Italy, and those who were discontented under the duke,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: among whom were the people of Urbino, took hope of effecting a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: revolution.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Thus it arose that, men’s minds being thus unsettled, it was decided by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: certain men of Urbino to seize the fortress of San Leo, which was held

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: for the duke, and which they captured by the following means. The

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: castellan was fortifying the rock and causing timber to be taken there;

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: so the conspirators watched, and when certain beams which were being

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: carried to the rock were upon the bridge, so that it was prevented from

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: being drawn up by those inside, they took the opportunity of leaping

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: upon the bridge and thence into the fortress. Upon this capture being

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: effected, the whole state rebelled and recalled the old duke, being

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: encouraged in this, not so much by the capture of the fort, as by the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Diet at Magione, from whom they expected to get assistance.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Those who heard of the rebellion at Urbino thought they would not lose

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the opportunity, and at once assembled their men so as to take any

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: town, should any remain in the hands of the duke in that state; and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: they sent again to Florence to beg that republic to join with them in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: destroying the common firebrand, showing that the risk was lessened and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that they ought not to wait for another opportunity.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: But the Florentines, from hatred, for sundry reasons, of the Vitelli

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and Orsini, not only would not ally themselves, but sent Nicolo

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Machiavelli, their secretary, to offer shelter and assistance to the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: duke against his enemies. The duke was found full of fear at Imola,
