author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: because, against everybody’s expectation, his soldiers had at once gone

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: over to the enemy and he found himself disarmed and war at his door.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: But recovering courage from the offers of the Florentines, he decided

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to temporize before fighting with the few soldiers that remained to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: him, and to negotiate for a reconciliation, and also to get assistance.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: This latter he obtained in two ways, by sending to the King of France

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: for men and by enlisting men-at-arms and others whom he turned into

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: cavalry of a sort: to all he gave money.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Notwithstanding this, his enemies drew near to him, and approached

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Fossombrone, where they encountered some men of the duke and, with the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: aid of the Orsini and Vitelli, routed them. When this happened, the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: duke resolved at once to see if he could not close the trouble with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: offers of reconciliation, and being a most perfect dissembler he did

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: not fail in any practices to make the insurgents understand that he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: wished every man who had acquired anything to keep it, as it was enough

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: for him to have the title of prince, whilst others might have the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: principality.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: And the duke succeeded so well in this that they sent Signor Pagolo to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: him to negotiate for a reconciliation, and they brought their army to a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: standstill. But the duke did not stop his preparations, and took every

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: care to provide himself with cavalry and infantry, and that such

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: preparations might not be apparent to the others, he sent his troops in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: separate parties to every part of the Romagna. In the meanwhile there

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: came also to him five hundred French lancers, and although he found

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: himself sufficiently strong to take vengeance on his enemies in open

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: war, he considered that it would be safer and more advantageous to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: outwit them, and for this reason he did not stop the work of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: reconciliation.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: And that this might be effected the duke concluded a peace with them in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: which he confirmed their former covenants; he gave them four thousand

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ducats at once; he promised not to injure the Bentivogli; and he formed

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: an alliance with Giovanni; and moreover he would not force them to come

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: personally into his presence unless it pleased them to do so. On the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: other hand, they promised to restore to him the duchy of Urbino and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: other places seized by them, to serve him in all his expeditions, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: not to make war against or ally themselves with any one without his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: permission.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: This reconciliation being completed, Guido Ubaldo, the Duke of Urbino,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: again fled to Venice, having first destroyed all the fortresses in his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: state; because, trusting in the people, he did not wish that the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: fortresses, which he did not think he could defend, should be held by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the enemy, since by these means a check would be kept upon his friends.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: But the Duke Valentino, having completed this convention, and dispersed

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: his men throughout the Romagna, set out for Imola at the end of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: November together with his French men-at-arms: thence he went to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Cesena, where he stayed some time to negotiate with the envoys of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Vitelli and Orsini, who had assembled with their men in the duchy of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Urbino, as to the enterprise in which they should now take part; but

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: nothing being concluded, Oliverotto da Fermo was sent to propose that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: if the duke wished to undertake an expedition against Tuscany they were

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ready; if he did not wish it, then they would besiege Sinigalia. To

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: this the duke replied that he did not wish to enter into war with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Tuscany, and thus become hostile to the Florentines, but that he was

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: very willing to proceed against Sinigalia.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: It happened that not long afterwards the town surrendered, but the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: fortress would not yield to them because the castellan would not give

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: it up to any one but the duke in person; therefore they exhorted him to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: come there. This appeared a good opportunity to the duke, as, being

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: invited by them, and not going of his own will, he would awaken no

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: suspicions. And the more to reassure them, he allowed all the French

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: men-at-arms who were with him in Lombardy to depart, except the hundred

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: lancers under Mons. di Candales, his brother-in-law. He left Cesena

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: about the middle of December, and went to Fano, and with the utmost

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: cunning and cleverness he persuaded the Vitelli and Orsini to wait for

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: him at Sinigalia, pointing out to them that any lack of compliance

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: would cast a doubt upon the sincerity and permanency of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: reconciliation, and that he was a man who wished to make use of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: arms and councils of his friends. But Vitellozzo remained very

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: stubborn, for the death of his brother warned him that he should not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: offend a prince and afterwards trust him; nevertheless, persuaded by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Pagolo Orsini, whom the duke had corrupted with gifts and promises, he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: agreed to wait.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Upon this the duke, before his departure from Fano, which was to be on

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: 30th December 1502, communicated his designs to eight of his most

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: trusted followers, among whom were Don Michele and the Monsignor

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: d’Euna, who was afterwards cardinal; and he ordered that, as soon as

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Vitellozzo, Pagolo Orsini, the Duke di Gravina, and Oliverotto should

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: arrive, his followers in pairs should take them one by one, entrusting

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: certain men to certain pairs, who should entertain them until they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: reached Sinigalia; nor should they be permitted to leave until they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: came to the duke’s quarters, where they should be seized.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: The duke afterwards ordered all his horsemen and infantry, of which

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: there were more than two thousand cavalry and ten thousand footmen, to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: assemble by daybreak at the Metauro, a river five miles distant from

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Fano, and await him there. He found himself, therefore, on the last day

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of December at the Metauro with his men, and having sent a cavalcade of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: about two hundred horsemen before him, he then moved forward the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: infantry, whom he accompanied with the rest of the men-at-arms.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Fano and Sinigalia are two cities of La Marca situated on the shore of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the Adriatic Sea, fifteen miles distant from each other, so that he who

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: goes towards Sinigalia has the mountains on his right hand, the bases

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of which are touched by the sea in some places. The city of Sinigalia

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: is distant from the foot of the mountains a little more than a bow-shot

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and from the shore about a mile. On the side opposite to the city runs

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: a little river which bathes that part of the walls looking towards

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Fano, facing the high road. Thus he who draws near to Sinigalia comes

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: for a good space by road along the mountains, and reaches the river

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: which passes by Sinigalia. If he turns to his left hand along the bank

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of it, and goes for the distance of a bow-shot, he arrives at a bridge

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: which crosses the river; he is then almost abreast of the gate that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: leads into Sinigalia, not by a straight line, but transversely. Before

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: this gate there stands a collection of houses with a square to which

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the bank of the river forms one side.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: The Vitelli and Orsini having received orders to wait for the duke, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to honour him in person, sent away their men to several castles distant

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: from Sinigalia about six miles, so that room could be made for the men

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of the duke; and they left in Sinigalia only Oliverotto and his band,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: which consisted of one thousand infantry and one hundred and fifty

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: horsemen, who were quartered in the suburb mentioned above. Matters

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: having been thus arranged, the Duke Valentino left for Sinigalia, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: when the leaders of the cavalry reached the bridge they did not pass

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: over, but having opened it, one portion wheeled towards the river and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the other towards the country, and a way was left in the middle through

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: which the infantry passed, without stopping, into the town.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Vitellozzo, Pagolo, and the Duke di Gravina on mules, accompanied by a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: few horsemen, went towards the duke; Vitellozo, unarmed and wearing a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: cape lined with green, appeared very dejected, as if conscious of his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: approaching death—a circumstance which, in view of the ability of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: man and his former fortune, caused some amazement. And it is said that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: when he parted from his men before setting out for Sinigalia to meet

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the duke he acted as if it were his last parting from them. He

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: recommended his house and its fortunes to his captains, and advised his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: nephews that it was not the fortune of their house, but the virtues of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: their fathers that should be kept in mind. These three, therefore, came

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: before the duke and saluted him respectfully, and were received by him

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: with goodwill; they were at once placed between those who were

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: commissioned to look after them.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: But the duke noticing that Oliverotto, who had remained with his band

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: in Sinigalia, was missing—for Oliverotto was waiting in the square

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: before his quarters near the river, keeping his men in order and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: drilling them—signalled with his eye to Don Michelle, to whom the care

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of Oliverotto had been committed, that he should take measures that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Oliverotto should not escape. Therefore Don Michele rode off and joined

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Oliverotto, telling him that it was not right to keep his men out of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: their quarters, because these might be taken up by the men of the duke;

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and he advised him to send them at once to their quarters and to come

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: himself to meet the duke. And Oliverotto, having taken this advice,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: came before the duke, who, when he saw him, called to him; and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Oliverotto, having made his obeisance, joined the others.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: So the whole party entered Sinigalia, dismounted at the duke’s

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: quarters, and went with him into a secret chamber, where the duke made

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: them prisoners; he then mounted on horseback, and issued orders that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the men of Oliverotto and the Orsini should be stripped of their arms.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Those of Oliverotto, being at hand, were quickly settled, but those of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the Orsini and Vitelli, being at a distance, and having a presentiment

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of the destruction of their masters, had time to prepare themselves,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and bearing in mind the valour and discipline of the Orsinian and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Vitellian houses, they stood together against the hostile forces of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: country and saved themselves.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: But the duke’s soldiers, not being content with having pillaged the men

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of Oliverotto, began to sack Sinigalia, and if the duke had not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: repressed this outrage by killing some of them they would have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: completely sacked it. Night having come and the tumult being silenced,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the duke prepared to kill Vitellozzo and Oliverotto; he led them into a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: room and caused them to be strangled. Neither of them used words in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: keeping with their past lives: Vitellozzo prayed that he might ask of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the pope full pardon for his sins; Oliverotto cringed and laid the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: blame for all injuries against the duke on Vitellozzo. Pagolo and the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Duke di Gravina Orsini were kept alive until the duke heard from Rome

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that the pope had taken the Cardinal Orsino, the Archbishop of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Florence, and Messer Jacopo da Santa Croce. After which news, on 18th

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: January 1502, in the castle of Pieve, they also were strangled in the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: same way.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: THE LIFE OF CASTRUCCIO CASTRACANI OF LUCCA

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: WRITTEN BY NICOLO MACHIAVELLI

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: And sent to his friends ZANOBI BUONDELMONTI And LUIGI ALAMANNI

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: CASTRUCCIO CASTRACANI 1284-1328

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: It appears, dearest Zanobi and Luigi, a wonderful thing to those who

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: have considered the matter, that all men, or the larger number of them,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: who have performed great deeds in the world, and excelled all others in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: their day, have had their birth and beginning in baseness and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: obscurity; or have been aggrieved by Fortune in some outrageous way.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: They have either been exposed to the mercy of wild beasts, or they have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: had so mean a parentage that in shame they have given themselves out to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: be sons of Jove or of some other deity. It would be wearisome to relate

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: who these persons may have been because they are well known to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: everybody, and, as such tales would not be particularly edifying to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: those who read them, they are omitted. I believe that these lowly

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: beginnings of great men occur because Fortune is desirous of showing to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the world that such men owe much to her and little to wisdom, because

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: she begins to show her hand when wisdom can really take no part in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: their career: thus all success must be attributed to her. Castruccio

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Castracani of Lucca was one of those men who did great deeds, if he is

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: measured by the times in which he lived and the city in which he was

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: born; but, like many others, he was neither fortunate nor distinguished

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: in his birth, as the course of this history will show. It appeared to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: be desirable to recall his memory, because I have discerned in him such

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: indications of valour and fortune as should make him a great exemplar

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to men. I think also that I ought to call your attention to his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: actions, because you of all men I know delight most in noble deeds.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: The family of Castracani was formerly numbered among the noble families

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of Lucca, but in the days of which I speak it had somewhat fallen in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: estate, as so often happens in this world. To this family was born a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: son Antonio, who became a priest of the order of San Michele of Lucca,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and for this reason was honoured with the title of Messer Antonio. He

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: had an only sister, who had been married to Buonaccorso Cenami, but

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Buonaccorso dying she became a widow, and not wishing to marry again

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: went to live with her brother. Messer Antonio had a vineyard behind the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: house where he resided, and as it was bounded on all sides by gardens,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: any person could have access to it without difficulty. One morning,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: shortly after sunrise, Madonna Dianora, as the sister of Messer Antonio

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: was called, had occasion to go into the vineyard as usual to gather

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: herbs for seasoning the dinner, and hearing a slight rustling among the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: leaves of a vine she turned her eyes in that direction, and heard

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: something resembling the cry of an infant. Whereupon she went towards

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: it, and saw the hands and face of a baby who was lying enveloped in the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: leaves and who seemed to be crying for its mother. Partly wondering and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: partly fearing, yet full of compassion, she lifted it up and carried it

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to the house, where she washed it and clothed it with clean linen as is

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: customary, and showed it to Messer Antonio when he returned home. When

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: he heard what had happened and saw the child he was not less surprised

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: or compassionate than his sister. They discussed between themselves

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: what should be done, and seeing that he was priest and that she had no

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: children, they finally determined to bring it up. They had a nurse for

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: it, and it was reared and loved as if it were their own child. They

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: baptized it, and gave it the name of Castruccio after their father. As

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the years passed Castruccio grew very handsome, and gave evidence of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: wit and discretion, and learnt with a quickness beyond his years those

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: lessons which Messer Antonio imparted to him. Messer Antonio intended

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to make a priest of him, and in time would have inducted him into his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: canonry and other benefices, and all his instruction was given with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: this object; but Antonio discovered that the character of Castruccio

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: was quite unfitted for the priesthood. As soon as Castruccio reached

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the age of fourteen he began to take less notice of the chiding of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Messer Antonio and Madonna Dianora and no longer to fear them; he left

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: off reading ecclesiastical books, and turned to playing with arms,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: delighting in nothing so much as in learning their uses, and in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: running, leaping, and wrestling with other boys. In all exercises he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: far excelled his companions in courage and bodily strength, and if at

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: any time he did turn to books, only those pleased him which told of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: wars and the mighty deeds of men. Messer Antonio beheld all this with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: vexation and sorrow.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: There lived in the city of Lucca a gentleman of the Guinigi family,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: named Messer Francesco, whose profession was arms and who in riches,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: bodily strength, and valour excelled all other men in Lucca. He had

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: often fought under the command of the Visconti of Milan, and as a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Ghibelline was the valued leader of that party in Lucca. This gentleman

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: resided in Lucca and was accustomed to assemble with others most

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: mornings and evenings under the balcony of the Podesta, which is at the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: top of the square of San Michele, the finest square in Lucca, and he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: had often seen Castruccio taking part with other children of the street

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: in those games of which I have spoken. Noticing that Castruccio far

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: excelled the other boys, and that he appeared to exercise a royal

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: authority over them, and that they loved and obeyed him, Messer

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Francesco became greatly desirous of learning who he was. Being

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: informed of the circumstances of the bringing up of Castruccio he felt

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: a greater desire to have him near to him. Therefore he called him one

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: day and asked him whether he would more willingly live in the house of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: a gentleman, where he would learn to ride horses and use arms, or in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the house of a priest, where he would learn nothing but masses and the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: services of the Church. Messer Francesco could see that it pleased

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Castruccio greatly to hear horses and arms spoken of, even though he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: stood silent, blushing modestly; but being encouraged by Messer

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Francesco to speak, he answered that, if his master were agreeable,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: nothing would please him more than to give up his priestly studies and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: take up those of a soldier. This reply delighted Messer Francesco, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: in a very short time he obtained the consent of Messer Antonio, who was

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: driven to yield by his knowledge of the nature of the lad, and the fear

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that he would not be able to hold him much longer.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Thus Castruccio passed from the house of Messer Antonio the priest to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the house of Messer Francesco Guinigi the soldier, and it was

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: astonishing to find that in a very short time he manifested all that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: virtue and bearing which we are accustomed to associate with a true

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: gentleman. In the first place he became an accomplished horseman, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: could manage with ease the most fiery charger, and in all jousts and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: tournaments, although still a youth, he was observed beyond all others,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and he excelled in all exercises of strength and dexterity. But what

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: enhanced so much the charm of these accomplishments, was the delightful

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: modesty which enabled him to avoid offence in either act or word to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: others, for he was deferential to the great men, modest with his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: equals, and courteous to his inferiors. These gifts made him beloved,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: not only by all the Guinigi family, but by all Lucca. When Castruccio

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: had reached his eighteenth year, the Ghibellines were driven from Pavia

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: by the Guelphs, and Messer Francesco was sent by the Visconti to assist

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the Ghibellines, and with him went Castruccio, in charge of his forces.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Castruccio gave ample proof of his prudence and courage in this

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: expedition, acquiring greater reputation than any other captain, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: his name and fame were known, not only in Pavia, but throughout all

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Lombardy.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Castruccio, having returned to Lucca in far higher estimation than he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: left it, did not omit to use all the means in his power to gain as many

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: friends as he could, neglecting none of those arts which are necessary

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: for that purpose. About this time Messer Francesco died, leaving a son

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: thirteen years of age named Pagolo, and having appointed Castruccio to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: be his son’s tutor and administrator of his estate. Before he died

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Francesco called Castruccio to him, and prayed him to show Pagolo that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: goodwill which he (Francesco) had always shown to HIM, and to render to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the son the gratitude which he had not been able to repay to the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: father. Upon the death of Francesco, Castruccio became the governor and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: tutor of Pagolo, which increased enormously his power and position, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: created a certain amount of envy against him in Lucca in place of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: former universal goodwill, for many men suspected him of harbouring

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: tyrannical intentions. Among these the leading man was Giorgio degli

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Opizi, the head of the Guelph party. This man hoped after the death of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Messer Francesco to become the chief man in Lucca, but it seemed to him

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that Castruccio, with the great abilities which he already showed, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: holding the position of governor, deprived him of his opportunity;

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: therefore he began to sow those seeds which should rob Castruccio of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: his eminence. Castruccio at first treated this with scorn, but

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: afterwards he grew alarmed, thinking that Messer Giorgio might be able

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to bring him into disgrace with the deputy of King Ruberto of Naples

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and have him driven out of Lucca.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: The Lord of Pisa at that time was Uguccione of the Faggiuola of Arezzo,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: who being in the first place elected their captain afterwards became

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: their lord. There resided in Paris some exiled Ghibellines from Lucca,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: with whom Castruccio held communications with the object of effecting

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: their restoration by the help of Uguccione. Castruccio also brought

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: into his plans friends from Lucca who would not endure the authority of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the Opizi. Having fixed upon a plan to be followed, Castruccio

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: cautiously fortified the tower of the Onesti, filling it with supplies

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and munitions of war, in order that it might stand a siege for a few

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: days in case of need. When the night came which had been agreed upon

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: with Uguccione, who had occupied the plain between the mountains and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Pisa with many men, the signal was given, and without being observed

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Uguccione approached the gate of San Piero and set fire to the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: portcullis. Castruccio raised a great uproar within the city, calling

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the people to arms and forcing open the gate from his side. Uguccione

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: entered with his men, poured through the town, and killed Messer

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Giorgio with all his family and many of his friends and supporters. The

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: governor was driven out, and the government reformed according to the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: wishes of Uguccione, to the detriment of the city, because it was found

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that more than one hundred families were exiled at that time. Of those

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: who fled, part went to Florence and part to Pistoia, which city was the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: headquarters of the Guelph party, and for this reason it became most

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: hostile to Uguccione and the Lucchese.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: As it now appeared to the Florentines and others of the Guelph party

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that the Ghibellines absorbed too much power in Tuscany, they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: determined to restore the exiled Guelphs to Lucca. They assembled a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: large army in the Val di Nievole, and seized Montecatini; from thence

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: they marched to Montecarlo, in order to secure the free passage into

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Lucca. Upon this Uguccione assembled his Pisan and Lucchese forces, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: with a number of German cavalry which he drew out of Lombardy, he moved

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: against the quarters of the Florentines, who upon the appearance of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: enemy withdrew from Montecarlo, and posted themselves between

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Montecatini and Pescia. Uguccione now took up a position near to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Montecarlo, and within about two miles of the enemy, and slight

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: skirmishes between the horse of both parties were of daily occurrence.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Owing to the illness of Uguccione, the Pisans and Lucchese delayed

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: coming to battle with the enemy. Uguccione, finding himself growing

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: worse, went to Montecarlo to be cured, and left the command of the army

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: in the hands of Castruccio. This change brought about the ruin of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Guelphs, who, thinking that the hostile army having lost its captain

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: had lost its head, grew over-confident. Castruccio observed this, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: allowed some days to pass in order to encourage this belief; he also

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: showed signs of fear, and did not allow any of the munitions of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: camp to be used. On the other side, the Guelphs grew more insolent the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: more they saw these evidences of fear, and every day they drew out in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the order of battle in front of the army of Castruccio. Presently,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: deeming that the enemy was sufficiently emboldened, and having mastered

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: their tactics, he decided to join battle with them. First he spoke a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: few words of encouragement to his soldiers, and pointed out to them the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: certainty of victory if they would but obey his commands. Castruccio

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: had noticed how the enemy had placed all his best troops in the centre

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of the line of battle, and his less reliable men on the wings of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: army; whereupon he did exactly the opposite, putting his most valiant

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: men on the flanks, while those on whom he could not so strongly rely he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: moved to the centre. Observing this order of battle, he drew out of his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: lines and quickly came in sight of the hostile army, who, as usual, had

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: come in their insolence to defy him. He then commanded his centre

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: squadrons to march slowly, whilst he moved rapidly forward those on the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: wings. Thus, when they came into contact with the enemy, only the wings

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of the two armies became engaged, whilst the center battalions remained

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: out of action, for these two portions of the line of battle were

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: separated from each other by a long interval and thus unable to reach

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: each other. By this expedient the more valiant part of Castruccio’s men

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: were opposed to the weaker part of the enemy’s troops, and the most

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: efficient men of the enemy were disengaged; and thus the Florentines

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: were unable to fight with those who were arrayed opposite to them, or

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to give any assistance to their own flanks. So, without much

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: difficulty, Castruccio put the enemy to flight on both flanks, and the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: centre battalions took to flight when they found themselves exposed to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: attack, without having a chance of displaying their valour. The defeat

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: was complete, and the loss in men very heavy, there being more than ten

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: thousand men killed with many officers and knights of the Guelph party

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: in Tuscany, and also many princes who had come to help them, among whom

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: were Piero, the brother of King Ruberto, and Carlo, his nephew, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Filippo, the lord of Taranto. On the part of Castruccio the loss did

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: not amount to more than three hundred men, among whom was Francesco,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the son of Uguccione, who, being young and rash, was killed in the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: first onset.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: This victory so greatly increased the reputation of Castruccio that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Uguccione conceived some jealousy and suspicion of him, because it

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: appeared to Uguccione that this victory had given him no increase of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: power, but rather than diminished it. Being of this mind, he only

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: waited for an opportunity to give effect to it. This occurred on the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: death of Pier Agnolo Micheli, a man of great repute and abilities in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Lucca, the murderer of whom fled to the house of Castruccio for refuge.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: On the sergeants of the captain going to arrest the murderer, they were

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: driven off by Castruccio, and the murderer escaped. This affair coming

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to the knowledge of Uguccione, who was then at Pisa, it appeared to him

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: a proper opportunity to punish Castruccio. He therefore sent for his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: son Neri, who was the governor of Lucca, and commissioned him to take

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Castruccio prisoner at a banquet and put him to death. Castruccio,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: fearing no evil, went to the governor in a friendly way, was

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: entertained at supper, and then thrown into prison. But Neri, fearing

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to put him to death lest the people should be incensed, kept him alive,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: in order to hear further from his father concerning his intentions.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Ugucionne cursed the hesitation and cowardice of his son, and at once

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: set out from Pisa to Lucca with four hundred horsemen to finish the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: business in his own way; but he had not yet reached the baths when the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Pisans rebelled and put his deputy to death and created Count Gaddo

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: della Gherardesca their lord. Before Uguccione reached Lucca he heard

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of the occurrences at Pisa, but it did not appear wise to him to turn

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: back, lest the Lucchese with the example of Pisa before them should

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: close their gates against him. But the Lucchese, having heard of what

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: had happened at Pisa, availed themselves of this opportunity to demand

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the liberation of Castruccio, notwithstanding that Uguccione had

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: arrived in their city. They first began to speak of it in private

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: circles, afterwards openly in the squares and streets; then they raised

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: a tumult, and with arms in their hands went to Uguccione and demanded

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that Castruccio should be set at liberty. Uguccione, fearing that worse

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: might happen, released him from prison. Whereupon Castruccio gathered

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: his friends around him, and with the help of the people attacked

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Uguccione; who, finding he had no resource but in flight, rode away

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: with his friends to Lombardy, to the lords of Scale, where he died in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: poverty.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: But Castruccio from being a prisoner became almost a prince in Lucca,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and he carried himself so discreetly with his friends and the people

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that they appointed him captain of their army for one year. Having

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: obtained this, and wishing to gain renown in war, he planned the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: recovery of the many towns which had rebelled after the departure of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Uguccione, and with the help of the Pisans, with whom he had concluded

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: a treaty, he marched to Serezzana. To capture this place he constructed

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: a fort against it, which is called to-day Zerezzanello; in the course

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of two months Castruccio captured the town. With the reputation gained

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: at that siege, he rapidly seized Massa, Carrara, and Lavenza, and in a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: short time had overrun the whole of Lunigiana. In order to close the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: pass which leads from Lombardy to Lunigiana, he besieged Pontremoli and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: wrested it from the hands of Messer Anastagio Palavicini, who was the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: lord of it. After this victory he returned to Lucca, and was welcomed

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: by the whole people. And now Castruccio, deeming it imprudent any

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: longer to defer making himself a prince, got himself created the lord

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of Lucca by the help of Pazzino del Poggio, Puccinello dal Portico,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Francesco Boccansacchi, and Cecco Guinigi, all of whom he had

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: corrupted; and he was afterwards solemnly and deliberately elected

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prince by the people. At this time Frederick of Bavaria, the King of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the Romans, came into Italy to assume the Imperial crown, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Castruccio, in order that he might make friends with him, met him at

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the head of five hundred horsemen. Castruccio had left as his deputy in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Lucca, Pagolo Guinigi, who was held in high estimation, because of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: people’s love for the memory of his father. Castruccio was received in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: great honour by Frederick, and many privileges were conferred upon him,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and he was appointed the emperor’s lieutenant in Tuscany. At this time

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the Pisans were in great fear of Gaddo della Gherardesca, whom they had

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: driven out of Pisa, and they had recourse for assistance to Frederick.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Frederick created Castruccio the lord of Pisa, and the Pisans, in dread

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of the Guelph party, and particularly of the Florentines, were

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: constrained to accept him as their lord.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Frederick, having appointed a governor in Rome to watch his Italian

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: affairs, returned to Germany. All the Tuscan and Lombardian

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Ghibellines, who followed the imperial lead, had recourse to Castruccio

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: for help and counsel, and all promised him the governorship of his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: country, if enabled to recover it with his assistance. Among these

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: exiles were Matteo Guidi, Nardo Scolari, Lapo Uberti, Gerozzo Nardi,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and Piero Buonaccorsi, all exiled Florentines and Ghibellines.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Castruccio had the secret intention of becoming the master of all

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Tuscany by the aid of these men and of his own forces; and in order to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: gain greater weight in affairs, he entered into a league with Messer

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Matteo Visconti, the Prince of Milan, and organized for him the forces

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of his city and the country districts. As Lucca had five gates, he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: divided his own country districts into five parts, which he supplied

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: with arms, and enrolled the men under captains and ensigns, so that he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: could quickly bring into the field twenty thousand soldiers, without

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: those whom he could summon to his assistance from Pisa. While he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: surrounded himself with these forces and allies, it happened at Messer

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Matteo Visconti was attacked by the Guelphs of Piacenza, who had driven

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: out the Ghibellines with the assistance of a Florentine army and the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: King Ruberto. Messer Matteo called upon Castruccio to invade the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Florentines in their own territories, so that, being attacked at home,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: they should be compelled to draw their army out of Lombardy in order to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: defend themselves. Castruccio invaded the Valdarno, and seized

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Fucecchio and San Miniato, inflicting immense damage upon the country.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Whereupon the Florentines recalled their army, which had scarcely

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: reached Tuscany, when Castruccio was forced by other necessities to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: return to Lucca.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: There resided in the city of Lucca the Poggio family, who were so

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: powerful that they could not only elevate Castruccio, but even advance

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: him to the dignity of prince; and it appearing to them they had not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: received such rewards for their services as they deserved, they incited

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: other families to rebel and to drive Castruccio out of Lucca. They

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: found their opportunity one morning, and arming themselves, they set

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: upon the lieutenant whom Castruccio had left to maintain order and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: killed him. They endeavoured to raise the people in revolt, but Stefano

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: di Poggio, a peaceable old man who had taken no hand in the rebellion,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: intervened and compelled them by his authority to lay down their arms;

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and he offered to be their mediator with Castruccio to obtain from him

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: what they desired. Therefore they laid down their arms with no greater

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: intelligence than they had taken them up. Castruccio, having heard the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: news of what had happened at Lucca, at once put Pagolo Guinigi in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: command of the army, and with a troop of cavalry set out for home.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Contrary to his expectations, he found the rebellion at an end, yet he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: posted his men in the most advantageous places throughout the city. As

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: it appeared to Stefano that Castruccio ought to be very much obliged to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: him, he sought him out, and without saying anything on his own behalf,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: for he did not recognize any need for doing so, he begged Castruccio to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: pardon the other members of his family by reason of their youth, their

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: former friendships, and the obligations which Castruccio was under to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: their house. To this Castruccio graciously responded, and begged

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Stefano to reassure himself, declaring that it gave him more pleasure

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to find the tumult at an end than it had ever caused him anxiety to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: hear of its inception. He encouraged Stefano to bring his family to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: him, saying that he thanked God for having given him the opportunity of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: showing his clemency and liberality. Upon the word of Stefano and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Castruccio they surrendered, and with Stefano were immediately thrown

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: into prison and put to death. Meanwhile the Florentines had recovered

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: San Miniato, whereupon it seemed advisable to Castruccio to make peace,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: as it did not appear to him that he was sufficiently secure at Lucca to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: leave him. He approached the Florentines with the proposal of a truce,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: which they readily entertained, for they were weary of the war, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: desirous of getting rid of the expenses of it. A treaty was concluded

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: with them for two years, by which both parties agreed to keep the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: conquests they had made. Castruccio thus released from this trouble,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: turned his attention to affairs in Lucca, and in order that he should

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: not again be subject to the perils from which he had just escaped, he,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: under various pretences and reasons, first wiped out all those who by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: their ambition might aspire to the principality; not sparing one of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: them, but depriving them of country and property, and those whom he had

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: in his hands of life also, stating that he had found by experience that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: none of them were to be trusted. Then for his further security he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: raised a fortress in Lucca with the stones of the towers of those whom

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: he had killed or hunted out of the state.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Whilst Castruccio made peace with the Florentines, and strengthened his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: position in Lucca, he neglected no opportunity, short of open war, of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: increasing his importance elsewhere. It appeared to him that if he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: could get possession of Pistoia, he would have one foot in Florence,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: which was his great desire. He, therefore, in various ways made friends

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: with the mountaineers, and worked matters so in Pistoia that both

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: parties confided their secrets to him. Pistoia was divided, as it

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: always had been, into the Bianchi and Neri parties; the head of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Bianchi was Bastiano di Possente, and of the Neri, Jacopo da Gia. Each

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of these men held secret communications with Castruccio, and each

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: desired to drive the other out of the city; and, after many

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: threatenings, they came to blows. Jacopo fortified himself at the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Florentine gate, Bastiano at that of the Lucchese side of the city;

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: both trusted more in Castruccio than in the Florentines, because they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: believed that Castruccio was far more ready and willing to fight than

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the Florentines, and they both sent to him for assistance. He gave

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: promises to both, saying to Bastiano that he would come in person, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to Jacopo that he would send his pupil, Pagolo Guinigi. At the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: appointed time he sent forward Pagolo by way of Pisa, and went himself

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: direct to Pistoia; at midnight both of them met outside the city, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: both were admitted as friends. Thus the two leaders entered, and at a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: signal given by Castruccio, one killed Jacopo da Gia, and the other

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Bastiano di Possente, and both took prisoners or killed the partisans

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of either faction. Without further opposition Pistoia passed into the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: hands of Castruccio, who, having forced the Signoria to leave the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: palace, compelled the people to yield obedience to him, making them

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: many promises and remitting their old debts. The countryside flocked to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the city to see the new prince, and all were filled with hope and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: quickly settled down, influenced in a great measure by his great

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: valour.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: About this time great disturbances arose in Rome, owing to the dearness

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of living which was caused by the absence of the pontiff at Avignon.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: The German governor, Enrico, was much blamed for what happened—murders

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and tumults following each other daily, without his being able to put

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: an end to them. This caused Enrico much anxiety lest the Romans should

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: call in Ruberto, the King of Naples, who would drive the Germans out of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the city, and bring back the Pope. Having no nearer friend to whom he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: could apply for help than Castruccio, he sent to him, begging him not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: only to give him assistance, but also to come in person to Rome.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Castruccio considered that he ought not to hesitate to render the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: emperor this service, because he believed that he himself would not be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: safe if at any time the emperor ceased to hold Rome. Leaving Pagolo

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Guinigi in command at Lucca, Castruccio set out for Rome with six

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: hundred horsemen, where he was received by Enrico with the greatest

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: distinction. In a short time the presence of Castruccio obtained such

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: respect for the emperor that, without bloodshed or violence, good order

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: was restored, chiefly by reason of Castruccio having sent by sea from

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the country round Pisa large quantities of corn, and thus removed the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: source of the trouble. When he had chastised some of the Roman leaders,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and admonished others, voluntary obedience was rendered to Enrico.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Castruccio received many honours, and was made a Roman senator. This

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: dignity was assumed with the greatest pomp, Castruccio being clothed in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: a brocaded toga, which had the following words embroidered on its

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: front: “I am what God wills.” Whilst on the back was: “What God desires

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: shall be.”

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: During this time the Florentines, who were much enraged that Castruccio

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: should have seized Pistoia during the truce, considered how they could

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: tempt the city to rebel, to do which they thought would not be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: difficult in his absence. Among the exiled Pistoians in Florence were

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Baldo Cecchi and Jacopo Baldini, both men of leading and ready to face

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: danger. These men kept up communications with their friends in Pistoia,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and with the aid of the Florentines entered the city by night, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: after driving out some of Castruccio’s officials and partisans, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: killing others, they restored the city to its freedom. The news of this

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: greatly angered Castruccio, and taking leave of Enrico, he pressed on

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: in great haste to Pistoia. When the Florentines heard of his return,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: knowing that he would lose no time, they decided to intercept him with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: their forces in the Val di Nievole, under the belief that by doing so

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: they would cut off his road to Pistoia. Assembling a great army of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: supporters of the Guelph cause, the Florentines entered the Pistoian

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: territories. On the other hand, Castruccio reached Montecarlo with his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: army; and having heard where the Florentines’ lay, he decided not to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: encounter it in the plains of Pistoia, nor to await it in the plains of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Pescia, but, as far as he possibly could, to attack it boldly in the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Pass of Serravalle. He believed that if he succeeded in this design,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: victory was assured, although he was informed that the Florentines had

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: thirty thousand men, whilst he had only twelve thousand. Although he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: had every confidence in his own abilities and the valour of his troops,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: yet he hesitated to attack his enemy in the open lest he should be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: overwhelmed by numbers. Serravalle is a castle between Pescia and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Pistoia, situated on a hill which blocks the Val di Nievole, not in the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: exact pass, but about a bowshot beyond; the pass itself is in places

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: narrow and steep, whilst in general it ascends gently, but is still

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: narrow, especially at the summit where the waters divide, so that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: twenty men side by side could hold it. The lord of Serravalle was

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Manfred, a German, who, before Castruccio became lord of Pistoia, had

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: been allowed to remain in possession of the castle, it being common to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the Lucchese and the Pistoians, and unclaimed by either—neither of them

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: wishing to displace Manfred as long as he kept his promise of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: neutrality, and came under obligations to no one. For these reasons,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and also because the castle was well fortified, he had always been able

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to maintain his position. It was here that Castruccio had determined to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: fall upon his enemy, for here his few men would have the advantage, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: there was no fear lest, seeing the large masses of the hostile force

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: before they became engaged, they should not stand. As soon as this

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: trouble with Florence arose, Castruccio saw the immense advantage which

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: possession of this castle would give him, and having an intimate

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: friendship with a resident in the castle, he managed matters so with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: him that four hundred of his men were to be admitted into the castle

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the night before the attack on the Florentines, and the castellan put

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to death.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Castruccio, having prepared everything, had now to encourage the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Florentines to persist in their desire to carry the seat of war away

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: from Pistoia into the Val di Nievole, therefore he did not move his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: army from Montecarlo. Thus the Florentines hurried on until they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: reached their encampment under Serravalle, intending to cross the hill

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: on the following morning. In the meantime, Castruccio had seized the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: castle at night, had also moved his army from Montecarlo, and marching

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: from thence at midnight in dead silence, had reached the foot of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Serravalle: thus he and the Florentines commenced the ascent of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: hill at the same time in the morning. Castruccio sent forward his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: infantry by the main road, and a troop of four hundred horsemen by a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: path on the left towards the castle. The Florentines sent forward four

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: hundred cavalry ahead of their army which was following, never

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: expecting to find Castruccio in possession of the hill, nor were they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: aware of his having seized the castle. Thus it happened that the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Florentine horsemen mounting the hill were completely taken by surprise

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: when they discovered the infantry of Castruccio, and so close were they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: upon it they had scarcely time to pull down their visors. It was a case

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of unready soldiers being attacked by ready, and they were assailed

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: with such vigour that with difficulty they could hold their own,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: although some few of them got through. When the noise of the fighting

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: reached the Florentine camp below, it was filled with confusion. The

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: cavalry and infantry became inextricably mixed: the captains were

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: unable to get their men either backward or forward, owing to the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: narrowness of the pass, and amid all this tumult no one knew what ought

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to be done or what could be done. In a short time the cavalry who were

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: engaged with the enemy’s infantry were scattered or killed without

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: having made any effective defence because of their unfortunate

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: position, although in sheer desperation they had offered a stout

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: resistance. Retreat had been impossible, with the mountains on both

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: flanks, whilst in front were their enemies, and in the rear their

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: friends. When Castruccio saw that his men were unable to strike a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: decisive blow at the enemy and put them to flight, he sent one thousand

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: infantrymen round by the castle, with orders to join the four hundred

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: horsemen he had previously dispatched there, and commanded the whole

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: force to fall upon the flank of the enemy. These orders they carried

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: out with such fury that the Florentines could not sustain the attack,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: but gave way, and were soon in full retreat—conquered more by their

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: unfortunate position than by the valour of their enemy. Those in the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: rear turned towards Pistoia, and spread through the plains, each man

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: seeking only his own safety. The defeat was complete and very

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: sanguinary. Many captains were taken prisoners, among whom were Bandini

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: dei Rossi, Francesco Brunelleschi, and Giovanni della Tosa, all

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Florentine noblemen, with many Tuscans and Neapolitans who fought on

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the Florentine side, having been sent by King Ruberto to assist the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Guelphs. Immediately the Pistoians heard of this defeat they drove out

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the friends of the Guelphs, and surrendered to Castruccio. He was not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: content with occupying Prato and all the castles on the plains on both

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: sides of the Arno, but marched his army into the plain of Peretola,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: about two miles from Florence. Here he remained many days, dividing the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: spoils, and celebrating his victory with feasts and games, holding

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: horse races, and foot races for men and women. He also struck medals in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: commemoration of the defeat of the Florentines. He endeavoured to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: corrupt some of the citizens of Florence, who were to open the city

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: gates at night; but the conspiracy was discovered, and the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: participators in it taken and beheaded, among whom were Tommaso Lupacci

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and Lambertuccio Frescobaldi. This defeat caused the Florentines great

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: anxiety, and despairing of preserving their liberty, they sent envoys

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to King Ruberto of Naples, offering him the dominion of their city; and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: he, knowing of what immense importance the maintenance of the Guelph

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: cause was to him, accepted it. He agreed with the Florentines to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: receive from them a yearly tribute of two hundred thousand florins, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: he sent his son Carlo to Florence with four thousand horsemen.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Shortly after this the Florentines were relieved in some degree of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: pressure of Castruccio’s army, owing to his being compelled to leave

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: his positions before Florence and march on Pisa, in order to suppress a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: conspiracy that had been raised against him by Benedetto Lanfranchi,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: one of the first men in Pisa, who could not endure that his fatherland

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: should be under the dominion of the Lucchese. He had formed this

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: conspiracy, intending to seize the citadel, kill the partisans of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Castruccio, and drive out the garrison. As, however, in a conspiracy

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: paucity of numbers is essential to secrecy, so for its execution a few

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: are not sufficient, and in seeking more adherents to his conspiracy

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Lanfranchi encountered a person who revealed the design to Castruccio.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: This betrayal cannot be passed by without severe reproach to Bonifacio

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Cerchi and Giovanni Guidi, two Florentine exiles who were suffering

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: their banishment in Pisa. Thereupon Castruccio seized Benedetto and put

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: him to death, and beheaded many other noble citizens, and drove their

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: families into exile. It now appeared to Castruccio that both Pisa and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Pistoia were thoroughly disaffected; he employed much thought and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: energy upon securing his position there, and this gave the Florentines

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: their opportunity to reorganize their army, and to await the coming of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Carlo, the son of the King of Naples. When Carlo arrived they decided

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to lose no more time, and assembled a great army of more than thirty

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: thousand infantry and ten thousand cavalry—having called to their aid

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: every Guelph there was in Italy. They consulted whether they should

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: attack Pistoia or Pisa first, and decided that it would be better to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: march on the latter—a course, owing to the recent conspiracy, more

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: likely to succeed, and of more advantage to them, because they believed

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that the surrender of Pistoia would follow the acquisition of Pisa.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: In the early part of May 1328, the Florentines put in motion this army

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and quickly occupied Lastra, Signa, Montelupo, and Empoli, passing from

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: thence on to San Miniato. When Castruccio heard of the enormous army

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: which the Florentines were sending against him, he was in no degree

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: alarmed, believing that the time had now arrived when Fortune would

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: deliver the empire of Tuscany into his hands, for he had no reason to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: think that his enemy would make a better fight, or had better prospects

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of success, than at Pisa or Serravalle. He assembled twenty thousand

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: foot soldiers and four thousand horsemen, and with this army went to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Fucecchio, whilst he sent Pagolo Guinigi to Pisa with five thousand

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: infantry. Fucecchio has a stronger position than any other town in the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Pisan district, owing to its situation between the rivers Arno and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Gusciana and its slight elevation above the surrounding plain.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Moreover, the enemy could not hinder its being victualled unless they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: divided their forces, nor could they approach it either from the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: direction of Lucca or Pisa, nor could they get through to Pisa, or

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: attack Castruccio’s forces except at a disadvantage. In one case they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: would find themselves placed between his two armies, the one under his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: own command and the other under Pagolo, and in the other case they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: would have to cross the Arno to get to close quarters with the enemy,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: an undertaking of great hazard. In order to tempt the Florentines to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: take this latter course, Castruccio withdrew his men from the banks of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the river and placed them under the walls of Fucecchio, leaving a wide

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: expanse of land between them and the river.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: The Florentines, having occupied San Miniato, held a council of war to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: decide whether they should attack Pisa or the army of Castruccio, and,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: having weighed the difficulties of both courses, they decided upon the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: latter. The river Arno was at that time low enough to be fordable, yet

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the water reached to the shoulders of the infantrymen and to the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: saddles of the horsemen. On the morning of 10 June 1328, the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Florentines commenced the battle by ordering forward a number of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: cavalry and ten thousand infantry. Castruccio, whose plan of action was

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: fixed, and who well knew what to do, at once attacked the Florentines

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: with five thousand infantry and three thousand horsemen, not allowing

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: them to issue from the river before he charged them; he also sent one

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: thousand light infantry up the river bank, and the same number down the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Arno. The infantry of the Florentines were so much impeded by their

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: arms and the water that they were not able to mount the banks of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: river, whilst the cavalry had made the passage of the river more

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: difficult for the others, by reason of the few who had crossed having

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: broken up the bed of the river, and this being deep with mud, many of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the horses rolled over with their riders and many of them had stuck so

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: fast that they could not move. When the Florentine captains saw the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: difficulties their men were meeting, they withdrew them and moved

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: higher up the river, hoping to find the river bed less treacherous and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the banks more adapted for landing. These men were met at the bank by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the forces which Castruccio had already sent forward, who, being light

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: armed with bucklers and javelins in their hands, let fly with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: tremendous shouts into the faces and bodies of the cavalry. The horses,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: alarmed by the noise and the wounds, would not move forward, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: trampled each other in great confusion. The fight between the men of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Castruccio and those of the enemy who succeeded in crossing was sharp

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and terrible; both sides fought with the utmost desperation and neither

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: would yield. The soldiers of Castruccio fought to drive the others back

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: into the river, whilst the Florentines strove to get a footing on land

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: in order to make room for the others pressing forward, who if they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: could but get out of the water would be able to fight, and in this

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: obstinate conflict they were urged on by their captains. Castruccio

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: shouted to his men that these were the same enemies whom they had

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: before conquered at Serravalle, whilst the Florentines reproached each

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: other that the many should be overcome by the few. At length

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Castruccio, seeing how long the battle had lasted, and that both his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: men and the enemy were utterly exhausted, and that both sides had many

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: killed and wounded, pushed forward another body of infantry to take up

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: a position at the rear of those who were fighting; he then commanded

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: these latter to open their ranks as if they intended to retreat, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: one part of them to turn to the right and another to the left. This

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: cleared a space of which the Florentines at once took advantage, and
