author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: thus gained possession of a portion of the battlefield. But when these

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: tired soldiers found themselves at close quarters with Castruccio’s

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: reserves they could not stand against them and at once fell back into

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the river. The cavalry of either side had not as yet gained any

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: decisive advantage over the other, because Castruccio, knowing his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: inferiority in this arm, had commanded his leaders only to stand on the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: defensive against the attacks of their adversaries, as he hoped that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: when he had overcome the infantry he would be able to make short work

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of the cavalry. This fell out as he had hoped, for when he saw the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Florentine army driven back across the river he ordered the remainder

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of his infantry to attack the cavalry of the enemy. This they did with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: lance and javelin, and, joined by their own cavalry, fell upon the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: enemy with the greatest fury and soon put him to flight. The Florentine

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: captains, having seen the difficulty their cavalry had met with in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: crossing the river, had attempted to make their infantry cross lower

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: down the river, in order to attack the flanks of Castruccio’s army. But

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: here, also, the banks were steep and already lined by the men of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Castruccio, and this movement was quite useless. Thus the Florentines

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: were so completely defeated at all points that scarcely a third of them

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: escaped, and Castruccio was again covered with glory. Many captains

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: were taken prisoners, and Carlo, the son of King Ruberto, with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Michelagnolo Falconi and Taddeo degli Albizzi, the Florentine

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: commissioners, fled to Empoli. If the spoils were great, the slaughter

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: was infinitely greater, as might be expected in such a battle. Of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Florentines there fell twenty thousand two hundred and thirty-one men,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: whilst Castruccio lost one thousand five hundred and seventy men.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: But Fortune growing envious of the glory of Castruccio took away his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: life just at the time when she should have preserved it, and thus

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ruined all those plans which for so long a time he had worked to carry

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: into effect, and in the successful prosecution of which nothing but

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: death could have stopped him. Castruccio was in the thick of the battle

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the whole of the day; and when the end of it came, although fatigued

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and overheated, he stood at the gate of Fucecchio to welcome his men on

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: their return from victory and personally thank them. He was also on the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: watch for any attempt of the enemy to retrieve the fortunes of the day;

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: he being of the opinion that it was the duty of a good general to be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the first man in the saddle and the last out of it. Here Castruccio

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: stood exposed to a wind which often rises at midday on the banks of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Arno, and which is often very unhealthy; from this he took a chill, of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: which he thought nothing, as he was accustomed to such troubles; but it

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: was the cause of his death. On the following night he was attacked with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: high fever, which increased so rapidly that the doctors saw it must

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prove fatal. Castruccio, therefore, called Pagolo Guinigi to him, and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: addressed him as follows:

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: “If I could have believed that Fortune would have cut me off in the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: midst of the career which was leading to that glory which all my

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: successes promised, I should have laboured less, and I should have left

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: thee, if a smaller state, at least with fewer enemies and perils,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: because I should have been content with the governorships of Lucca and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Pisa. I should neither have subjugated the Pistoians, nor outraged the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Florentines with so many injuries. But I would have made both these

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: peoples my friends, and I should have lived, if no longer, at least

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: more peacefully, and have left you a state without a doubt smaller, but

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: one more secure and established on a surer foundation. But Fortune, who

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: insists upon having the arbitrament of human affairs, did not endow me

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: with sufficient judgment to recognize this from the first, nor the time

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to surmount it. Thou hast heard, for many have told thee, and I have

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: never concealed it, how I entered the house of thy father whilst yet a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: boy—a stranger to all those ambitions which every generous soul should

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: feel—and how I was brought up by him, and loved as though I had been

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: born of his blood; how under his governance I learned to be valiant and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: capable of availing myself of all that fortune, of which thou hast been

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: witness. When thy good father came to die, he committed thee and all

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: his possessions to my care, and I have brought thee up with that love,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and increased thy estate with that care, which I was bound to show. And

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: in order that thou shouldst not only possess the estate which thy

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: father left, but also that which my fortune and abilities have gained,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: I have never married, so that the love of children should never deflect

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: my mind from that gratitude which I owed to the children of thy father.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Thus I leave thee a vast estate, of which I am well content, but I am

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: deeply concerned, inasmuch as I leave it thee unsettled and insecure.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Thou hast the city of Lucca on thy hands, which will never rest

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: contented under thy government. Thou hast also Pisa, where the men are

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of nature changeable and unreliable, who, although they may be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: sometimes held in subjection, yet they will ever disdain to serve under

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: a Lucchese. Pistoia is also disloyal to thee, she being eaten up with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: factions and deeply incensed against thy family by reason of the wrongs

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: recently inflicted upon them. Thou hast for neighbours the offended

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Florentines, injured by us in a thousand ways, but not utterly

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: destroyed, who will hail the news of my death with more delight than

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: they would the acquisition of all Tuscany. In the Emperor and in the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: princes of Milan thou canst place no reliance, for they are far

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: distant, slow, and their help is very long in coming. Therefore, thou

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: hast no hope in anything but in thine own abilities, and in the memory

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: of my valour, and in the prestige which this latest victory has brought

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: thee; which, as thou knowest how to use it with prudence, will assist

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: thee to come to terms with the Florentines, who, as they are suffering

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: under this great defeat, should be inclined to listen to thee. And

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: whereas I have sought to make them my enemies, because I believed that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: war with them would conduce to my power and glory, thou hast every

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: inducement to make friends of them, because their alliance will bring

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: thee advantages and security. It is of the greatest important in this

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: world that a man should know himself, and the measure of his own

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: strength and means; and he who knows that he has not a genius for

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: fighting must learn how to govern by the arts of peace. And it will be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: well for thee to rule thy conduct by my counsel, and to learn in this

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: way to enjoy what my life-work and dangers have gained; and in this

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: thou wilt easily succeed when thou hast learnt to believe that what I

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: have told thee is true. And thou wilt be doubly indebted to me, in that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: I have left thee this realm and have taught thee how to keep it.”

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: After this there came to Castruccio those citizens of Pisa, Pistoia,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and Lucca, who had been fighting at his side, and whilst recommending

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Pagolo to them, and making them swear obedience to him as his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: successor, he died. He left a happy memory to those who had known him,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and no prince of those times was ever loved with such devotion as he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: was. His obsequies were celebrated with every sign of mourning, and he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: was buried in San Francesco at Lucca. Fortune was not so friendly to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Pagolo Guinigi as she had been to Castruccio, for he had not the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: abilities. Not long after the death of Castruccio, Pagolo lost Pisa,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and then Pistoia, and only with difficulty held on to Lucca. This

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: latter city continued in the family of Guinigi until the time of the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: great-grandson of Pagolo.

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: From what has been related here it will be seen that Castruccio was a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: man of exceptional abilities, not only measured by men of his own time,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: but also by those of an earlier date. In stature he was above the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ordinary height, and perfectly proportioned. He was of a gracious

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: presence, and he welcomed men with such urbanity that those who spoke

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: with him rarely left him displeased. His hair was inclined to be red,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and he wore it cut short above the ears, and, whether it rained or

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: snowed, he always went without a hat. He was delightful among friends,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: but terrible to his enemies; just to his subjects; ready to play false

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: with the unfaithful, and willing to overcome by fraud those whom he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: desired to subdue, because he was wont to say that it was the victory

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that brought the glory, not the methods of achieving it. No one was

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: bolder in facing danger, none more prudent in extricating himself. He

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: was accustomed to say that men ought to attempt everything and fear

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: nothing; that God is a lover of strong men, because one always sees

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that the weak are chastised by the strong. He was also wonderfully

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: sharp or biting though courteous in his answers; and as he did not look

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: for any indulgence in this way of speaking from others, so he was not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: angered with others did not show it to him. It has often happened that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: he has listened quietly when others have spoken sharply to him, as on

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: the following occasions. He had caused a ducat to be given for a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: partridge, and was taken to task for doing so by a friend, to whom

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Castruccio had said: “You would not have given more than a penny.”

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: “That is true,” answered the friend. Then said Castruccio to him: “A

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: ducat is much less to me.” Having about him a flatterer on whom he had

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: spat to show that he scorned him, the flatterer said to him: “Fisherman

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: are willing to let the waters of the sea saturate them in order that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: they may take a few little fishes, and I allow myself to be wetted by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: spittle that I may catch a whale”; and this was not only heard by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Castruccio with patience but rewarded. When told by a priest that it

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: was wicked for him to live so sumptuously, Castruccio said: “If that be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: a vice then you should not fare so splendidly at the feasts of our

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: saints.” Passing through a street he saw a young man as he came out of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: a house of ill fame blush at being seen by Castruccio, and said to him:

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: “Thou shouldst not be ashamed when thou comest out, but when thou goest

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: into such places.” A friend gave him a very curiously tied knot to undo

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and was told: “Fool, do you think that I wish to untie a thing which

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: gave so much trouble to fasten.” Castruccio said to one who professed

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to be a philosopher: “You are like the dogs who always run after those

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: who will give them the best to eat,” and was answered: “We are rather

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: like the doctors who go to the houses of those who have the greatest

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: need of them.” Going by water from Pisa to Leghorn, Castruccio was much

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: disturbed by a dangerous storm that sprang up, and was reproached for

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: cowardice by one of those with him, who said that he did not fear

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: anything. Castruccio answered that he did not wonder at that, since

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: every man valued his soul for what is was worth. Being asked by one

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: what he ought to do to gain estimation, he said: “When thou goest to a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: banquet take care that thou dost not seat one piece of wood upon

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: another.” To a person who was boasting that he had read many things,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Castruccio said: “He knows better than to boast of remembering many

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: things.” Someone bragged that he could drink much without becoming

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: intoxicated. Castruccio replied: “An ox does the same.” Castruccio was

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: acquainted with a girl with whom he had intimate relations, and being

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: blamed by a friend who told him that it was undignified for him to be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: taken in by a woman, he said: “She has not taken me in, I have taken

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: her.” Being also blamed for eating very dainty foods, he answered:

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: “Thou dost not spend as much as I do?” and being told that it was true,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: he continued: “Then thou art more avaricious than I am gluttonous.”

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Being invited by Taddeo Bernardi, a very rich and splendid citizen of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Luca, to supper, he went to the house and was shown by Taddeo into a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: chamber hung with silk and paved with fine stones representing flowers

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and foliage of the most beautiful colouring. Castruccio gathered some

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: saliva in his mouth and spat it out upon Taddeo, and seeing him much

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: disturbed by this, said to him: “I knew not where to spit in order to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: offend thee less.” Being asked how Caesar died he said: “God willing I

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: will die as he did.” Being one night in the house of one of his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: gentlemen where many ladies were assembled, he was reproved by one of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: his friends for dancing and amusing himself with them more than was

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: usual in one of his station, so he said: “He who is considered wise by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: day will not be considered a fool at night.” A person came to demand a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: favour of Castruccio, and thinking he was not listening to his plea

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: threw himself on his knees to the ground, and being sharply reproved by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Castruccio, said: “Thou art the reason of my acting thus for thou hast

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: thy ears in thy feet,” whereupon he obtained double the favour he had

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: asked. Castruccio used to say that the way to hell was an easy one,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: seeing that it was in a downward direction and you travelled

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: blindfolded. Being asked a favour by one who used many superfluous

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: words, he said to him: “When you have another request to make, send

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: someone else to make it.” Having been wearied by a similar man with a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: long oration who wound up by saying: “Perhaps I have fatigued you by

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: speaking so long,” Castruccio said: “You have not, because I have not

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: listened to a word you said.” He used to say of one who had been a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: beautiful child and who afterwards became a fine man, that he was

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: dangerous, because he first took the husbands from the wives and now he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: took the wives from their husbands. To an envious man who laughed, he

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: said: “Do you laugh because you are successful or because another is

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: unfortunate?” Whilst he was still in the charge of Messer Francesco

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Guinigi, one of his companions said to him: “What shall I give you if

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: you will let me give you a blow on the nose?” Castruccio answered: “A

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: helmet.” Having put to death a citizen of Lucca who had been

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: instrumental in raising him to power, and being told that he had done

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: wrong to kill one of his old friends, he answered that people deceived

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: themselves; he had only killed a new enemy. Castruccio praised greatly

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: those men who intended to take a wife and then did not do so, saying

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that they were like men who said they would go to sea, and then refused

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: when the time came. He said that it always struck him with surprise

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that whilst men in buying an earthen or glass vase would sound it first

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to learn if it were good, yet in choosing a wife they were content with

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: only looking at her. He was once asked in what manner he would wish to

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: be buried when he died, and answered: “With the face turned downwards,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: for I know when I am gone this country will be turned upside down.” On

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: being asked if it had ever occurred to him to become a friar in order

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to save his soul, he answered that it had not, because it appeared

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: strange to him that Fra Lazerone should go to Paradise and Uguccione

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: della Faggiuola to the Inferno. He was once asked when should a man eat

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: to preserve his health, and replied: “If the man be rich let him eat

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: when he is hungry; if he be poor, then when he can.” Seeing one of his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: gentlemen make a member of his family lace him up, he said to him: “I

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: pray God that you will let him feed you also.” Seeing that someone had

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: written upon his house in Latin the words: “May God preserve this house

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: from the wicked,” he said, “The owner must never go in.” Passing

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: through one of the streets he saw a small house with a very large door,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and remarked: “That house will fly through the door.” He was having a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: discussion with the ambassador of the King of Naples concerning the

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: property of some banished nobles, when a dispute arose between them,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: and the ambassador asked him if he had no fear of the king. “Is this

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: king of yours a bad man or a good one?” asked Castruccio, and was told

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: that he was a good one, whereupon he said, “Why should you suggest that

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: I should be afraid of a good man?”

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: I could recount many other stories of his sayings both witty and

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: weighty, but I think that the above will be sufficient testimony to his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: high qualities. He lived forty-four years, and was in every way a

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: prince. And as he was surrounded by many evidences of his good fortune,

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: so he also desired to have near him some memorials of his bad fortune;

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: therefore the manacles with which he was chained in prison are to be

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: seen to this day fixed up in the tower of his residence, where they

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: were placed by him to testify forever to his days of adversity. As in

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: his life he was inferior neither to Philip of Macedon, the father of

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Alexander, nor to Scipio of Rome, so he died in the same year of his

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: age as they did, and he would doubtless have excelled both of them had

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: Fortune decreed that he should be born, not in Lucca, but in Macedonia

author: Niccolò Machiavelli
text: or Rome.
